I think we can characterize him as questionable this week. Marcus Gilbert, the same thing, with his left shoulder, and Casey Hampton, the same thing, with his right shoulder. James Harrison is out. Chris Kemoeatu has a left knee injury. His availability will be dictated by his ability to practice throughout the week. We expect Aaron Smith to miss another game with his right foot sprain. Some of the other guys that are trying to work their way back in: Cortez Allen is expected to work his way back in, Rashard Mendenhall continues to progress, as will Ben Roethlisberger with his left foot injury. We are moving in a positive direction with some of those things. Marcus Gilbert, being the new one, if he's unable to participate we will swing Jonathan Scott over to right tackle like we did in the game last Sunday. In regards to last Sunday, it was a necessary response to bounce back from a sub-standard performance. It's what we needed, particularly at home in front of our fans. We made the necessary plays in all three phases. I thought we got shots in the arm for portions of the game from all three phases. I thought the big element of the game, at least early on, was that we scored touchdowns instead of field goals. When you look at the Tennessee Titans, they are number one in the league in points allowed. Touchdowns are very tough to come by against them. I thought our ability to score touchdowns in those early possessions instead of kicking field goals was a shot in the arm for us. All in all, it was the necessary response from us. Hopefully we are a team that's ready to move forward, and continue to build on a positive outing. I know that's going to be drawn to our attentions as we formulate our plans this week, and put things in place as we get ready to deal with the Jacksonville Jaguars. I think the first place you start when you look at the Jaguars is Maurice Jones-Drew. Whether you talk about offense, defense or special teams, there's probably no one in football that means more to their team than Maurice Jones-Drew, in terms of the things he's capable of doing and the things he does. When you watch him on tape, he's a very physical runner. He has great vision, power and speed. He's not small; he's just short. He has built in leverage. We've had issues, like many others, with him in the past. He's a very competitive football player, and they put the ball in his hands. Maybe not as much in the passing game this year, as they have in the past, but I'd imagine that's a function of them getting settled at the quarterback position. We expect that to increase. We have to not only defend this man in terms of the running game, but we have to be sharp against him in the passing game. That includes the screen game. If you look at what they've done up front, they have a nice group that they have put together. They have a nice blend of young and old. They have Brad Meester at center. He's been around for a long time. The interesting element of the group is Eugene Monroe. He's their left tackle. He's a high-pedigree, first-rounder from the University of Virginia. The guy that plays alongside of him is Eben Britton. He's another high-pedigree, high-round pick out of Arizona. Those two guys work really well in tandem together. On their toss plays, they utilize their skills, particularly Eugene Monroe's, getting him out in open space. That's been an asset to them. If you look at their wide receivers, it starts with their tight end, Marcedes Lewis. He is coming off a very productive year. He's really made himself into a well-rounded player. People are very familiar with his receiving skills, ever since he played at UCLA. He's really made himself into a good blocker. We have to deal with him on the perimeter and edges. Mike Thomas is the number one third-down receiver in the AFC. They give him the ball in a variety of ways. He's a quick to speed young man. He's very good in the screen game. He creates mismatches if you get him in the slot. He's done an awesome job for those guys. They went through a quarterback switch and went with Gabbert, the young man out of Missouri, a few weeks back. He's done a nice job acclimating himself. His pedigree is obvious when you look at the tape. He can make all the throws. He's extremely mobile. They are doing a nice job in terms of helping him manage the game. You can see that when they get into third-down situations. They mix in the run quite frequently, and it's effective. They also mix in the screen game, whether its running back screens or wide receiver screens, particularly when it's third-and-long. I think they do a nice job of that. They've converted some third downs. Equally as important though, they've done a nice job protecting the young man, and allowed him to find rhythm. Defensively for them, the strength is in the unit. These guys are playing really good football. They are seventh or eighth in the league right now in total defense. They are doing a nice job of just keeping it simple. They hustle, hit and run to the football, very rarely are they out of place. They don't miss runs or screens. When you talk about the people, I like their end combination with what they do with Jeremy Mincey and Matt Roth. Both of those guys are playing extremely hard and are very productive. We anticipate them adding Aaron Kampman to that mix. He's a Pro Bowl-caliber guy. I don't know how they intend to use him but we better have our antennas up, at least initially, to find out where he's going to be located. His reputation is legitimate. They went out and got some free agents at the linebacker position, some veteran guys that know how to play. Paul Posluszny is in the middle. He's a sideline to sideline, run and chase tackler. He's also very good in pass defense. He's touched quite a few footballs. Clint Session, he's a Pitt man, is playing outside linebacker. He's playing extremely well for them. The back end is led by Rashean Mathis. He is a solid veteran player. He has gotten after us pretty good in the past. I've seen him run with the football against us in stadiums a few times, probably a few too many times. He's a good, solid veteran player. He's a great tackler and cover man. I think the rest of the group mirrors him. They acquired Dawan Landry from Baltimore in free agency at the safety position. What they are doing at the nickel position with Drew Coleman, a man they picked up from the Jets, is probably as impressive as anything they do. He's playing really well. He's blitzing. He's very good at underneath defense, whether he's playing zone or man-to-man. He's getting around the football quite a bit, and he's making a bunch of splash plays for them. Number-30, we respect him and what his tape looks like at this point. From a special teams standpoint, they are solid there. Josh Scobee, I think, is perfect on the year with his kicks. We have a lot of work to do this week. We need to build on that performance. We have another AFC South team coming in here. We respect what is AFC football, and we understand what that means. We need to see a victory this week, and we are excited about preparing to do so. (Q: Who will replace Chris Kemoeatu if he cannot play?) A: We will let the week determine that. We are not going to talk hypothetically in regards to that. If he is able to prepare and practice, we will take a look at those scenarios and formulate what is the best group for us. But as of right now, he hasn't practiced, and we will anticipate moving forward with Doug Legursky and Ramon Foster until his availability proves otherwise. (Q: How did Lawrence Timmons do?) A: I thought he did some nice things, particularly against the run. I think he had five or so tackles in the game, and he did a few more things than we even anticipated. He moved around late in the game in some sub-package football, allowing Chris Carter to do the simplest assignment when he was rotating. We value position flexibility. Lawrence has done it before. We expect him to do it, and do it well. It was a good start. He is going to have a few more weeks there, and we expect him to continue to improve. (Q: Re: Rashard Mendenhall's hamstring:) A: I said we expect him to participate this week, and we will see where that participation leads us. (Q: Is he still the feature running back?) A: Again, we will let his level of health and participation in the work week dictate that. (Q: Will Worilds have a chance to start at ROLB if he is healthy?) A: As of right now, Timmons is going to be there. I don't know how optimistic we are of Jason Worilds at this juncture. When a guy goes down in open grass with a quad injury, usually that means he will miss a couple weeks. (Q: Re: James Harrison's return:) A: We are looking at roughly a month, based on what we are told.  But again, every man is different, particularly guys that are wired like James. We will leave a seat on the bus for him, if you know what I mean. (Q: Re: Chris Hoke:) A: He did a nice job. We came up short a few times there early on. I think Chris Johnson reeled off a 20-yard run or so there early but he settled in, and we settled in very nicely and played extremely hard. Then it turned into a lot sub-package football. He needs to be prepared to play more snaps than he played a week ago. (Q: Is it easier for rookie QBs to play in this league now?) A: I think in general, unless you are talking about somebody who is really talented, most of the time it is just a man seizing an opportunity, and the opportunity has nothing to do with what he has done but what is going on around him. I think that is the case with many rookies' play regardless of position but especially with the quarterback position. (Q: Do they have a limited play book with Blaine Gabbert, or is it wide open?) A: Again, they have done a nice job of managing situations. I wouldn't say it is a limited playbook. I say they manage situations, and they keep him out of hotspots, third-and-long and things of that nature. They have done a nice job of managing it and helping him remain in rhythm. (Q: Why do you think Jacksonville has lost four in a row?) A: I think when you are going through the type of transition that they have at the quarterback position, not only here recently but dating back to the week prior to the start of the regular season, there is going to be a period of adjustment. They let David Garrard go the week before the opener. Then of course, they went with Luke (McXown), and then they made the transition to Blaine. In the last month, they have had three primary signal callers, and I think that creates a tough transition period. I think they are doing a nice job managing it, playing to their strengths, utilizing Maurice Jones-Drew. That's a great place to start, and I think they have been really salty on defense. (Q: Will Max Starks need time to get the soreness out?) A: I hope he doesn't because he won't receive any. We have work to do. (Q: Re: Bryant McFadden:) A: I think he is getting pretty close to healthy. At this point we have liked what the other guys have done in the interim, talking about William Gay and Keenan Lewis. Such is life in the NFL though. When those guys step up and are given an opportunity and play at a high level, than you are not going to fix it if it's not broken. McFadden has done a nice job of working while he is waiting for his opportunity to get back into the rotation, and to me, those are all good issues to have. We have a reliable veteran cornerback that we know is capable of playing good football and is moving closer to 100% health, and we have some guys who have answered the call in the interim and have showed us that they are capable of playing salty football. So those are good issues. (Q: What is the difference between last year's pass defense and this year?) A: I'm not ready to characterize it in that way. Last year's 19 or 20 games, that body of work, and at this point we are just four or five games into this body of work, so I am not ready to look for any trends or anything of that nature to this point. I think we are doing a nice job of keeping the ball in front of us, challenging throws, and that is a nice place to start. (Q: Re: Isaac Redman:) A: I thought he did a nice job but that is kind of what we expected. Isaac is not an unknown commodity in terms of what he is capable of doing with the ball in his hands, as a blitz pick-up guy and all of the things that encompass being a running back for us. So we were pleased but not surprised.   (Q: Was Jonathan Dwyer's big play a pleasant surprise?) A: I wouldn't necessarily call that a surprise. Since Jonathan has been here, I think he has always made it very evident that running the football is something that he does well. But we are more pleased with some of the other things that he did in the game and other things that come with being a professional running back. He made two tackles on kick coverage units. He did a nice job there. He is growing in all areas, and that is what is going to be required for him to continue to move forward and retain his helmet as some of those guys who are injured get healthy. (Q: Is it easier or harder to defend a player who makes up a large portion of a team's offense?) A: It doesn't necessarily make is easier. It just depends on the level of success that they are able to have that day. You look at some other guys that make up big portions of their teams' offense, like Adrian Peterson and Ray Rice. It doesn't make those guys any easier to defend. So we are not going into this thing with the mindset that they are going to be easy to defend, because we know who their primary ball carrier is going to be. We have a lot of respect for him. He gets those amounts of totes and gets that percentage of the offense because he is very capable.   (Q: Re: Fake punt:) A: I think some of those things probably get a little more play than they deserve.  We are ready to go with things such as that every week.  It doesn't always unfold.  Sometime we check out at the line of scrimmage.  It is just part of our football.  (Q: Re: Special teams:) A: I think we have been kind of feast or famine.  We have created some big plays but we have also given up some big plays.  We recognize moving forward that giving up big plays could reduce our chances of winning and by that I mean that we have had a kick blocked and punt blocked here in the last two weeks.  We have had some splash, no doubt.  But those negative plays, we have to eliminate, and eliminate them in a hurry if we want that unit to continue to be an asset for us. (Q: Re: Ben's mobility last game:) A: I don't know if he moved as he normally does but he moved well enough. (Q: On an onside kick, can the other team hit your player when he tries to catch the ball?) A: Yes. (Q: How does that differ from any other kick?) A: Once that ball goes past 10 yards, it's free. That's just football-101. (Q: He doesn't become a receiver?) A: Once the ball hits the ground in the manner in which it did before it went the 10 yards, he cannot fair catch it. It's a live ball. It's a free for all. That's why people like doing it. That's why we have to have guys over there like Arnaz Battle ready to field it. It's not an easy endeavor by any stretch. I wish it did go in the air without hitting the ground. Then we could have put up a fair catch sign and not gotten abused like we did. (Q: Re: A false start penalty but the play isn't blown dead:) A: Your guess is as good as mine. I am still trying to figure it out. I know that Byron Boston, who was on our side, was blowing the whistle. I don't know if any other whistles were being blown, and that runner was running. It's unfortunate. We just have to a better job of continuing to emphasize the whistle in the game of football, in my opinion. (Q: Was that play accurately enforced?) A: It was, based on the rule. If you have two fouls on the play, the personal foul is going to trump the other one. My contention is that if we are contingent on blowing the whistle, those actions don't even occur. (Q: Re: Dwyer and Weslye Saunders playing on special teams:) A: Weslye did a nice job. He's a big gun but he can run. They are just joining other bodies that are capable of helping us win. Arnaz Battle is on that unit. Emmanuel Sanders has been on that unit for the better part of the year and a half that he's been here. We subscribe to the more that you can do theory. Just because they are offensive players doesn't mean that they aren't capable of covering kicks. Arnaz Battle continues to illustrate that, as does Emmanuel Sanders. Now we are looking at a couple of new guys that can show that as well in Weslye Saunders and Jonathan Dwyer.  (Q: Are people starting to kick away from Antonio Brown?) A: I don't know. I don't know if he's done enough to dictate that at this point. He hasn't even gone to the house. I think they are going to kick it to him.

Good afternoon. I will quickly start with our injury report. We have some new and kind of significant injuries to discuss. I will start with James Harrison. He has a right orbital fracture around his eye socket. That's going to be fixed tomorrow. Needless to say he is going to be out for a number of weeks. I will have more details regarding that injury and the rate of recovery after he has that surgical procedure tomorrow to have that fixed. Cortez Allen has a right ankle sprain that will make him questionable. Casey Hampton has a right shoulder contusion, that may limit him. We will see how he works this week. Rashard Mendenhall has a right hamstring strain. That may limit him at the early portions of the week. Mewlede Moore has a left ankle sprain. That's more severe. His participation in this game is questionable. Aaron Smith has a right mid-foot sprain. The same thing can be said there. His participation in this game is extremely questionable. Jason Worilds has a left quad strain. His participation is doubtful. Ben Roethlisberger had his foot x-rayed and had an MRI. Thankfully nothing is broken there. It is a sprain. It may limit him at the early portions of the week but we anticipate him being able to participate in this football game. Some of the other guys that have missed time due to injuries in the recent weeks, we anticipate having them back, Doug Legursky being one of them, Jonathan Scott being another and Bryant McFadden among others. That's kind of the injury lineup if you will. Obviously, we have some adjustments that need to take place in terms of who is playing where and preparations, now specifically at the outside linebacker position with two linebackers being out. We believe that deems necessary to move Lawrence Timmons to right outside linebacker. We are going to do that. He's going to play there. Larry Foote will play inside. We will go on with that group. Lawrence has practiced there and played there before. Larry Foote is no stranger to the Mack linebacker position. We anticipate those guys will play winning football for us. Our performance in Houston, in some areas it leaves a lot to be desired. In other areas I thought some things were very encouraging. The reality is that it was a losing effort. We have to get better. We can't continue to make some of the mistakes we have made and think that we are going to beat good people, particularly at their place. I thought we were in the game. I thought the guys fought. I thought we had an opportunity to do some things in the second half. It didn't come together for us. We created too big of a hole for ourselves to get out of. And we weren't able to make sufficient enough plays to win. That being said, it's a new week for us. We have a new challenge in the Tennessee Titans. They are extremely hot. They've won three straight games. They have a bunch of talented people. Thankfully we are playing them in the comforts of Heinz Field. We look forward to and appreciate the support of our fans. We are going to need it. Looking at Tennessee and what they've done here in the 2011 season, Matt Hasselbeck has done an awesome job for these guys. He's done a very good job of taking care of the football. They've gotten yards in chunks. He's spreading the ball around to a variety of receivers. Kenny Britt was doing great things before he got injured. Nate Washington and Matt have hooked up quite a bit. They've got a great rapport. Nate, I think, is the number one third-down receiver in the AFC. They have Chris Johnson running the football. And how we've defended the run recently makes that a doubly important challenge for us. I understand that they've had issues of their own in terms of running the football. You will see two scalded groups playing in that regard on Sunday. I look forward to our guys preparing for him. We've played him a lot recently. We know what he's capable of. He's a very dangerous man anytime he gets the ball in his hands. They do a nice job creating schemes for him and creating a package of plays that lean on his strengths as a runner. They have big, strong people up front. Their right tackle, Dave Stewart, is a special player. They have some vertical threat tight ends, guys that are capable of displacing themselves from the core. Jared Cook went 80 yards last weekend. They also have some guys in that group that are very good at blocking, veteran guys like Daniel Graham and Craig Stevens, a third-year man out of Washington. They have a well-rounded offense. I really think the acquisition of Matt Hasselbeck has been critical to that unit. He's doing a nice job as their signal caller and field general and keeping these guys moving the football and winning games. Defensively, they play with a similar personality that they've always played with in recent years. Their front four is very disruptive. They play a lot of people. That group is led by Jason Jones. We've seen quite a bit of him in recent years. He's been problematic for us, getting him blocked. He's a very good pass rusher. Others like Dave Ball and William Hayes add to that group. But again when you talk about this group it's about the strength and numbers in this group. They play as many as seven and eight people during the course of a football game in a regular rotation. They have a good linebacker core, a veteran core. Will Witherspoon has been joined by Barrett Ruud. Ruud was a free agent acquisition from the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. He plays in the middle. Akeem Ayers has done some nice things for them. He's a young linebacker from UCLA. In the secondary, I think the first place you start is with Cortland Finnegan. This guy really plays with a high motor. He's very aware and disruptive. He's a really good football player. He added some new tricks to his bag. This guy has played in the slot in the nickel. He's really doing a nice job as an underneath, zone-defender, poaching people and defending some of the throws and things you see in underneath coverage. He's doing a nice job of that as well as playing cornerback. Their safety group is rock solid with Michael Griffin and Chris Hope. They've been back their together for a number of years. They really do a nice job of complementing one another. They are capable of going into the box and playing with depth. Needless to say we have a worthy opponent, one that we respect and one that's extremely hot. They've won three straight games. We have to get prepared to play these guys. We have a lot of preparation to do, not only from the quality of our play, but the assimilation and placement of our people. And we need to gain cohesion in that way. We look forward to utilizing the week. (Q: Any doubt that Ben will be ready to go Sunday?) A: I think we are going to let the week speak to us. We are going to be prudent in our approach. We are going to have a package of plays ready for Charlie Batch if that is the case. But based on the information that I have right now we anticipate him being limited in the early portions of this week and being able to be in form by the weekend. (Q: With Marcus Gilbert and Doug Legursky coming back, how do you see the offensive line responding?) A: With those guys, if they are capable of playing, we are going to reinsert them into the lineup and proceed. (Q: With Mewelde Moore and Rashard Mendenhall limited, is Isaac Redman next up in the order?) A: If Rashard's injury does prevent him from playing, obviously that will mean that Isaac Redman will be the feature runner. With both guys, at the very least they are nursing injuries at the early portion of the week, it is obvious that Redman is going to get the bulk of the action and we expect Jonathan Dwyer to ready himself to contribute as well, if the opportunity presents itself. (Q: Re: Bringing someone in at running back:) A: For practice purposes we are going to look to at least bring in someone who is capable of being Chris Johnson-like in preparation this week. There are two elements when you prepare for a football game, not only in terms of what we are doing with our running backs, obviously with the injuries we have, to be thoughtful with how we prepare our guys and get these guys ready to play but also to get ready to defend the run against a guy like Chris Johnon. When you have injuries, it's interesting because we need guys capable of showing us what Chris Johnson and the Tennessee Titans are capable of doing in the run game. So that is where our interests are at this point. We will make those decisions here relatively quickly this afternoon. (Q: With Harrison and possibly Jason Worilds out, what do you do with that spot?) A: Again we are going to move Lawrence to outside linebacker. We are going to move Larry Foote to Mack linebacker. Of course, we've got Chris Carter as a young outside linebacker and Stevenson Sylvester who has played both inside and outside. (Q: Any update on Brett Keisel?) A: We anticipate him being back. His participation at the early portions of the week is going to guide us in that regard. But again, based on where he is and based on some of the run tests and stuff that he did the ladder part of last week, we feel comfortable that he is going to be able to participate in this game. As far as how we have defended the run of late, that has nothing to do with Brett Keisel's absence. We have capable men who play and who need to do a better job. (Q: How much of it is getting beat physically versus mentally?) A: It had been a little bit of both. In many instances it's always the case when you are not performing as you would like. There is a fine line in performing well and sub-standard. Some of the mistakes are mental, some are physical. They are not all centrally located in one person or position. But when you add those things up over the course of a football game, you get 8-10 snaps where someone is letting you down either mentally or physically. Then you have the opportunity to give up some big yards. Really, that is what we have to get more consistent in, assignments and techniques in terms of defending the run, and that is what we intend to do. (Q: Re: Greater sense of urgency:) A: We better have a sense of urgency. I think anytime you are coming off of a sub-standard performance when you lose, there needs to be a sense of urgency in terms of how you bounce back. But we are not going to make something out of this that it's not. We understand that we are capable of playing better. We expect to play better. We know where the solutions lie, of course within us, and how we prepare and ultimately how we perform. We have to get better technically. We have to get better from an assignment standpoint, not only on defense but also on offense and special teams, and that is what this week is about for us. (Q: Will Cameron Heyward replace Aaron Smith?) A: It depends on the availability of Brett Keisel. (Q: Re: Harrison injury:) A: I know very little.  I've been told that he broke his orbital bone and that it is going to require surgery tomorrow and they will have more details tomorrow on the rate of the recovery when he comes out of surgery. That's about all I know. I'm sorry. (Q: Is his vision okay?) A: Any time you are talking about the orbital bone, I think you need to get it fixed. Again, I am not doctor. And I don't pretend to be one. (Q: Does the limited number of padded practices affect how you prepare for a game?) A: In the big scheme of things it does but we also have some flexibility in terms of how we allocate those padded practice days. This week might be one of those weeks when we dial up a mulligan. (Q: What do you mean?) A: We may practice multiple times in pads this week. You are allowed to do that at least once during the regular season. There's no time like the present, given how we've performed and in terms of putting people in positions to play this week. (Q: Would Worilds have started if he wasn't hurt?) A: He definitely would have been in the discussion, because we like some of the things he's done, not only in terms of practice but in terms of what he's done in football games when given the opportunity. (Q: Re: Defense being too old, keeps coming up:) A: I really don't care to be honest with you. I don't care how our performances are characterized or the reasons why. We are not into making excuses or explanations. This is a bottom line business. And the bottom line is what we have on tape. That's not good enough right now. We are going to continue to work diligently to make sure it is.  (Q: Re: Redman and Moore having success last week running the football:) A: I think it's a product of us starting slow and really finding our rhythm, specifically in the last game. Our inability to run the football or find rhythm early in the game was because the Houston Texans possessed the ball for 21 out of the first 30 minutes of the game. We accept responsibility for that because we didn't do a good enough job converting third downs until that last drive before halftime. We felt good about our run plan going into the game. We stuck with the plan and we were able to move the football, running it in the second half. Unfortunately, due to injury, some of that didn't include Rashard. We are not going to read into that more than what it is. We will evaluate these guys in the early portions of the week in terms of their availability, and of course we are going to play healthy guys. We have a great deal of confidence in all of these guys. All of these guys have had their moments in time, not only this year but in the past. We have a good stable of backs.  (Q: Re: Taking for granted stopping the run:) A: I don't think that's an element of football that you take for granted. I will say that there are not many football elements that you do take for granted. That's definitely not one of them. (Q: What did you do well against the Texans?) A: I thought we stuck to our plan in terms of running the football. I thought we came out in the third quarter and established that presence and rhythm. We moved the ball a little bit and controlled the clock. We were able to keep our defense off the field some. After the big run, the 42-yard run that put them up by seven, our defense got the necessary stops at the end of the game to provide us an opportunity to score. Not only were they stops, they were quick stops. I think there were three straight three-and-outs, which is what you desire. We had good field position on a punt return late in the ball game that also gave us an opportunity to tie the game up. We had our opportunities. We just didn't do enough good things in all three phases to win the football game.  (Q: What are teams doing so well to run the football against your defense?) A: We aren't playing the run as well. I really think it's quite simple. Like I said after the game and I've said recently, there's nothing mystical about our issues, specifically in terms of stopping the run. We need to be better technically. We have to whoop blocks and make tackles. (Q: Re: Coach Mike Munchak:) A: I haven't thought a lot about that. He's new to the position but not new to the Titans. He was their offensive line coach. So a lot of their personality and things, at least from the running game, remain the same. They are still flying around and playing defense with a great deal of intensity. When I look at this group, I see a group that's very similar philosophically to what they've been in the past. They've been doing a nice job, and I tip my hat to coach Munchak for getting his unit off to a great start, particularly over the past three weeks. (Q: Why are the Titans struggling to run the football?) A: It's not an instant thing, particularly with some of the things that occurred during the offseason. They had to assimilate new people to new positions, new coaches to the coaching staff. They were a new staff. It is a process. I am sure they are going to remain dedicated and diligent in terms of how they work and improve. (Q: Re: The team's attitude:) A: I think they are hacked off and they should be. We haven't performed close enough to what we expect. We've lost games because of it, specifically we lost last week. We look forward to preparing and playing this week in front of our home fans, and hopefully righting this thing.  (Q: Will you put Bryant McFadden in if he is healthy or will you continue to rotate?) A: I like what's going on with some of the men. We will let his level of participation over the course of the week dictate how we get him back into the mix. (Q: Re: Chop blocking:) A: I can't speak to league trends. There doesn't appear to be more chop blocking, at least in recent years. I know that we are probably not seeing any more chop blocks than we've seen in recent years. We've played better than we are playing it right now, and we need to continue to get back to that. (Q: Did you ever figure out what Mike Wallace said when he got penalized?) A: No I did not. It really doesn't matter. Like I said after the game, regardless of what was said or how it was said, it was deemed a penalty. We can't have pre-snap and post-play penalties. That's us beating us. We had 45 yards or so of those types of penalties offensively, counting the penalty by Maurkice Pouncey. We had three false starts offensively. That's not conducive to winning football. We met on that and acknowledged that yesterday. Hopefully that won't continue. (Q: What does that say about James Harrison, playing with that type of injury?) A: That's nothing that probably hasn't been said about James Harrison. He's James Harrison. (Q: Does a hamstring injury have to be fully recovered for a running back to play?) A: No. I am not going to say that. It has to be above the line. We will lean on our medical experts in terms of guiding us in that area with Rashard. (Q: Does working on fundamentals affect your defense making splash plays?) A: No. We can strike a good balance in terms of that. It's not like all of a sudden we are drawing up new defenses or new blitzes this week. Many of the blitzes we employ during a course of a football game have been there since the very beginning of this thing. We are not concerned about striking a balance in that regard. That's not an issue. (Q: Re: LaMarr Woodley:) A: He's played about two-and-two, probably about how I've coached and the rest of us have played. He's had his moments. He's done some good things but not enough for us to be as successful as we'd like or for him to be as successful as he would like. (Q: Re: Similarities between Chris Johnson and Arian Foster:) A: They are different runners. Very little in the NFL is comparable to Johnson from a speed standpoint. Foster is a unique runner, in terms of contact, balance, strength, cutting ability and vision. They are both different and both special. (Q: Does playing on the road three of the first four weeks play into anything?) A: No. (Q: Re: Punt returners catching the ball inside the 10-yard line:) A: I think the days of having hard and fast judgments along those lines are done. Punters are simply too good. They have pinpoint accuracy. The evolution of this rugby punt, with bounce control after the ball hits the ground; I think it's changing that. The reality is that if you think the ball has a chance of getting to the endzone you let it go. If you don't, you play the football.

Good afternoon. I guess I will start with the injury report since we have a significant number of people to talk about. Chris Carter played in the game. It was his first game. He experienced some soreness. We will evaluate his hamstring. He should be able to practice this week and participate. Marcus Gilbert looks like he is going to be ok from his left shoulder injury. We anticipate him practicing and playing. Arnaz Battle has some swelling in his right knee. His participation this week will be determined by his ability to practice. We will see where Brett Keisel is this week. You can say the same thing for him, coming back from his PCL sprain. He is working hard. We will see if he is able to practice. If he is, we will gauge whether or not we will allow him to participate. Doug Legursky can be characterized as questionable with his left shoulder injury. The same can be said for Jonathan Scott with his left ankle sprain. Again their availability will be determined by their ability to practice this week. In regards to some of the offensive line things, we may be open to bring someone in. We haven't made any definitive plans in that regard yet. We will let the participation of these men dictate what we do in that area. I am swapping our padded practices up this week. We are just going with helmets only on Wednesday. We will carry our shoulder pads on Thursday. We believe that approach will help us deal with some of these injuries, and be inclusive in terms of practice and give some guys an opportunity to practice Wednesday, and give them another day, 24 hours or so to participate on Thursday. Some other minor things, Jerricho Cotchery is moving closer. We anticipate him being a candidate to play this week. That's the same for Bryant McFadden. Mike Wallace suffered a rib cartilage injury in the game. We will see what his availability is at the early parts of the week in terms of practice but it shouldn't prohibit him from playing. In regards to our performance, it was great going into a hostile environment and win a game. We were not perfect by any stretch. We are still very much a team in development. It was very encouraging to see necessary plays in all three phases in a close football game in a hostile environment to make the necessary plays to win. I saw it offensively with the last drive, 2:09, and having to go down and kick a field goal. I saw a timely turnover defensively delivered by James Harrison, and of course capitalized by Troy Polamalu. I saw some exciting things in the special teams' game, particularly in our punt return game. They were all encouraging signs. We are still developing as a team. I think that anybody who is not saying that this time of the year is probably mistaken. The important thing is that we do enough to win games as we go through this process, and we were able to do that. It doesn't necessarily mean the quality of our performance last week is going to produce anything this week. We acknowledge we are playing a very tough opponent. The Houston Texans are a 2-1 football team. They are coming off a stinging loss to the New Orleans Saints. They are a quality outfit. They have quality players in all three phases. Offensively I think the first thing you notice is that they have great continuity. Coach Gary Kubiak has been there six years. They pretty much have maintained the same offensive scheme over that time. Matt Schaub has settled in nicely at quarterback. His skill set lends itself to how they play football with the zone-scheme running and misdirection passing. His number one target is arguably the best receiver in the world in Andre Johnson. I have a great deal of respect for him. When you talk about defending him, you talk about containing him, not stopping him. If they are committed, and I know that they will be, they will get the ball in his hands, using a myriad of formations, shifts and motions. Their tight ends are excellent. Owen Daniels is very good and has been for a number of years. They have a new multi-faceted player in James Casey. He's a man out of Rice, who is a unique guy. He did a lot of unique things at Rice, wildcat quarterback and things of that nature. We looked at him in the draft. They ask him to do a lot of things. He's a tight end-like guy and a fullback-like guy. He's a very good football player. He catches the ball extremely well. He's a very good blocker, be it lead blocking or on some of the backside things associated with that zone-scheme running. He cuts off the defenders. He's very good. They have a rock solid group up front. I think their left tackle, Duane Brown, a third or fourth-year guy out of Virginia Tech, is playing top-flight football. He looks like a Pro Bowl-caliber player. Defensively if you look at them, I think the first thing you acknowledge is the acquisition of Wade Phillips and what he brings, his track record. He's a proven defensive football coach. I think he has those guys believing. They are playing with a great deal of energy and are very physical. Up front they are led by Mario Williams. Whether you call him an end or an outside linebacker, it doesn't matter. You better keep him out of your backfield. He's a dangerous man. He has two sacks for them on the year. He's been to multiple Pro Bowls. Their first-round pick, J.J. Watt from Wisconsin, is an awesome addition. He appears to be playing extremely well. He's very aware. He utilizes his hands and his length very well. He was one of those 3-4 end guys that we evaluated. We held him in high regard. Their outside linebacker play is exceptional with Brian Cushing and DeMeco Ryans. DeMeco appears to be back from his injury, and Brian Cushing is a sideline-to-sideline, chase-and-tackle football player. The significant thing about what is going on in their secondary starts with their acquisition of two quality, proven veteran players. Johnathan Joseph came over from the Cincinnati Bengals. He is very familiar with us. And Danieal Manning is playing free safety for them. He also brings the added dimension that he is a very highly respected kick returner. He will return kickoffs for them. They have a quality punt returner in Jacoby Jones. Their special teams coordinator, Joe Marciano, I know personally, and he's a very good coach. He's been down there a really long time. I think he's the only special teams coach their organization has ever had. I think that speaks to what he is capable of and how solid that unit and element of their team is. We are going down to Houston, Texas, in search of another AFC road victory. We don't underestimate that. It is our third opportunity in terms of going on the road this month and trying to seek victory. We need to improve in doing that. Houston is going to be an awesome challenge, and we are excited about it. We are excited about preparing ourselves. We are excited about working with our men in terms of moving toward it.(Q: Will Marcus Gilbert move to left tackle?) A: No, Marcus Gilbert will be at right tackle.  We are comfortable with what he is doing and with Trai Essex lining up on the left side, and what he is capable of doing on the left side of our offensive line. We have played a lot of football with Trai in the past, and he has generally been above the line and that is what we anticipate him playing. (Q: Is Jonathan Scott the guy if he is ready to go?) A: If he is deemed healthy he will play left tackle, yes. (Q: Re: Scott struggling against Dwight Freeney:) A: I think I was pretty clear about what Dwight Freeney is capable of even prior to the game. That is no secret. He is a quality player. (Q: Re: Running game:) A: When I talk about us being a team in development that is one of the things that I point to; we are still very much a team in development in that area. I try not to frame it at this early juncture, but when you look at it we got behind in Baltimore so we didn't have a productive day there. I thought we did have a functional day running the football versus Seattle. Although the sledding did get a little tough at the end of the game when they knew we weren't going to throw it. Then we didn't do well the other night. So I am not ready to start talking about trends in that area. I don't know that we have a big enough body of work at this juncture. I'll acknowledge that we didn't do well the other night. And that we better improve in that area and improve in a hurry beaus ewe desire to be balanced offensively and be a good offense and be able to win games in a lot of ways and be able to win in that area. One things that I didn't mention about Sunday's performance was that even though we struggled in terms of running the football, our ability to convert third downs, I think helped us in that area in terms of moving the football and not allowing it to be a detriment of what we were trying to do offensively in terms of possessing the football and in terms of scoring. (Q: Re: Three lineman getting injured make you reevaluate how many you dress?) A: For that particular instance it does when you are down that road in that juncture/ I take a cerebral approach in terms of participation week-to-week. The health of the men that are scheduled to play, being an element of it, our areas of need in terms of our team in compared to the other team weighs into that decision. That is a week-to-week decision and I try not to let things that have occurred in the past guide me in terms of that because if you do this job long enough there are things that will scare you and you will try to suit 53 and of course that is not allowed. (Q: Outdoors or indoors this week and does that have any affect?) A: It has no bearing on us. If we are good and that is something that we desire to be, things like game location and climate need to be irrelevant. Good teams are great at making those things irrelevant and that is what we strive to do. That is out of our control and we really don't care. (Q: Are they required to let you know?) A: I don't know what the parameters are because it is not important to me. I will assume we will play on a 100-yard field. That's what is important. (Q: Re: Bringing someone in depends on Scott:) A: It will depend on not only him but Doug Legursky and Marcus Gilbert. We are encouraged with Marcus, we will see on the others. (Q: Do you have anyone in mind?) A: Not at this juncture. No. (Q: If you brought someone what would it be for?) A: Just be for practice purposes only. We don't anticipate bringing someone in who can help us win this football game. (Q: Will he be just practice squad?) A: Practice, practice bodies. Be it practice squad or active roster. (Q: Will you add a lineman or replace a lineman?) A: Those are discussions because I am talking hypothetically as we sit here. I a think the first thing to do is just check the availability of the men we have mentioned and then let that lead us as we proceed. But make no mistake. We intend to prepare with the men that we have here. Those will be the guys that will help us win this football game. Anyone we add will be simply for the purposes of practice or numbers. (Q: Re: Wade Phillips personality for their defense:) A: I think that would be the case for this past Sunday. I think particularly when you are talking about personalities in September it is tough.  I think they are finishing themselves as are we. They have a new coordinator and I think when you are at an early juncture with a new coordinator it is too early to start framing what a personality is and what you need to do to be successful against them. (Q: Is their 3-4 like Baltimore's?) A: I think a good assessment or comparison would be the Cowboys. Of course Wade came from Dallas. But that is the first thing that jumps out at me. They have the quote-un-quote undersized athletic nose in (Shaun) Cody, very similar to the man they have in Dallas. I think about the Cowboys when I look at how they implement their 3-4. (Q: Where does (James) Casey get most of his yards?) A: He gets them on misdirection passing, whether he is a flat-receiver or if he is the man running the over-route. They move him around quite a bit. He is a quality player. He does a lot of things well. The yards are just art of his story.  I have been really impressed with his lead blocking as a full back or full back light guy.  I have been very impressed with his backside blocking in some of their zone scheme runs. We are talking about a guy who is new to the position if you will that did a variety of things at Rice and I even think he is a professional baseball player. He is just really a big unique skilled athlete. (Q: Re: Hybrid tight ends:) A: I don't think that is a new trend. I think the flexibility that tight ends provide you offensively in terms of being able to add a gap in the offensive line or put a guy in the back field and have two back runs or displace a guy and have a big wide receiver type guy.  I think versatile tight end and tight end like bodies that 240 to 250 pound body is a unique guy and I think you see a lot of guys utilizing them in a lot of ways. They can be big receiver-like, fullback-like and tight end-like. (Q: Re: Troy (Polamalu) being more active on the line:) A: I don't know if it was anything done in reaction to the Baltimore game. It is just us developing our personality as a defensive unit at the season wears on. Obviously Troy is a big component of that and putting him isn't position to doing that and doing it well. Which of course is move around, pressure, show up in the run game, blitz and cover. Troy is a multi-faceted guy so we have to be open-minded in terms of how we utilize him and we will be. (Q: Re: Troy played more in back-field past few seasons:) A: I hadn't looked at it from a '08 or '09 perspective. I am just talking about it here as the development of our team in 2011 and the ways that we can utilize him to help us win. I think it is early in the season. We are getting some good play from a number of guys. Of course Troy being one of them and Ike being another. But it is very early in the season and of course we are going to be tested this week with Schaub, Johnson and company. (Q: How important is it to get to Schaub?) A: I think it is importance to get to him but I think in order to get to him the first thing you need to do is be sound against the running game.  If you are sound against the running game I think that will help in terms of misdirected past and solidify a launch point, if you will. As long as they are running the football, they are going to attack you with the misdirection pass and the launch point is going to change.  It is going to be tough to find rhythm in terms of getting to him.  No question we would like to do that.  We would like to get to any quarterback we play.  But specifically this week is starts with utilizing their running game.  Of course they have a great stable of backs.  Whether it is Foster, Slaton, Ward, Tate, it doesn't matter.  Foster of course has gotten a lot of recognition in recent years and rightfully so. He is a quality back but when I look at their tape it doesn't appear to matter who it tote that thing. They have a stable of quality backs and they run it extremely well. (Q: Does it make it harder to prepare when a team has so many capable running backs?) A: No it's always difficult to prepare. Whoever is back there really is irrelevant. I was just acknowledging that they have quality people, regardless of who they choose to use or who is available. Whether Foster is available or not or whether they choose to use others, Foster, Tate, Ward and Slaton all have been very good. (Q: How did your run defense do against the Colts?) A: It was good at times. It wasn't consistent enough for my comfort. We didn't stone them out. Joseph Addai and their group had something to do with that. You have to tip your hat to those guys. I never want to not do that, acknowledge quality play from the people that we respect and compete against. We can be better. Like some of the other things we talked about here today, we are still very much a team in development in that area. That's not unusual this time of year, in terms of being solid and being able to stay in your gaps as you rolodex defenses and myriads of formations and offensive plays. We have to continue to grow. (Q: Re: Every year Houston seems to have a new guy that steps up:) A: I think it's all of those things [coaching and schemes]. Coach Kubiak and others there have a great deal of experience in the schemes that they run. Quite frankly they probably know exactly what they are looking for when they go about acquiring talent to play in that scheme. They know what they are looking for in terms of runners. That past experience probably helps them in acquiring men like Foster, Tate, Ward and Slaton. (Q: Re: Not having any timeouts Sunday night on the final drive:) A: I didn't realize that until after. I lost that timeout when Jonathan Scott went down in that sequence of events. I have to get better too. I am a guy in development from a game management standpoint. I don't run away from that. (Q: Re: Emmanuel Sanders not touching the defensive back on the interception return:) A: Really there was no need to talk to him. He understood where he was wrong. Sometimes coaching the obvious is silly. That's a mistake that was made and acknowledged immediately. It's probably more important that we moved on to things that were less obvious.  (Q: Re: James Harrison feeling better:) A: He is a sandbagger. We expect him to be James when he steps into the stadiums. (Q: Re: Turnovers:) A: This is why they concern me: we are not doing a good enough job of protecting the ball, and we are not doing a good enough job of getting it. Those two things together make you extremely uncomfortable. We are a blessed group to be sitting here 2-1 after being minus-nine after three games. We have to be near the bottom of the NFL, if not the worst. We got to get better in that area, and preserve and protect the football, and getting it. Thankfully when it mattered on Sunday, at significant moments we were able to maintain the ball offensively and get the ball defensively. That's why we were able to get out of that stadium with the necessary win. (Q: Re: Teams relying on the big defensive play:) A: I would agree with that but I don't know if it applies to us. I don't think we take that approach to our business. I think that every time the ball is snapped, it's an opportunity for a big play to occur, whether it's offensively, defensively or on special teams. I think our guys have that mentality. I don't think anyone waits for plays to happen. I think every man on the field in a helmet is capable of delivering those plays. I hope they share that same sentiment. I think that they do. So I don't know if that applies to us. But in terms of that concept I agree with it.  (Q: Re: Defensive line:) A: I think it starts with protecting themselves. They have to stand on their feet and move with gaps as they move laterally. I think we can get better in that area. (Q: Re: Play clock winding down on almost every play:) A: It's a product of a myriad of things. Sometimes we have multiple-play options at the line of scrimmage. Sometimes we change personnel. Sometimes we slow the pace down and wait for looks to reveal themselves. Indianapolis was very good at maintain a two shell, because they play a lot of cover-two until late in the pre-snap, and then they spin safeties down. There is a myriad of reasons of why you let a play clock run down, depending on what particular instance you are talking about. It could be any of those. (Q: Did that help their pass rush?) A: I am sure it did. The silent count helps their pass rush. Their pass rush helps their pass rush. Having Dwight Freeney and Robert Mathis helps your pass rush.

Good afternoon. I will start by saying that it's great to get our first win under our belt, especially at Heinz Field in front of Steelers Nation. We put together a winning performance in all three phases. With that now in our rearview mirror, we turn our attention to this week's challenges, which of course is a trip to Indianapolis to play the Colts. We don't want to underscore the importance of that. We have an opportunity to go on the road and face an AFC opponent, our second opportunity to do that. We all know how the first one turned out. With that being said I will give you an update in terms of injuries. Brett Keisel does have a grade-one PCL sprain. That will make his participation questionable this week. We will see where the week takes us. But he's probably questionable at best. Bryant McFadden continues to work his hamstring along with Jerricho Cotchery. We will see how available they will be in terms of participation this week. We will let that guide us in terms of whether or not they will be available for the game. I believe Chris Carter's hamstring injury is in his rearview mirror now. He really perked up toward the end of last week. We expect to get a full week's participation from him. Really, it's a big week for a guy like Chris Carter and Jason Worilds. They are going to be simulating Robert Mathis and Dwight Freeney on our scout team defense. The rest of the injuries are the minor bumps and bruises that are associated with playing. They shouldn't inhibit us in any way with our preparation or play this weekend. The Colts have had their share of adversity this year, not only with Peyton Manning but some quality defensive players have missed some time as well. Linebackers Gary Brackett and Ernie Sims, who is an acquisition of theirs is a top-quality football player. As you watch the tape, it's obvious, although it hasn't shown in their record to this point, they are getting comfortable in playing with some of the changes that they've had. They are really executing nicely in some areas. If you start to look at them offensively, when you look at their game against Cleveland, they didn't have a problem moving the football. They kicked field goals when drives stalled. I think that's a function of working with a new quarterback. Of course he's not an inexperienced one, talking about Kerry Collins. He is simply new to that situation. Things such as situational football are going to be difficult under those circumstances. But veteran players like Kerry Collins have a quick learning curve. We imagine he will be better and they will be better than what we are looking at on tape. We better be prepared and I am sure that we will. Third down is another area they have kind of fallen below the line and one of the reasons why they are 0-and-2. They have quality players. Joseph Addai is their featured runner. He has nice vision, a zone-scheme runner. He also includes himself very nicely in the passing game. I think he has six catches in two games thus far. He is backed up by Delone Carter, a rookie who has shown some nice running skills. He is up over 4.0 per carry. He is supplementing Addai. If you look at their receiving corps, those guys have been together for a number of years. They are led by Reggie Wayne, who is a perennial Pro Bowl-type talented player. Pierre Garcon is their deep threat on their offensive right side, defenses' left side. He is a vertical threat guy. He stretches the field vertically for them and has done a nice job. He has taken over Reggie Wayne's former role as Reggie settled in the role that Marvin Harrison used to do for those guys. They supplement those two with some interior slot-like guys. Austin Collie has played quite a bit for them. You have to include Dallas Clark in that slot receiving discussion. He removes himself from the corps quite a bit. They've designed some things for him. He is very dangerous. They throw him screens. He's a very heady player. He understands zone coverage. He understands man coverage. I would imagine Kerry Collins is working very hard to build a rapport with that man because he is a chain mover and he can ring the scoreboard up. He scored their lone touchdown last week. Up front they are anchored by Jeff Saturday. Anthony Costanzo, their left tackle, is a highly thought of rookie from Boston College. We have a great deal of respect for him. When you look at what they do defensively, I think it starts with putting pressure on the passer. They trample the runner on the way to the pass like a lot of four-down teams. We are very familiar with their approach to football, schematically their game is predicated on speed. Guys like Mathis and Freeney, that is a great place to start. Those guys have been to a bunch of Pro Bowls and have disrupted a lot of football games. For them they continue to do it. Those guys have their sacks this year. But they are supplemented by some other guys. They picked up Jamaal Anderson from the Falcons, the former Arkansas Razorback, who is a first-round guy. He is doing some real nice things, some dangerous things for them. They play a bunch of people up front like a lot of 4-3 teams do. When you look at their linebacker corps, I mentioned earlier that Brackett and Sims have missed some time. Pat Angerer has done a nice job filling in and playing a little bit for those guys. I really like their safety crew. Antoine Bethea and Melvin Bullitt have been back there for quite some time. A few years ago it was always Bullitt in relief of Bob Sanders, who of course missed quite a bit of time with injuries. He performed well enough where I thought they were comfortable enough to let him play. He has proven that line of thinking was correct. He had an interception in the opener. They work well together. They send both guys down. Both guys are capable of playing half the field and covering a lot of range. They have a talented young cornerback group led by Jerraud Powers. Pat McAfee is a top, solid specialist. He is right around 50 or 49 yards on average in the punting game. We are going to roll our sleeves up and get back to work. We have to go on the road and win in a hostile environment. We haven't done that yet. We have an opportunity to go seek an AFC road victory. We haven't done that yet. We need to sharpen our sword for it. (Q: Re: defense saying they played angry this game:) A: I thought they had played better and that is what I am interested in. (Q: Re: Some said they played with more of an individual effort rather than team effort against Baltimore:) A: I think sometimes those explanations are in an effort to answer questions. I believe it is very black and white. I believe you step into stadiums and you play or you don't.  Or you make plays or you don't. We aren't in the business of excuse making. That tape is in our file as is last week's. I am not going to try to explain it away. And I prefer that they didn't.  Most of the time when you have comments like that from them it is them just trying to be courteous and answer the questions. (Q: Re: Chris Kemoeatu:) A: We will see where practice takes us, and you are right I did fail to mention his name.  His availability will be predicated on his level of performance here this week in practice. (Q: How extensive is the playbook under Peyton Manning?) A: Of course they are a multiple group.  And they are a multiple group for a lot of reasons.  Not only do they have Peyton Manning but they have great continuity in some core players offensively.  I mentioned Jeff Saturday and Reggie Wayne, Joseph Addai, but they also have great continuity in their coaching staff. Clyde Christensen, their offensive coordinator, has been there ten years, Ricky Thomas the tight ends coach, ten years.  Of course, Jim Caldwell has been there ten years in different capacities but he has been there for ten years. I think when you have that great of continuity in players and coaches you have an opportunity to grow and develop and become very complex.  Obviously, when you have a change at quarterback I am sure you lose a little bit of that but I am sure that is one of the reasons they were interested in Kerry Collins because he is a veteran football player, I am sure a quick study and I am sure that he will adjust and learn the nuances of some of the things that they have evolved to very quickly.  That is why I am more concerned about him and them and what they are capable of than I am in terms of what I have seen on tape. Because I imagine under those circumstances he's capable of improving quickly, as are they. (Q: Re: Communication problems with noise:) A: If we perform better initially that will help us with crowd control.  That is the focus of mine. (Q: Re: Performances of Ramon Foster and Marcus Gilbert:) A: I thought Ramon did some nice things. I like his effort, his finish, and his play demeanor. I think it is what we desire. Marcus Gilbert did some nice things as well. I talked after the game, I thought we moved the ball. I thought we won the line of scrimmage in the first half, not so much in the second.  Maybe that is a function of conditioning. We've had some guys who's roles have been back ups in the past playing in the line of scrimmage for us.  Maybe the snap count became a factor.  I have to address that with them.  The reality is that we have to be able to play 60 minutes of football in the manner of which we desire. I didn't think we ran the ball as effectively as you would like to in the second half. Our run game efficiency wasn't acceptable and we will just simply work. No question when you talk about Ramon Foster or Marcus Gilbert, their performances were above the line. (Q: Re: Goal line missed opportunity on first drive:) A: It's execution.  They performed better under those circumstances than we did.  (Q: Did you get more run blitz in second half?) A: Yeah, but I am not going to let that affect our mentality in terms of what we expect.  I don't care what our opponents do to be quite honest with you.  They need to be nameless, gray faces to us. We have a job to do.  We have a level of expectation in terms of how we perform and we fell below that in the second half of the game. (Q: Does stopping the run on the way to the quarterback make you more vulnerable to the run game?) A: Potentially. I mentioned their continuity offensively, I think you can say the same thing defensively. They have a lot of savvy veteran football players in that front.  Starting first and foremost with Mathis and Freeney.  I am sure that they have knocked out the kinks of those things along the way.  I have been on teams that have taken that philosophy in the past and we have found ways with veteran players and continuity to overcome that and minimize that.  I think that they have as well. (Q: Were short yardage issues due to shuffling lineman?) A: I am sure that was a factor.  I am not going to say that it was a significant factor.  I always think that the most significant factor is our preparation and ultimately our play.  We felt comfortable with our preparation. Obviously, we need to perform a little better or maybe put together a better or more comprehensive plan in that area.  We will see what this week has in store for us. (Q: Re: Importance of Peyton Manning:) A: I am not going to try to minimize the importance of Peyton Manning for the Indianapolis Colts.  I'd imagine that it is a major adjustment that they are going through. But I also think they've got great continuity and great quality players at other positions and he is a part of the bigger picture in terms of what they have done there for a number of years.  No question he is central to it.  But they have done some unique things in terms of utilizing people in the way they place people.  Reggie is always on the offenses left and Pierre is always on the offenses right.  Dallas Clark does some unique things. They do a nice job of utilizing the skill sets of all of their players, particularly the ones that they identify as core players, like the ones that I just mentioned. (Q: Why do you keep a guy on the same side all of the time?) A: I don't know. I'd be interested in that.  Ask them. Maybe I will join them if it is a good enough explanation.  That is just how they handled business.  Maybe it just started initially with the great rapport that Peyton had years ago with Marvin Harrison and just simply wanting him available to him on his right at all times.  I don't know that.  But I recognize it as being unique and something that is unique to them. (Q: Will Ziggy Hood go if Keisel can't?) A: Yeah, and not only Ziggy but we have a great deal of confidence in all of our guys that are position flexible. Chris Hoke is position flexible, Steve McClendon is position flexible and of course the young guy Cameron Heyward has not disappointed us with his performance thus far. (Q: Re: Ike Taylor:) A: He is playing at a high level.  He really is and he is doing a nice job of playing through personal adversity that he is going through in terms of his injury.  He hadn't missed a lot of time.  He has found ways to continue to work and improve in spite of it.  Really, he is a blue print for young guys in terms of what it is about to be a veteran player and to prepare and to deal with things that occur in professional football and not allow them to become excuses.  He is prepared.  He has performed to this point and we are pleased with what he is doing. (Q: Re: Keenan Lewis:) A: He did a solid job.  He really did. Not only in terms of playing extensively but when you look at the circumstances that a person in his position comes onto the field in, it's always in third downs and critical situations and things in that nature.  I thought he did a nice job.  He was competitive.  He played a lot of routes close. He finished plays.  It was a nice start for him. (Q: Is McFadden a concern in regards to health recovery?) A: I wouldn't necessarily identify it as a concern.  It is simply an issue.  When you have a lower body injury and you play corner you are not going to have an opportunity to work through it as opposed to a thumb injury. (Q: How much better can Mike Wallace get?) A: He's a one-trick guy. He's working though. I like Mike. (Q: How do you choose who Ike Taylor covers?) A: It's a lot of things. It's not only the pedigree of the people he covers or how the offenses utilize them. We make that determination on a weekly basis. We haven't done that this week. (Q: Re: Mike Wallace still getting open despite teams knowing his speed:) A: I broke into this league with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. We were in the division with the Minnesota Vikings. We all knew that Randy Moss was fast and it didn't change the highlight reels week-in-and-week-out. When a guy has a distinguished skill set you have to deal with it, even though you know it is coming. That's the awesome challenges of coaching and playing in the NFL.  (Q: How has Wallace's game evolved?) A: He is working. (Q: Re: Taking the crowd out of the game:) A: I don't know that it does anything for a defense initially. At the early outset of games, regardless of how the other side of the ball is playing, I think it's a feeling out process that takes place, particularly early in the year. I think that mentality and demeanor reveals itself as games unfold, particularly in the latter parts of the halves and particularly in the second half. (Q: Re: Pass protection for Kerry Collins:) A: They have done a nice job. Of course they do some nice things with the play action to help in that area. But no question they would probably characterize themselves as an evolving group and rightfully so. (Q: Re: Collins being different than Manning:) A: I hadn't thought about comparing or contrasting them. More than anything I've looked at Collins and what he's done since he's been there. I also went back and looked at our action against him in Week Two a year ago when he came on in relief for Vince Young when we played at Tennessee. He moved the ball pretty easily against us under those circumstances. Some turnovers kept them from ringing up the scoreboard but I do make a note that he was capable of reading coverage and distributing the ball rather freely in those circumstances against us 12 months ago. They actually scored and recovered an onside kick and were driving again as time expired. That experience is not lost as we prepare for this one. (Q: What kind of wine were you drinking after this victory?) A: We are not thirsty right now. We are still squashing grapes. (Q: Re: Scoring plays being challenged:) A: It's kind of been a non-factor for us. I think we experienced it once in Carolina in the preseason. But it hasn't been a factor for us thus far. (Q: Do you want to see the rules changed for that?) A: I don't have any problem with the rule as it is written. I think scoring plays are significant. We need to get them right. I think that's why the rule was installed. I am in agreement with it. (Q: Did any of the sting go away from the Baltimore loss?) A: No. and it shouldn't. It really shouldn't. Each playing opportunity stands on its own. It is what it is. We accept it and take responsibility for it, for our first performance just like we do our second and ultimately all of them. It's important. I think that's what is so special about this game and this league. You only get so many opportunities to state a case. Each and every one of them are very important and they don't go anywhere.

Good afternoon. Some 48 hours or so after our last contest, and really I have no explanation for the way we performed. Really there is none. The reality is that tape is our tape and we have to own it. It's not something we enjoy or like but such is life in the NFL. We will evaluate the tape and look at our performances and how we fell short in many ways and areas. We will start the process of preparing for Seattle. From an injury front, I just received some information regarding Willie Colon. He had surgery this morning. It was a torn triceps. He is going to be out for an extended period of time to say the least, probably a candidate for the Reserve/Injured List, but we haven't made that determination yet. We will let him come out of recovery before we proceed. Marcus Gilbert will be given an opportunity at right tackle to play. We like where he is. He has performed well for us. He's a talented young guy. He doesn't have a great deal of experience but we are going to give him an opportunity to play and show what he's capable of. All the other injuries are the minor in-game injuries that come along with playing. Needless to say it's a personal blow for Willie Colon. We are saddened for him. For us we acknowledge that it's a natural part of the game of football. Things like that along this journey happen. And as a football team we will do what a football team does, which is the next man will move on and we will expect him to play to the same standard. For Willie, going down two consecutive seasons is a tough blow. We will keep him close and encourage him, and help him through what is going to be a tough time with rehab. More than anything, Willie is a guy that loves to play the game of football. We won't be given the opportunity to do that. Moving forward towards this week's challenge, we have the Seattle Seahawks. We've been watching tape over the last couple of days, familiarizing ourselves with them. They are a very talented group. I know some of these guys personally. I'll start with Tarvaris Jackson, who I was with in Minnesota. He is a legit, tough guy at the quarterback position. I believe his teammates and that organization recognizes that. That's probably one of the reasons he was voted captain. He's a quality dude, a competitor. That's my personal experience with him. He appears to be continually growing and developing as a football player. He has some nice tape out there this year. They have Sidney Rice. I know he missed the last game, but he's a talented acquisition for them. They have Zach Miller at tight end. This is a guy they picked up from the Oakland Raiders. He's an Arizona State man who is off to a great career. Mike Williams is a nice reclamation project of Pete Carroll's. They have a shared background. This guy is back in action playing well for them as he did last year. They have a very talented front, young but talented. Russell Okung is a first-rounder. They have John Moffitt, a young guy from Wisconsin. They have a young, talented guy from Alabama in James Carpenter. What they lack in experience they make up in pedigree. These are some talented young people. They have Max Unger at center. He's a really high quality player, a guy that we looked at when he came out in the draft. Defensively, they run to the ball. They play with a great deal of energy. They have some nice acquisitions on that side of the ball as well. Alan Branch was picked up from Arizona. He's really playing well, really rushing the passer well. He's really working the edges and working the guards really well. At linebacker they have Aaron Curry, a talented young guy. He was a top-five pick out of Wake Forest. On the back end I've really been impressed by their young safety tandem. Earl Thomas from Texas is a talented young guy. Back there with him is Kam Chancellor, a young man from Virginia Tech. those two guys show a lot of range and get to a lot of plays and strike a lot of people. But more than anything, when you look at coming off a performance like we are coming off of, it's more about how we prepare and ultimately play. We have a great deal of respect for that team. They are a good team. They are coming off a loss as well. Hopefully you will see two hungry teams battling it out at Heinz Field, and we are happy to be there. (Q: Should your team be angry about the last game?) A: We should be angry about that performance. But anger is less of an issue. It's more about what we do moving forward and how we prepare and play. If we channel that anger properly then it can be a good thing. If we don't it can be an increasingly frustrating thing. We are aware of that. We acknowledge that. More than anything we are focusing on the things we can control that are pertinent to winning and playing well. That at this juncture is planning and preparation. (Q: Are you going to bring in any tackles to replace Colon?) A: We are going to work out a couple of guys today for potential depth and see if they are capable of us, the normal process that you go through when you experience what we are experiencing with Willie. It will play itself out over the next 24 hours or so. (Q: What has Gilbert shown you?) A: We like his pedigree. He is a talented guy. He has showed the ability to play a variety of positions at Florida. He played both tackle positions and actually some guard at Florida. He has shown that he is not a fish out of water in those areas since he's been here in terms of being position flexible. There's not a lot of tape because there hasn't been a lot of opportunities for the young guy. But we do believe he is talented. He has done a nice job with the opportunities he has been given up to this point. It's enough for us to feel comfortable moving forward. We are giving him an opportunity here this weekend. (Q: Does your team need motivation or to be humbled?) A: Hopefully we are humble. Hopefully that didn't happen on Sunday in the stadium. This is a humbling game, particularly at this level. That's just an example of the many ways you can be humbled. I think that's more of a catch phrase than anything else. I think the people that know and competed in this league understand that there is a fine line between drinking wine and squashing grapes. Obviously last weekend we were grape squashers.
