I didn't think they were gutting us by any stretch.  I think their longest was 11 yards from the line of scrimmage.  But they exhibited the patience that others hadn't under similar conditions so they were able to find some rhythm and get a play or two.  Didn't think it was a bad game in terms of us stopping the run but I didn't think it was our best effort and of course you have to tip your hats to those guys.  They had an element to do with that and probably first and foremost their willingness to continue to run the football.  Which is what we expect Carolina to do, given those two quality players that have at running back and the fact that they have a young quarterback.  We expect Carolina to exhibit similar patience this week so we better be prepared to turn them back even if it is plus 45 times. (Re: Why you had success running the football:) Because we can run the football, Ed. (But you did not have as much success in previous weeks, why is that?) We ran for 120 (yards) or so the previous week.  It wasn't out of line I don't think with our season average and what we have done. (I think you ran it 37 times and this week I think you only ran it 25.  You averaged five per carry.) We were behind in this game.  We finished our last possession of the first half in the two-minute drill.  Of course the later part of the game we were virtually throwing it every down.  Sometimes numbers get skewed due to game circumstances.  We are committed to running it and running it well (Had the Jets shown that bootleg?) Are you talking about the fourth-and-one that they scored the touchdown?  They have shown that.  When you are playing Coach Ryan you know the kind of guy she is.  You want to make him pull that ball and run that naked.  So I was pleased that they ran the play. I think it kind of shows the level of respect that Coach Ryan has for our short yardage defense.  You want to stop them.  We weren't able to do that.  But it is a small victory when you are playing the New York Jets and they don't hand that ball to LaDainian Tomlinson or (Shonn) Greene in that situation for circumstance. (Will you speak to how crucial it is to get the bye?) I won't.  I won't speak to it.  I will only speak to preparing for Carolina. (Is Troy's situation at all comparable with Aaron (Smith)?) No.  Troy is experiencing some discomfort in his lower leg and as soon as the discomfort subsides he is going to be back in action. I think we are moving close to that.  We will see where this week takes us. (Were you satisfied with the pressure on Sanchez?) I would always like more pressure.  You are always going to hear me say that.  I think how they approached the game has something to do with that. No question, I like to start by saying that we missed some sack opportunities in the game.  We had some unblocked guys, we defeated some blocks but we weren't able to get the quarterback on the ground.  But I think the patience that they exhibited in terms of continuing to run the football, the way they mixed the quick game in there made it really tough to find your rhythm in terms of pressuring the quarterback.  We need to get more pressure on the quarterback but they did a nice job in terms of the way they approached the game, in terms of limiting our opportunities. (Re: Ryan Mundy:) I thought he was solid.  I thought he played above the line of football. (Re: Flozell Adams' striking out against (Darrelle) Revis:) I didn't even know who it was against.  It's not on video because it occurred after a play.  I hadn't had an opportunity to have an in depth discussion with him in terms of what transpired. My only comment to the officiating crew is that the confrontation happened in our backfield, in our huddle area and we have a right to our huddle area.  That was my concern regarding the confrontation.  I didn't see the confrontation. I don't know the minute details about how it unfolded but I did see the location and that was of concern to me. (Re: Spot and first down when you only gained nine yards:) Because ball spots in terms of a replay, you are running on a beach in the National Football League.  I think history has proven that. (You would take the first down, right?  Or would you take second and one?) They spotted it as a first down and in that situation it worked in our favor so we moved on.  But I do understand the play you are talking about and I did think he was a yard short. (When did you find out you made the playoffs?) I don't recall.

Good afternoon. It's a big week for us. A quick review of Sunday's performance, it was a satisfying win for us. Any time you have an opportunity to get a division win this time of year they are all significant. It was not easy to come by; I didn't expect it to be. Familiarity always creates that kind of atmosphere, but we did what was necessary really in all three phases to get the job done, highlighted by the great efforts of our defense and some great individual plays, some very good collective play. It really kind of spearheaded the charge for us and provided a wave that all of us were able to follow, and to make necessary plays to win the game. We are pleased with that; we like where we are. From an injury standpoint we're not in too bad of shape. Flozell Adams continues to deal with his ankle sprain. He might be limited here at the early portions of the week. He was able to play in the game, probably not to the level of which he would have liked, but he should be better this week if we continue with that approach. Bryant McFadden continues to deal with a hamstring. He was able to play. He was a little less than 100 percent as can be said with just about everybody that plays football in the NFL this time of year. We may preserve him a little bit at the early portions of the week. Troy is still dealing with his situation. We plan on continuing to follow the same protocol that we have the last several weeks in terms of not letting him practice at the early part of the week and giving him the necessary work as we push closer to game time. Aaron Smith is a week better. He started lifting and stuff and he's going to be in at some point today, and we'll see where today takes us. We're still optimistic about him potentially joining us at some point. He's done a nice job in rehabilitation. We like the progress. We're just going to continue to live day-by-day and take the medical information that we get from the experts and let that be our guide. Some other minor bumps and bruises, Anthony Madison has a knee contusion. He should be fine. Keyaron Fox hyper-extended his left elbow. He didn't miss any action in the game, but it did create a lot of discomfort. He should be fine. Heath Miller worked out this morning. He passed his post-concussion test and has absolutely no symptoms. He is a full go for practice participation tomorrow, which is a good thing. We anticipate having him back in the fold, and all the other ones are normal bumps and bruises that come with playing. This week we are faced with a stiff challenge, an AFC challenge in the New York Jets. They are a 9-4 football team that like us has a desire to remain in the elite. That's what December football is about. Both teams are trying to keep pace with those that are at the top of our conference. They are a team that needs this win desperately. We are a team that needs this win desperately. It should create an interesting matchup. I've got big time respect for those guys, starting with Rex Ryan and his coaching staff. They have unique leadership I think. When you look at some of the names as I am familiarizing myself with this football team, guys that I know, like Tony Richardson, who is a veteran fullback and quality professional, providing quality leadership for them, LaDainian Tomlinson, Jason Taylor, Bart Scott, this team is stacked with quality leadership and that's probably why they are in the position they are in. They are also extremely talented. Let's talk a few minutes about some of the things we have to deal with in playing these guys. Mark Sanchez is their quarterback. He's a high-round draft pick, very talented young man that's got a complete arsenal of weapons to throw to. I'll start with Santonio Holmes, a former Pittsburgh Steeler, who is providing play after play for them like he did for us. This is a guy that embraces those moments whatever those moments are. He's always at his best in the midst of them. He's shown that time and time again when he was here and now he is doing similar things there. He's accompanied by Braylon Edwards, a guy that we are also very familiar with, a former Cleveland Brown. He's a very talented, high-round draft pick at the other wide receiver position. Their wide receiver group is rounded out by some quality guys that can play in Jerricho Cotchery, who is probably one of the tops in the AFC in third-down catches, and of course the multi-talented Brad Smith. Their tight end is a vertical threat, a very athletic guy, a guy that we have to contend with. They drop a lot of passes to LaDainian and Shonn Greene out of the backfield, being screens or check downs. I think LaDainian might be leading them in catches. If he's not then he's pretty close. Sanchez spreads the ball around to a bunch of top quality people; nobody really jumps off the page at you statistically. And I think that's because he has so many options to be quite honest with you. LaDainian is going to get his passes, be it screens or check downs. The same can be said for Shonn Greene, the tight end, Braylon Edwards and Santonio Holmes. They do a really nice job of running the ball, passing the ball, play-pass and screens. They are very balanced under Coach Schottenheimer, who is their offensive coordinator. Defensively they are going to bring pressure from just about every angle you could imagine. I think they are up around 32 or 33 sacks as a football team, but when you look at the distribution of it, it's not heavy in any area. They don't have a guy like James Harrison who has 10 sacks. They spread it out; they are getting contributions from a lot of people. They are good up front. They have Shaun Ellis up front. Their linebacker position group is spectacular. This Calvin Pace guy, number 97, is a top-notch player. He's been probably the most impressive thing that has jumped out on tape to me. I don't have a lot of exposure to him; I have just really been pleased with watching him play, how he plays and the kind of plays he provides for them. Their inside linebacker tandem is a good as any in football. Bart Scott and David Harris, a Michigan man and friend of LaMarr Woodley, they are nine-on-seven linebackers. They are going to turn your backs around. They don't turn it down. They are very combative. They are awesome players. Their cornerback tandem in Darrelle Revis and Antonio Cromartie, not a lot needs to be said about what they are capable of. They can shut down your number one and your number two weapon and they do it repeatedly just about every weekend. So we have a lot to be excited about. We have a lot of work to do. We are excited about doing it. We are glad that we are going to have an opportunity to perform in front of our fans here this week. We are going to need their support because we got a charged-up opponent coming our way. Such is life in the NFL. That's what you wish for this time of year. It's good to be in significant games. That means that you have done what you needed to do to this point.  (What is your opinion of Troy's lateral at end of game?) We desire to educate our guys in situation football. It wasn't a good situation football maneuver.  It was a two score game, there were two minutes left to go, we had gained possession of the football, we had a red-zone stop. So I think that is pretty self explanatory, that possession of the ball pretty much ensures a victory.  He put the possession of the ball at stake with the lateral.  His reaction pretty much sums up the situation.  It is something also to learn from and that is what you try to do this time of year when things come up such as that lateral, particularly when it doesn't prevent you from winning.  I think it is a great teaching tool moving forward, similar to the muffed punt by Antonio Brown.  We were leading in the football game, the punt falls short, it is rolling around and what we want is possession of the football.  It was too risky of a maneuver under the circumstances.  So I always, as a coach, try to look at situations like that that occur in a football game to use as a teach tool for our team moving forward.  It creates personal discomfort for the men involved, but I think we are all better for it and those types of things happen in every football game.  You hope they don't get you beat, but when they do happen you do have an opportunity to use it as a teach tool moving forward and that is what I always try to do in those circumstances. (Re: Darrelle Revis being frustrated that teams aren't throwing his way:) I assume he is that good because I don't have a lot of video evidence because nobody is throwing the ball in his direction.  He has a right to be frustrated and hopefully he is frustrated on Sunday. (Does that affect your offense at all?) We are such in the early portions of our game planning and things, I can't speak to what his presence is going to do to us at this juncture.  We acknowledge that he is a top quality player and that he's capable of being a big time factor in a football game. (Re: Being inside the 10-yard line and coming away with field goals:) We want to score touchdowns and in the recent past, of course, we haven't done as we would like.  There are a myriad of reasons and usually they are centered around the execution and detail of. We are going to work toward getting better this week. (Re: 17 holding penalties in last four games:) We've been holding and we need to stop, we need to cut down on holding.  No question that holding occurs just about on every snap in the National Football League.  I think anybody in this industry will acknowledge that.  What we need to do is stop, cut down on the actions that are triggering the flags of course, which is grabbing and restricting, the jersey coming away from the body and so forth.  We've got to do a better job of it, a more detailed job of playing technical. (Re: Players complaining about how Ben has been getting hit:) No, I don't have a flag. (Have you talked to the League about it?) Again, like I say in here repeatedly.  The things that go on between me and the league will remain between us.  I think that is the prudent approach in getting what we desire which of course is clarity and or change.  I don't think talking to you guys about it helps me in that regard, so I won't do it. (Re: Ben's health:) He has a broken nose, he has a foot.  Ben will be fine.  Ben will be there on Sunday. (Will you limit him at all in practice this week?) No. (Is William Gay more comfortable in nickel packages than the outside?) You'd probably have to ask him that.  I know that he has been providing quality plays for us, not only in coverage but also in pressure.  I think he got a sack last week, but equally important as the sack, he has batted a number of balls down in pressure on the quarterback.  As like a lot of guys, he is playing quality football for us right now and we are appreciative of it. (Did he lose confidence at all last year?) Again, he's be better equipped to answer that question.  I don't delve into confidence, I just look at results and play and I know that I appreciate the play that he is providing us this year. (Does Mark Sanchez remind you of anyone?) He is his own man.  He's got great arm strength and pretty good mobility. I guess you could say he is (Drew) Brees-like.  He plays with great confidence.  He is very aware and he is mature beyond his years.  He is how own man.  I think all of those guys who are top talent, high round draft picks really have characteristics that are individual to themselves. (Take us through Troy's interception.) Troy had a tremendous break on the play.  Whether or not he was baiting Carson (Palmer) is debatable.  It was a route that he was familiar with.  I think TO (Terrell Owens) was the intended receiver, the first one is the one you were referring to, may have tripped or stumbled coming out of his break.  I think that provided the necessary grass that Troy needed to come down hill on the ball and make the play.  But no question, Troy was in great position and he had a great break on the ball.  I think a little click between maybe TO and who it was defending him or the area in which he was planting created the opportunity for us. (Is his injury an aggravation of an old one?) Aggravation of the old one.  One that he been dealing with and one we have been dealing with and we will continue to. (Re: How Jets use Holmes and how he was used here:) There is a definite difference, of course, two different offensive systems.  I think that his unique skill set lends itself to some similarities of course.  Santonio is a great route runner, he is very good after the catch, he has strong hands and those things are X receiver like.  He's capable of creating yards after the catch and individual route running.  So anytime you have a guy of his talents you are going to utilize him in similar ways because of his skill set. (What was it like to say goodbye to him?) It was very much a part of this business.  Those decisions come around every year and we are going to do what is best for our football team.  That decision being one of them.  We realized that we were potentially weakening ourselves at the wide receiver position but we were very optimistic about what Mike Wallace was capable of.  We also knew that what we got in exchange for him would probably strengthen us in another position; of course we eventually used that pick to get Bryant McFadden at starting corner for us.  So those are the normal decisions that go on in our business, particularly in the off season when you are talking about building your football team, usually it involves weakening you in one area and possibly  strengthening you in another area.  So those are the things that you weigh when you make not only that decision but when you make any decision that is personnel related. (Did you watch any of Hard Knocks?) I don't watch it.  I don't watch it all. (I assume you have no interest in doing that.) I have no interest, whatsoever, in doing Hard Knocks.  Hopefully Mr. Rooney feels the same way. (Re: Jets' offensive line losing Damien Woody:) It's a talented bunch. They have a top-round draft pick in D'Brickashaw Ferguson at the left tackle. They have a first-round center in Nick Mangold. I always tease Maurkice Pouncey. He wants to be the best center in the world. He can try by being the best center in the stadium on Sunday. They have some quality players. Losing Damien Woody, a veteran right tackle, is going to require some adjustment, but they are not going to get any sympathy from us. We know about backup tackles playing. It's that time of year, situations that all teams deal with. The good teams find ways to overcome them. They are a 9-4 team so whatever issues they've had I am pretty sure they have been successful in overcoming them, and we'll try to do the same.  (Re: Jets' offense having issues:) They've played some good defenses. They've played some hot teams, some teams that have created issues for them. They've turned the ball over some. They are not a team that turns the ball over quite a bit. It is the things you kind of go through during the course of the season, and I am sure they are excited about kind of rectifying them here this weekend at our expense. (Re: Injuries to tight ends affecting red-zone production:) I am not going to blame anything. If we want to put three tight ends and employ three tight ends, and we only have two of them suited, we can tell number 79 [Trai Essex] to report as eligible and go about our business. We are not executing in that area to our liking because we are not executing in that area to our liking.

Good afternoon. I guess we will start with a little bit of personnel news. Daniel Sepulveda is going to have surgery on Friday and have his ACL repaired. It's good news from a standpoint that it is repairable, and it should be a normal recovery. So we're excited about that. But with that we had to acquire the services of a new punter. We worked out several candidates today. We selected Jeremy Kapinos. He's a Penn State man, a three-year NFL veteran. He was employed by the Indianapolis Colts earlier this year. He's punted in a game this year; he's done a nice job. He's formerly employed by the Green Bay Packers. He's a guy that met the criteria that we're looking for to be quite honest with you. He's got league experience. He's kicked in games this year, and he's no stranger to the elements as we know that may be a factor for us moving forward. So we're excited about having him in the fold and moving forward with him as our punter. He represented himself nicely today in the workout as did all the men. We appreciate their efforts. So we have a nice stable body there and are ready to move forward. In some other injury news Flozell Adams has a mild high ankle sprain that he sustained in the game. He wasn't able to finish the game. We'll see how that limits him at the early portions of the week and let that be the determinate of whether or not he's available to us. Ben had surgery yesterday to have his broken nose fixed. I think he's going to have some gauze removed today. I am sure there is going to be some level of discomfort. I don't think it's going to keep him out of football in any form or fashion. About the only adjustment is that he's probably going to wear a shield on his helmet, a clear shield to protect him from that standpoint. Heath Miller is experiencing some discomfort that goes along with concussions. His availability may be doubtful this week but we'll see if it picks up as the week goes on. Of course if we are going to err we are going to err on the side of caution when it comes to player's health, and that's the appropriate thing to do. So we'll take that approach. We're still taking a similar approach with Troy in terms of his potential practice participation in the early parts of the week like we have done the past several weeks. It seems to be serving him well and us well so we will continue to do that. Aaron Smith had an MRI. He's doing pretty good. He's going to take the next step now and that's lifting weights. We're going to take another MRI in about two weeks or so and see where that takes us. We're encouraged by his progress. There are no setbacks in his recovery. It's time to take the next step and now start tossing a few weights around, which is good news. Matt Spaeth appears to have a clean bill of health from his concussion from a couple weeks backs. He's been fully cleared. He's going to be practicing and participating tomorrow so that's an encouragement. Usually there is a laundry list when you come out of a Baltimore Ravens' contest. Our last one is no different than others. We're pleased with the win. It was very necessary. We had to even the score. They came into our place and got on, so it was good to go and do that at theirs. It was a significant win to go into a hostile environment and win in December. That's the measure of a good team. It's our desire to be a good team, but we're going to keep it in perspective. It was a win that had to happen for us. The guys delivered it, and now we move on to a new week and a new AFC North opponent in the Cincinnati Bengals here at our place. Looking at them briefly, I think it's important when you start to talk about playing someone for the second team you start with how they are different. When you look at how the Cincinnati Bengals are different, they have sustained a significant number of injuries in their defensive line over the course of the season. I would imagine that they would be pleasantly surprised by the talent and skill of their young players that they have on their defensive line. This young man rush rotation that they have has been pretty impressive over the last several weeks. We're going to have our work cut out for us there with young guys like Carlos Dunlap, a rookie out of Florida. I think he leads them in sacks. Man, he's come on like gangbusters. They're playing Robert Geathers inside in rush situations. He's highly athletic and a big matchup problem for guards. Geno Atkins, a young under tackle-like guy out of Georgia, is another guy that's being very disruptive on the inside for them. And of course Michael Johnson, who is a second or third-year man out of Georgia Tech, is the other end. Those four young guys come in during passing situations and are really rushing well together. They're game are disruptive. Their edge men in Dunlap and Johnson are really breaking pockets down. And of course Atkins and Geathers are really getting after guards and centers when given the opportunity. I think that's the number one place they are different defensively. In the secondary Reggie Nelson continues to emerge as a guy that's a playmaker for them. Their linebacker group is essentially intact since the last time we played them. They have a high quality corner tandem. When you talk about playing the Bengals' defense it starts with those guys in Jonathan Joseph and Leon Hall because they can cover folks. They're really good at it and solid. They have got a new nickel in Jonathan Wade. New to them, not new to the NFL, this guy has been around. Offensively if you look at how they are different I don't know if they are drastically different from a personnel standpoint as they are defensively. But what you do see is a division of labor change or guys having an opportunity to make more plays for them. Their rookie tight end, Jermaine Gresham, is really coming on. He's first-rounder, a high-pedigree guy, you see that. I think Carson Palmer is developing a great deal of comfort in delivering him that ball and particularly in critical circumstances. Last week against New Orleans he converted some highly contested and pivotal third downs. He also was a two-point conversion man for them that tied that game up. Same thing can be said about Jordan Shipley inside. He's playing beyond his years from a wisdom standpoint and awareness standpoint. He's doing a nice job of working the interior of the field in their passing game. They are rotating some offensive linemen in because of injury. Anthony Collins, the Kansas man, is playing some right tackle for them. This guy has been familiar with us. He's started against us in the past and quite frankly he's blocked us well. So we have big time respect for him, and we have to be prepared to deal with him. I am seeing some more guys participating out of the backfield for them, whether it's Ryan Leonard in the passing game as a third-down back, or whether it's Bernard Scott as a change of pace back, who is a nice perimeter runner and provides a nice compliment to Cedric Benson. They are a 2-9 football team or so, no doubt. But they've been in just about every football game. They made us absolutely miserable the last time we played them. This is an AFC North matchup. We expect no different, 60 minutes of football is going to be required. So we are excited about starting the preparation process here this week.    (How important was Kapinos' holding ability?) It was an element of the equation but I wasn't going to let it be a significant element.  We need a punter.  We have some holder candidates on our football team.  Some guys that have held in NFL football games and are capable. Antwaan Randle El is one of them.  So I was not going to let holding be the determining factor in selecting a punter. I was more interested in the punting (Will he hold or will someone else?) We will determine that over the course of the week in preparing and really just rely on the comfort level that Shaun has in the candidates. (What us the recovery time for (Daniel) Sepulveda?) I have no idea.  We are going to place him on IR, so that is a 2011 question. (Is (Heath) Miller just experiencing headaches at this point?) I just characterize it as post concussion syndrome and we will see where it takes us.  I haven't talked to him personally, that is why I am being hesitant about describing what those symptoms are.  I don't know. (Re: Ben's performance:) He's a competitor.  I think I even said it after the game that we expect that from him, not that it goes unappreciated, but we just expect that from him.  He expects that from himself.  He is our quarterback.  The AFC North is competitive.  The series against the Ravens is a competitive one.  Noone is going to leave that stadium extremely comfortable, on either side.  We understand what playing those guys is about and he delivered for us. (Will Trai Essex stay on the right side if Flozell (Adams) can't go and who would you have been your tight end other than a lineman?) We had no other tight end.  David Johnson was the last one on our roster.  We had no other.  In regards to the Flozell question, Trai of course finished the game and did a nice job for us.  He is the first man off the bench but we will see where the week takes us in terms of Flozell's availability. It's a little uncomfortable playing with one tight end and six offensive linemen.  There is a lot that is not comfortable about the NFL this time of year. (Hines (Ward) said he was ready to go and be the next guy at tight end.) We have a bunch of volunteers and it doesn't necessarily mean I want to use them. (Did you blitz more against Baltimore than you did the past few games?) It is probably in line with our personality.  We don't allow other teams dictate how we go about our business. (Is it nice to see that you aren't the one answering the questions about fines this week?) I didn't know that someone was being asked. (Re: Baltimore received fines.) It's none of my business.  It is Cincinnati Bengals Week for us and that stuff is between the league office and the people they are addressing it with. (Are you concerned with getting beat deep?) I don't like it when it happens.  I am not overly concerned about it, no.  They have some talented people in Baltimore and they have a talented quarterback.  They made a few nice plays.  It is kind of uncharacteristic of us but I think giving up big plays is uncharacteristic of any great defense.  Of course we desire to be a great defense, so hopefully we don't make a habit of it. (Isaac (Redman) indicated that he wasn't supposed to be on the field for the touchdown pass, can you take us through that? ) He is possibly capable of being on the field.  Those backs are interchangeable, particularly in those situations.  All three of the backs that we employ are very reliable in our empty sets and we have a great deal of comfort of course.  Mewelde Moore is usually the lead dog in that regard because of his past experience but Isaac is quite capable.  We delivered a hot pass to him, he was a determined guy, he came out of two or three tackles and we picked up a block or two on the other side.  One of them by a young man, Emmanuel Sanders, who ensured that he was able to get in the end zone.  It was just a timely play delivered by a young man who works extremely hard and it is good to see it pay off when given an opportunity to contribute to us.  He like others, we are getting a lot of contribution from young guys and it is funny when you look at the stats sheet after the game and you see guys like Mike Wallace, Antonio Brown, Emmanuel Sanders and Isaac Redman and David Johnson catching multiple passes.  It is encouraging, not necessarily comfortable, but encouraging. (You said two dogs and two bones.  Did you like what (Antonio) Brown and (Emmanuel) Sanders contributed?) I thought both guys made their presence felt in the football game and helped contribute to the win and that's what we are looking for.  All of the guys that are given game day helmets need to be capable of anteing up and kicking in.  I like the contributions of both guys.  Particularly, I thought the kickoff coverage tackle by Emmanuel Sanders at the end of the game.  We hold those kinds of contributions at high regard, because we are football coaches and football players first and positional guys second.  Yes he is a wide receiver and kick return man but that was as big of a play that he has delivered for us to run down there and tackle a guy inside the twenty in the latter parts of that football game. (Were you surprised Baltimore didn't make a change schematically on the play which led to Troy's play on (Joe) Flacco?) I don't know how they administer their offense or what their check and balances are.  I am not the man to comment on that.  I am glad it unfolded the way it did. (Re: Ziggy Hood) Like some of the offensive guys that I mentioned and of course it is easy to measure their progress because of their touches or what they do with the football.  Ziggy can be compared to the other ones.  He is a young guy who has been given an opportunity and has taken advantage of it.  He is playing really good football for us.  He is doing the detail things, using his hands well, staying squared, playing with good pad level, is getting some production, but production comes with some of those things that I have mentioned earlier.  He had a big sack for us there early in the game.  He is doing a nice job. He is still a guy early in the development like those other ones are and we fully expect him to continue to grow.  When you talk about people that you are playing, their young guys are growing and developing.  I mentioned Jordan Shipley, Jermaine Gresham, the young rush-man from Cincinnati.  Our young people better mirror their growth and development. (Can you talk about going into the last quarter of the season?) I am not ready to have a quarter talk.  It is Tuesday of the Cincinnati Bengals.  They swept us a year ago.  They celebrated pretty nicely on our field the second time they beat us.  That's my focus.   (Re: Brett Keisel) There is another guy who is I am sure willing to play tight end and he is probably the first place I would go.  He is an awesome athlete.  I like his contributions.  It is great to have him back for not only his play but his leadership and demeanor.  He provided a nice interior rush for us.  He disrupted some passing lanes with his length.  I think he batted a pass or two. Just a rock solid Brett Keisel type of contribution. (Re: Did you try to stop Suggs more in the second half?) No we didn't, not more than what we had planned going into the game. I thought that we warmed up to the action. We got the crowd out of it a little bit as the game wore on, and that helped him get off in terms of that nature. I just think that we stayed in the fight and didn't blink, guys continue to compete. You can't always nail down where he is going to rush from. This makes helping to guess him extremely difficult.  They play him at left and right end. They have a guy that compliments him, Nagata as a rush man who they move around a bit as well. It's tough to nail down their locations in terms to help us, but in general I thought that we continued to warm up to the action, to the challenge and we improved as the game moved on.  (Re: Shaun Suisham's kick: ) He hit 45-yarder into the wind, but actually it was two yards out of our agreed upon range based on from what happened in pregame. I think the ball was at the 27-yard line, and I was really going to be comfortable when the ball was at the 25-yard line or in. I took a shot at it, and gave the man a competitor's opportunity. He made the play and that wind was significant at that end of the stadium. It was not a surprise to me that Baltimore did not attempt a field goal at the 48-yard line in that same direction. 45 yards was pushing it. (Is Shaun a lift to the team?) He's six for six, we'll take it. (RE: Spaeth being the same as Heath Miller:) He does everything that Heath Miller has done. This won't be his first rodeo by any stretch in terms of replacing Heath Miller. He's done these stretches before. I think Heath Miller missed a two or three game stretch in 2009 and Matt Spaeth delivered four or five catch games back to back. This guy is a reliable guy, a Mackey Award winner. He doesn't get a lot of notoriety because he plays behind Heath Miller, but he is not a back up. He is a starter in waiting as far as we're concerned. If given the opportunity the standards for him will be Heath-like.  (What happened in the first game against Cincinnati? ) They came back. (Where there any specific breakdowns?) One drive we were highly penalized and gave them the ball on the one-yard line. I think that entire dive was penalties. They punched the ball in and the other one was when they put together a nice drive, which of course they are capable of that. They have two legendary wide outs and a rock solid quarterback, and Carson Palmer as well as some other young weapons. They are capable of moving the ball on anyone quite frankly, like they did against New Orleans and made that game close. It is what it is. It is the NFL, record or no, people are capable of competing and whooping you. There's no question that's what makes it exciting. That's why our fans watch and that's why were preparing with an edge. (Re: T.O's season:) There's a bunch of examples of that in the NFC North. Hines Ward, Derrick Mason and T.O. There are a bunch of seasoned wide receivers that are very talented, but also very smart, and are call on experience and know how. He has some of those characteristics that some of the other men that I mentioned. (Does Keenan Louis have trouble knowing where he is on kickoffs?) Ask Keenan. (Is this where you were hoping Aaron Smith was?) He is a week better the last time we talked and that's encouraging. Maybe the next time we talk I'll say the same. (With him lifting weights now is there a reason for hope that he'll be ready for playoffs?) Yes and that's been our intentions all along. This is not charity by any stretch. We're not in that business. We're in the business to win football games. We thought that it was a possibility that this man can make it back and help us. He's doing what he is supposed to do. Were doing what were suppose to do, which is win and hopefully those two things converge and meet.  (Re: The fan that got arrested at the game:) Steeler Nation, you got to love them. I appreciate his support and all the other supporters we had at Baltimore. It was awesome.

Good afternoon. It's Tuesday so we'll take care of our normal housekeeping. A quick assessment of the Buffalo game, there were a couple of things that stood out to me when reviewing the tape. I thought we had critical playmaking at critical times, really in all three phases. Whether you look at Ben's scramble on third down, I thought it was a significant, uplifting play for our football team. But just our third-down playmaking in general I thought was at a high level for the better part of the game. At critical moments I thought that we delivered necessary plays. Defensively you could look to a number of situations and plays; Troy's interception in the red area was a critical play, forcing them to kick a field goal after Rashard Mendenhall fumbled when we gave them an extremely short field. What the defense was able to do in overtime under the circumstances given that the initial kickoff return came to midfield. We were fighting an uphill battle from a position standpoint in overtime, the better part of overtime. And I thought our defense did a nice job of defending the blades of grass that we had to defend. And on special teams, Shaun Suisham banged four kicks for us and Daniel Sepulveda had a significant punt for us out of our endzone that really changed the complexion of the overtime period. I thought we had significant playmaking in all three phases. I liked the way that our team didn't blink in the face of adversity. It was another positive. There was a lot of adversity from trying times in that football game. Negatively speaking, some of the adversity was self-induced. As is always the case in football, we've got to do a better job of taking care of the football. I thought the turnover jump-started them. That's just how it is. We were highly penalized. We can't be as penalized as we've been, not only in that game but in the last two weeks, and think we are going to be successful on the road against a good Baltimore Ravens' team. As is always in regards to penalties, we're not going to get carried away with dealing with it. What we're going to do is focus on the things we can control and play the game as extremely hard as we can, as fair as we can within the rules that are prescribed by the NFL. If you look at our injury status in terms of where we are from an injury standpoint, Antonio Brown worked out this morning, had a really good workout. We're optimistic about this guy being able to participate in the early portion of the week and fully participate this week. We'll see where that participation takes us. Nick Eason looks to be pretty good. He might be limited here somewhat at the initial part of the week but we expect to have him. Similar things can be said about Bryant McFadden, but when you're dealing with a hamstring injury it could be more problematic, but he's slated to participate. We'll see where that participation takes us. Same thing could be said about Ben Roethlisberger with his foot sprain. He might be limited somewhat tomorrow. I'm going to be optimistic and hopeful and maybe he will be a full participant, but there's a chance he couldn't be. Similar approach this week with Troy as it has been the last couple of weeks. We simply want to take every precaution possible to keep this man up-and-running. It's obvious that he's playing really good football for us, so we want that to continue. There's a fine line in terms of that when you're talking about limiting someone's preparation, but he is a veteran football player, a good one. So we're going to do the best thing we can in terms of getting him to the stadium in one piece. Aaron Smith is a week better. Matt Spaeth, we will get some post-concussion tests and stuff run tomorrow morning to determine his practice availability. Some things are shaping up. We're feeling pretty good from a health standpoint. We're not going to make any bones about that anyway. Brett Keisel is going to be a full participant as well this week and hopefully play of course. So we feel comfortable with that. In regards to the Ravens it is usual Steelers versus Ravens. It's the significant game. It's awesome to be a part of significant games in December. We're two 8-3 football teams. If you want to be a division winner you have to go on the road and win division games. They did it earlier in the year against us. We're given an opportunity to go to their place and try and get a victory. That's the only way to get it done. The secret in this thing is that there is no secret. If you want to be a dominant team, if you want to be a good team, if you want to make a splash, you have to take your show on the road in hostile environments against known opponents, familiar opponents, and make the significant plays that are necessary to win. That's going to be our focus in terms of our preparation this week. I can run down the list of superlatives regarding the Ravens. I think we all know what they are capable of. Offensively Joe Flacco throws to a variety of receivers, Anquan Boldin, Derrick Mason, Todd Heap and others. They run the ball extremely well with Ray Rice and Willis McGahee. They've got a good, tough interior offensive line. They've done a nice job blocking us the last couple of times we've played them, not only in the run game but in the pass game. We've got to do a good job there. We've got to put pressure on the quarterback; we've got to stop their run. Defensively they are led up front by Haloti Ngata. He's playing as good as anyone at his position in the game right now. He's a disruptive force, one that we have to reckon with in some form or fashion. Usually that's going to require multiple men, just being honest. When you turn the tape on people try to block him with multiple people. Notice how I said they try to block him with multiple people. He's a really good player. Terrell Suggs is as disruptive as ever. Jarrett Johnson is very versatile. Ray Lewis is making plays in the run and in the pass. I think I mentioned the last time we were preparing for these guys how impressive it is that he makes the plays that he makes in the passing game, in space. He closed our game out with an interception. He had a pick-six versus Carolina. This guy covers a bunch of ground. He's a really good football player. The significant thing or difference for them in this game, on the back end, is the presence of Ed Reed. And we all know what the presence of Ed Reed means, proceed with caution when attacking him vertically down the field. Time and time again he shows that he's capable of making plays, game changing plays. He surveys the deep middle of that field, but he's a sideline-to-sideline capable guy. This guy has missed a significant amount of action. He has four interceptions, one of which he pitched to a teammate that ran it back for a touchdown. This is an unselfish, top-notch and quality playmaker. So we have to reckon with him. If there's a significant difference in preparation for this game than the last one, it's the acknowledgment in this existence of Ed Reed. Of course we didn't have Ben last game; they didn't have Ed Reed. Those two things probably cancel each other out. This game is probably going to come down to a last possession or two in a hard-fought game in a hostile environment like it always does. So we're excited about that opportunity. I think that we've been in this situation before this year and have been somewhat unsuccessful. We have an opportunity to go into a hostile environment versus a good team in prime time football and win. When you look back at our journey that has been the 2010 season, we haven't been successful in that situation. In New Orleans we didn't play as well as we'd like to have played. So this week provides an opportunity on that front for us, to kind of exercise the man versus himself battle. We got a desire to be good in all areas, situations and circumstances, and really the opponent is irrelevant. We have an opportunity as a football team to go into a hostile environment versus a good team on prime time television and seek a victory. That victory will put us in decent position in terms of some of the other things we'd like to do. But all our eyes are focused on this opportunity and preparation for it.  (Was there ever a thought that Ben would have to come out of the game and did you know he was going to punt with his left foot?) I did.  I called it.  And he was fine to go.  We have to do a better job of getting down there and downing that ball.  I didn't really think that he was in danger of coming out of the game.  He was absent from our sideline there at the very end of the first half and maybe late coming back after halftime but that was simply because we were taking pictures of his foot.  I was pretty comfortable that he was going to compete and continue throughout the game.  (Re: Ben being roughed up after the tackle and was that something you send to the League?) What I send to the league is between me and the league. (Did you think that was roughing the passer?) I don't remember what particular play you are talking about and again, I don't have a response to that. (Could Ben's injury get worse?) No, not at this point.  There is some pain and discomfort of course.  We have him in a walking boot when we are not working to help him with that as much as we can.  We will see where the week takes us. (Would you go with Byron Leftwich then?) Byron. (Re: Casey Hampton:) He is playing good football for us.  He was somewhat of a frustrated worker on Sunday but that was because of the amount of four-wide offense and things that Buffalo displayed against us.  He didn't get an opportunity to play as much as he would have liked.  Casey is a leader and a competitor.  He understands the situation that is going on around him in terms of how we have some starters in waiting playing with him.  He understands the added responsibility with playing with those types of guys and I think he wants to deliver for us. (Re: Responding to adversity:) I think games like this week really will tell that story. I like where we are.  I like the way we responded to some of the situations and circumstances that we have been in.  But this is a December battle that we are all on, not only us but the other 31 teams.  The races get heated in December.  There are significant games of course.  So how we do moving forward will really kind of indicate what we are in terms of responding to those things that the game presents us. (Why have you been so penalized?) We could exercise a little better technique, no doubt.  I like the way the guys are fighting. Sometimes fighting and competing comprises your technique.  I think we could be better in that area and that is what we are going to focus on in terms of preparation for this week and for our next opportunity. (Re: Chris Kemoeatu talking about using better technique and at any point did you consider replacing him with having four holding penalties?) I didn't and the reason I didn't more importantly than the penalties themselves, like I talked about earlier, I liked the way that we collectively responded to the adversity, some of which we created ourselves.  There were many instances in the game where we were getting penalties and then boom, we were overcoming them immediately whether it was the next play or converting a third down.  I understand that that is not always going to be the case and that is why I said moving forward, playing a team like Baltimore, we have to be careful with putting our team in those circumstances.  But largely throughout that game, I thought that we were able to overcome the penalties that we sustained throughout the course of the drives, at least offensively.  So for that reason I was less concerned about them during the course of the game, it is just something that stands out to you after the completion of the game when you are evaluating your work.  (Teams come out with offensive formations that force you to change your defensive personnel and is that an automatic advantage when aren't playing the guys you want out there?) We don't always match them personnel-wise.  Oftentimes, particularly in first-and-ten and second-and-medium when people go three wides, if we chose to, we still stay in our base defense of personnel.  The offensive personnel doesn't always dictate what we do from a personnel standpoint.  It is the complete picture.  It is offensive personnel, field position, down and distance.  All of those things dictate to us which people we chose to employ so the offensive personnel alone never dictates that to us. (Re: David Johnson's great blocking:) I wouldn't necessarily call it great.  I think his better days lie ahead.  He took a step, he played with energy and emotion, he finished blocks.  He is a young guy that has kind of been on the come throughout the better part of the year.  By the nature of his job description he doesn't get a lot of notoriety for improvement or for doing his job, but we are not concerned about that.  We have monitored his progress and have given him feedback.  He continues to adjust to the things that we want him to do and the nature in which we want him to play.  I thought last Sunday was a signature game from that standpoint.  Let's see what he does with it. (Re: Byron and Charlie Batch:) They are veteran guys.  Both have been franchise-like quarterbacks.  If called upon I expect one or both of those guys to perform winning football for us. (Re: Being more comfortable with giving Isaac Redman the ball:) I felt that way all season to be honest with you.  I don't think anything has happened over the course of the season with him that has made me feel more comfortable.  This guy has been earning his carries since he has been here.  He did a nice job a year ago as a young guy.  He continued to get himself acclimated to the professional game with preparing himself and working.  He had a great training camp and preseason. He is doing a nice with the opportunities that are given to him and has been. (Re: Troy's strip and how that was different from the continuation catch in the end zone with like what happened to Calvin Johnson.) What happened was that was in the field of play of course and the rules governing the plays like that in the field of play are different than in the end zone.  But in that specific circumstance it was inside the two minutes.  The booth controlled the review.  So they wanted to take a look at it and make sure that was a catch, no catch or a fumble or what have you.  So they blew the next play dead, the kill play and took a look at it upstairs. (So there is a different rule when you are in the field of play or in the end zone?) Certainly. (Are weeks leading up to Baltimore game different than other weeks?) They are different in terms of some of the attention the game garners and some of the things that you have to deal with. But in terms of preparation and us putting a plan together to accentuate our strengths and minimize our negatives, to play to the strength of the matchups, to minimize the weaknesses of the matchups, it is a normal week for us. (Re: Ravens not being as successful on sacks:) Sacks don't always measure success in terms of pressure.  The way the ball is distributed and the time in which the ball is delivered has a lot to do with it.  I think they have put consistent pressure on opposing passers.  The tape tells me that.  That are disruptive as usual, whether it is Johnson, or Suggs or Ngata or others.  Of course they are capable of blitzing linebackers and secondary men.  They do a nice job of bringing both safeties and corners.  They have been doing a typical Baltimore Raven type job in terms of putting pressure on the quarterback and getting the opportunities that comes with that. (Re: Ziggy Hood's progress?) Similar to the David Johnson discussion, he is a second year guy that has been given the opportunity due to someone else's misfortune and has taken advantage of it. He is consistently on the rise and the nature of his job doesn't garner a lot of attention and the plays that he is making or not making don't get the kind of attention that say a Mike Wallace does.  But he is a young guy on the come, that is taking advantage of opportunities and we are pleased with his progress and we hope and need it to continue. (Is there any more clarity on the return time for Aaron Smith?) He is a week closer. (Are there milestones set for him in his progress?) We are actually going to take some hard core looks and pictures of his progress probably first of next week and I might have a significant update or two for you. (Re: William Gay:) I thought William Gay specifically responded to the challenge. He was competitive and combative. He made plays, he challenged throws.  I think maybe he had four pass break ups.  His play is as significant as Troy's on Troy's interception down there in the red area because he made the initial break up and of course Troy made an incredible catch on the interception.  But William Gay stepped up and made some significant plays, particularly in the latter part of that game and the others guys, just having to step up and play defensive football and log defensive snaps along with their four-phased special teams responsibility, I was impressed with. (Will James Harrison have to change his tackling technique?) Obviously he does because the league doesn't agree with him. (What did you think?) My opinion doesn't matter. (Is there a fairness issue when gets fined that much and then you see the fines on those who got into fist fights?) Life isn't fair.  I am not concerned about fairness.  I am really not.  I am more concerned about preparing for the Baltimore Ravens. (Re: Worries about your pass rush:) What I want is consistent pressure when given the opportunity. I think our guys are capable of more. We're going to need more in this environment going into Baltimore. So that's going to be our mentality as we prepare this week. (Re: Stevie Johnson dropping the touchdown catch:) The guy ran a nice route. As Ike Taylor rolled out with his coverage and tried to track the ball, his angle was a little flatter than the receiver's. It created some separation. Ryan Clark came over and covered as much of the distance as he could. Quite frankly it was a really good route and an even better throw, and thankfully he didn't catch it. But I don't worry about those things. I thought Emmanuel Sanders had an opportunity to catch and run for a score in regulation where none of those plays even exist. Im not going to cry about our drop; I hope they don't cry about theirs. (Re: Sanders and Brown both dressing this weekend:) There very well may be two dogs and two bones. We will see how the week unfolds.  (What is your normal routine when evaluating games and sending stuff to the league:) I want to leave the game evaluation and the official evaluation process that goes on in every city around the league on Mondays and Tuesdays between myself and the league. I think that's the appropriate thing to do. We all want to do our jobs at a high level, including the officials and the officiating department. I'm not going to address the minute details of how we go about doing it. We seek clarity on a game-in-and-game-out basis, whether we are highly penalized or not. It's just a process of going about trying to play perfect football and an attempt to. In terms of what we're going to do with our football team, we're going to focus on the things that we can control. We're going to try to play as hard as we normally play, as fairly as we can and within the rules the NFL prescribes. That is and will be our focus moving forward. In terms of some of the things that we gain clarity with the league, it happens on a week-in-week-out basis. I am not going to make more out of it this week because we were highly penalized. We're not going to make more out of it this week because we were highly penalized the last two weeks. It is what it is. It's November pushing into December football. Guys are straining and doing their very best to play winning football, with that sometimes comes penalties. We're going to do everything in our power to minimize it this week because we realize that under the circumstances it can be extremely hurtful to our chances of winning if it is similar to the way it's been in the last couple of weeks. (Re: Differences between Baltimore and the Steelers since the first meeting:) We're different, they're different. It's all going to wash out. We're all the same. We were close in record the first time we played. We are both 8-3. It's what we've come to expect from those guys. We just try to uphold our end of the bargain in terms of the rivalry and be a competitive, good team when we face each other. I think we've done that. I think we're going to give our fans a top-quality game. I look forward to seeing Steeler nation in Baltimore this weekend. It's going to be awesome.

Good afternoon. I guess I will start with a quick assessment of our performance on Sunday. It was what was required. I liked the response that our team had to a disappointing outing that we had a week prior. I thought the energy was awesome. I thought plays were delivered from a variety of people from all three phases. It's good to see signs of those things from a football team at this time of year, particularly in response to a sub-par performance. I thought the leaders stepped up, guys like Ben [Roethlisberger], James Farrior and James Harrison. But they were supported by just about everyone. Everyone put their hand in that pile and made the necessary plays for us to come out of the game. For that we're pleased. From an injury standpoint coming out of the game, Antonio Brown has some swelling on his knee. It's going to slow him down here at the early portion of the week. He's in the process of getting that evaluated right now, as always when you're talking about a young guy that misses practice time that might put his availability in danger. But I'll have more information as we proceed with that throughout the week. Matt Spaeth sustained a concussion. He's going to take a concussion test and that's going to guide us in terms of where we go with him. Troy Polamalu's injury is still the same. We're probably going to rest him at the early portion of the week, but of course it didn't affect his play on Sunday and we don't anticipate it affecting his play this Sunday coming up. Will Allen has been cleared to come back to practice and play. So we're excited about that. Maurkice Pouncey had a quad contusion. He appears to be fine, maybe limited somewhat in the earlier part of the week. From that standpoint we're a relatively healthy outfit. We anticipate getting Brett Keisel back. He's going to be a full participant here at the early portion of the week and will be able to play for us. That's a good thing, getting some of these people back, finding ways to put a winning combination together. Some young guys, some starters in waiting are getting the opportunity to put their hand in the pile and contribute. That's all part of this journey that is this season. We like where we are this far. We got a big week this week. We're going to Buffalo, getting back in the business of playing on the road. We don't take that lightly. We got an AFC team here of course. It seems like we always tend to run into people as they get hot, which is fine by us. The only way you're going to be the team we desire to be is by playing people, playing good people, playing people at their best, playing teams on the rise and finding a way to get it done. When you look at the last five games or so for Buffalo, they are really shaping up and identifying themselves. They've had some changes with the new coaching staff, but in the last five games they lost at Baltimore by three, they lost at Kansas City in overtime by three and they won their last two. So they are a warm football team. I am sure they are looking to get hot. I am sure they are excited about us coming in there. We have to prepare to be at our best, go take care of our business and that's what we intend to do. When you look at these guys and what they're capable of and the things that need to concern us as we prepare probably starts at the quarterback position with Ryan Fitzpatrick. The unique thing about this guy from our standpoint is he is familiar with us. This guy started some football against us and represented himself well. Some of the blitzes and looks that we have shouldn't be foreign to him. He got after Cincinnati pretty good, and it really seems like he's establishing a nice rapport with his receiving corps. The young man, Stevie Johnson being one of them, some of these receivers are some young guys and some guys that you're less familiar with. But when you turn the tape on you see why they're getting some of the recognition that they are. Johnson had a big day last Sunday against Cincinnati in that comeback victory, but he's not a one-trick-pony if you will. This guy has got nine touchdowns on the season, up over 700 yards receiving. He's really established himself as a legitimate player in this league. Lee Evans is a known commodity. He's a big play guy, a speed guy capable of getting behind you. Donald Jones is another guy, number 19, who is emerging as a potential weapon for Fitzpatrick. Fred Jackson is doing some nice things for them at running back. He went over 1,000 yards a year ago. He's not new to this. He did some nice things last week and closed the game out with a nice run against Cincinnati. Defensively they kind of been a unit in flux, from 3-4 to 4-3. They appear to be settling in now in regards to that. One thing that they have is a talented, deep and high-motored front. Marcus Stroud is a rock-solid player. Chris Kelsey is a high-motor guy. Kyle Williams, I got big-time respect for at the nose tackle position. He's an aware, hustling play-maker kind of a guy. Spencer Johnson plays a bunch of ball for them. They picked up Dwan Edwards who is familiar with us from his time in Baltimore. He appears to be providing a spark for them and really some quality play. Paul Posluszny is an every down linebacker that we need to be prepared to deal with. This guy is a sideline-to-sideline tackler who is very aware, a screen man who destroys those things. He's very good in coverage. They put him a lot against running backs in coverage. He does a nice job with that. And they got some quality players in their secondary. Leodis McKelvin is a first-rounder. At the safety position, Donte Whitner is a first-rounder and a good football player. Jairus Byrd is a second year free safety coming off a Pro Bowl rookie season when he had nine interceptions and was around the tops in the league. Their special teams has always been rock solid with this group as long as Bruce DeHaven has been there as a coordinator. They never run out of return men. C.J. Spiller has missed some time. He is a legitimate return man. Roscoe Parrish is on the Reserve/Injured List. They've still got Leodis McKelvin; they've still got Terrence McGee. These guys churn out Pro Bowl-caliber return men every year. It seems like a lot of their eligibles are capable return men. So we got to be on our screws in that area. It's Tuesday, we got a lot of work ahead of us. Such is life in the NFL, and we're okay with that. We like where we are but boy we've got some work to do, and we're excited about doing it. (What is your reaction to (Richard) Seymour's fine?) None.  I don't have a reaction.  I tend to focus on the things that are relevant to our team, moving forward with the things that we can control.  That doesn't fall into either category.  That is really between Richard Seymour and the NFL office. (Have you heard anything on possible fines for your players?) Have not, no. (Do you think the league is in transition with officiating?) I know that there has been some heated reaction from players and so forth from around the league on how the games have been officiated and so forth, but in terms of the league being in transition or potential transition, in that phase, that is not a question for me to answer.  Emotions always run high during the course of the football season particularly when you push through the later part of November.  Guys are fighting for spots, there is going to be some competitive spirit involved.  Very rarely do I view guys pleased with officiating when it doesn't go your way.  Such is life.  We are not going to worry about those things.  What we are going to do is prepare ourselves for the challenge that is in front of us this week. (What is your philosophy on when to keep players in the game or pull them when a game has got out of hand?) It just really depends on each particular game.  I think each individual circumstance has its own rules that guide you and you develop that mentality as the week develops.  The nature of your lead, how you acquired the lead, are you controlling the line of scrimmage, the potential capability of your opponent to come back , what's their personality like when they are behind, are they effective in that area, is that a strong suit of theirs or is it not.  There is a myriad of things that go into those decisions, and really makes each individual circumstance unique and those decisions are made accordingly. (Re: Perception that officials might be looking more closely at your team:) I hope everybody is looking closely at our team because we want to be that team.  We want to be good.  So I am not concerned about that perception or that talk to be quite honest with you.  If we are as good as we desire to be everybody is going to be looking at us. (Is it cause and effect because you are that team, the popular team in the NFL and made an example of?) We better add to that reputation with our preparation and play this week.  That again is my focus, that's what I want the focus of our team to be.  It's ok.  People throw stones at the crown.  We don't wear the crown but we desire to.  So if something comes with that we will embrace whatever that is.  (Re: Standard and expectations:) The standard is the standard.  I don't think it changed a week ago.  We always desire to play winning football.  I like the way our guys responded to a subpar performance but really that has nothing to do with what we expect.  We expect winning football every time we play.  The record of our opponent this week is really irrelevant.  I expect winning football.  I expect a winning type preparation.  We are not taking this group lightly because of their record.  We recognize that they are a better football team right now than their record.  The last five games tell us so, particularly the last two of course, which were wins.  They played quality teams, they took Baltimore and Kansas City into overtime and lost by three.    We won't take this group lightly.  We are not in a position to take anyone lightly.  We aren't that good.  We are just trying to etch out a position for ourselves in this thing as we push into December and there is some clarity in terms of who is good and who is not.  We want to be one of those teams. (If you pull a guy is it to prevent injury or to give someone else experience?) Usually a combination of both, but players' safety when a game is decided will probably be the premium. But again, those decisions are made on a week to week basis based on game circumstance. (Why not in this game, why not put Byron (Leftwich) in?) We intended to run the ball.  So we thought that he was ok to turn and hand the ball off to Isaac Redman and others, which is what we did. (Re: Ramon Foster and did he earn another start?) He did.  He wasn't perfect but none of us were.  We like the intensity.  We like the physical presence that he provided.  We liked the way he and Flozell worked together.  We will push forward.  Again we are not going to be bashful about what we expect from our guys.  We are trying to fight and win football games. We want guys to play well.  We believe that we have a bunch of guys that are capable of playing winning football for us so when given an opportunity we expect them to deliver and I thought that he did. (Is Flozell (Adams) where you thought he would be?) Really he has done maybe even better than what we anticipated.  He is an old dog learning a new trick, if you will, playing on the right side.  He has been very stable, a stabilizing presence for us.  He has a nice demeanor that we like.  He plays, he is competitive, is only concerned about winning.  I like guys like that.  This guy has made a lot of money, he's got a lot of accolades, he has been on some high profile teams and so forth.  None of that seems to be overly important to him right now. He just wants to win and he wants to do whatever he can to help us do so.  So those things are a lot of the reason why we are excited that Flozell is a Steeler right now. (Has Ziggy (Hood) improved and will (Brett) Keisel start?) We will determine whether or not Keisel participates or his level of participation based on how he plays this week and of course conditioning and our perception of how many snaps he can handle will be a portion of that.  Ziggy I think is continuing to emerge.  He played over 50 snaps this week.  I think that was significant.  But I thought he just showed some quality play. I thought he was squared on the line of scrimmage, I thought he used his hands well, he made some plays.  He was a consistent presence in terms of providing pressure on the passer and we were given the opportunity to rush. This is a young guy with some talent and we expect him to continue to get better. (What has Emmanuel Sanders done to earn more playing time?) He's made plays when given an opportunity.  He continues to prove that it is not too big for him.  More than anything though, when he makes a mistake, he doesn't go in the tank, and he usually rebounds from it relatively quickly.  He put a ball on the ground in Miami and rebounded from it relatively quickly.  He dropped the third down on the first ball that was thrown at him on Sunday down the field, thought he had the opportunity to make that play, but he quickly rebounded.  So not only is it not too big for him, he doesn't shadow box, he doesn't ride the emotional roller coaster, he tends to bounce back from failure pretty quickly.  All of those things are attractive that go along with the talent, of course which we all see. (Re: Rashard Mendehall's performance:) I thought Rashard played really well.  I thought we left about 40 or 50 of his yards out there in the form of penalties.  So I thought he played well.  The stat sheet is not going to show the quality of his play in that game, but such is life. We are in a team game and sometimes that happens.  But he gave us a winning performance. (Re: Offensive line:) These guys, I like their mentality in regards to it. Thankfully we have not dipped below five in any games, well maybe, but we didn't have the ball when we did.  They don't bat an eye and they don't have reason to.  We have a bunch of guys that are capable of playing winning football, that are ready to do that.  All of those guys have played. The only offensive lineman on our active roster that hasn't played is Chris Scott.  Everyone else has played and contributed to wins so we expect those guys to be ready when called upon.  I know that they are.  I know that a guy like Trai Essex is ready to respond when given an opportunity.  He came in and played some left tackle and some left guard in the football game.  These guys are willing to do whatever I think to help us win and that is what is required. (How do you get past all of the penalties?) We are not going to worry about the number of penalties or what was called.  I still believe the core of the statement I made following the game.  We are not going to get overly concerned about the penalties or the nature or the state of the NFL in terms of how things are being officiated.  All we are going to simply do is play the game extremely hard, play it is as fairly as we can, play within the rules and play to win.  Those are the things that are at the forefront of my mentality.  Those are the things that I want at the forefront of the team's mentality.  Those are the things that we can control. So we are going to stay with it there.  Penalties are going to get thrown every now and then, some of the times it is going to be our fault, believe it or not, but we are going to move on and continue to play. (Do you feel your players showed restraint when your quarterback was sucker punched?) Your words, not mine.  No, emotions are going to get away from you when something like that occurs in the football game. You hope something like that never occurs in a football game but it did.  For the most part I think our guys were able to gather themselves quickly after that sequence of events was over and get back to what we intended to do, which was playing winning football.  But their response, their emotional response, is understandable. (Do you need a new nickname for Mike Wallace?) Not yet. He's going to have to show me more than that play on Sunday. (Re: Wallace suggesting the nickname, "Bag of tricks.") He's got a lot of suggestions. I suggest that he prepare for the Buffalo Bills. (Re: Team responding to Ben being punched:) That's what a team is about. Am I shocked the way they responded, no. Am I excited the way they responded? I expect them to be good teammates. That's a part of being good teammates. They're going to protect one another particularly when they think someone has been wronged. That's just human nature. These guys work extremely hard together. They are close personally and professionally. So should we be surprised at the type of response that occurred in the stadium on Sunday? It's very natural. I am glad that both teams were able to move on from it and continued to play a football game. (Re: Chris Scott dressing:) We'll see, probably about 90 minutes before kickoff. (Is the offensive line that banged up?) I think we will be fine. I think we'll base those judgments on the availability over the course of the work week. (Any changes to the Thanksgiving schedule?) Oh, it is Thanksgiving. We got a little business. We're going to handle our business then we'll have time to eat and be thankful.

Good afternoon. I'll start with a little bit of personnel news. We let Jeff Reed go here today. Jeff has had a distinguished career here. He's had a lot of individual success and contributed to our success as a team. But at this juncture, we thought it was appropriate for us to make a change on our football team at that position. We worked out Shaun Suisham. He's a Bowling Green man. He's an NFL experience guy. He's kicked the last several years in Washington D.C. He finished last year with the Dallas Cowboys. He worked out today over at the stadium. He had a productive workout. He had a solid level of comfort with what he's capable of. His background is attractive to us. He's kicked at Bowling Green. He's from Canada originally. He's no stranger to the elements, which are things that are critical components for kicking for us. So we'll move forward with that change. Those changes never come easy. It's a unique situation at times when you're making those kinds of changes. Obviously we deemed it necessary in terms of moving forward. I just wanted to make that announcement. Also moving forward are our challenges this week, coming off Sunday's performance. It was not a good one. We were beaten soundly by a good football team, similar to how they were beaten by Cleveland a week prior to that. Hopefully we respond the way that they did. I know that's going to be our intentions here as we evaluate, make adjustments and prepare for the Oakland Raiders coming in here. We played them a year ago here at Heinz Field. We'll get another opportunity at them this week. You are talking about a team that's as hot as any team in football. They are a 5-4 football team. They are stacked with talent as the Raiders always are. They are a big and fast outfit, 13 or 14 former first-round picks on their team. Specifically, let's talk about them and look at them a little bit. Offensively their signal caller right now is Jason Campbell. He's produced three straight wins for them. He's making great decisions. We're familiar with him. He's got a great long ball, makes good decisions, a good above-the-neck veteran quarterback. He's distributing balls to a variety of people, Louis Murphy who made some critical plays up here against us a year ago is a leader of that receiver group, Darrius Heyward-Bey and a young rookie in Jacoby Ford from Clemson had a big game there the other week. Their tight end, Zach Miller, from Arizona State is as good of a complete tight end you're going to find in football. This guy is capable of doing it all, similar to our [Heath] Miller. He's good on the line of scrimmage, good at blocking. They move him. He's a vertical threat. He can create space on short routes. He's a good football player. I know he missed their last game.
