I am sure they anticipate getting him back coming off of a bye week. Their running backs, they got a stable of running backs led by Darren McFadden, who is having as good as a year as anyone. He's running some wildcat football. He is the original wildcat, going back to his days in Fayetteville, Arkansas in college football. He's accompanied by Michael Bush, a Louisville man. He's a power runner, a big man. Their fullback, Marcel Reese, is multi-faceted. He's capable of catching screens and going the distance. He runs some routes out of the backfield, slants and slant-and-go's. He really has a unique skill set for a fullback and they utilize his skills very well. Offensively they pound you with the run. They throw the ball vertically. They have a myriad of tricks, reverses and flea-flickers. They're similar to what they've been in the recent past. They have a great deal of success with it. Their record indicates that, especially their recent record, winning the last three games. Defensively they really have been impressive here of late. You start up front when you're talking about 4-3 defenses and you start with Richard Seymour. This guy is having an all-pro caliber year. They move him around. They put him on a variety of people. He can play inside; he can play outside. He's a big power player who happens to be extremely athletic. He's accompanied up front by Tommy Kelly, who is very disruptive and having a quality year. A young second-rounder that they have, Lamarr Houston, out of Texas, is playing end for them. They get a lot of production out of that young man. Their first-rounder at the linebacker level, Rolando McClain out of Alabama, does some great things for them. You know their secondary is equipped with big, fast men that can run. Michael Huff and Tyvon Branch at safety do some nice work. They got a myriad of sub-package football players that allow them to cover just about whatever personnel group you put out there. They make some critical splash plays on special teams. It really broke open the San Diego game for them with some of the plays that they made on special teams. They had a kickoff return in the second half versus Kansas City that got them back in the football game. That really set the table for a dramatic victory that they had. They're playing really good football. They went through Seattle relatively easy and Denver. It's well documented. This is the kind of opponent we need, coming off our last performance. We got to get back into the world of the competent and the competing. This is a great opportunity for us, one that I'm sure our guys will be excited about taking advantage of. When we looked our tape yesterday, we started with just being accountable to what we looked at and what we put out there, players and coaches. It was below the line, and New England took advantage of it like they should, like good teams are capable of doing. I am hoping we will learn from it. We're not going to dwell on it. We are going to learn from it. We're going to make our corrections and move forward, and get ready for this next opportunity, acknowledging what we've got out there. That being said, looking at some injuries and things in preparation for this week. Will Allen is still a question mark. I didn't speak to you guys in great detail. Saturday morning he got up and still had a headache or two from his concussion from the other week. Of course we didn't play him. We needed further testing there to make sure he's okay before we proceeded. Crezdon Butler had a quad strain in the game. He can be characterized as questionable. Brett Keisel is still working on his hamstring. We'll see where he is later in the week. Chris Kemoeatu has an ankle sprain. We're going to get him going here, and hopefully he's going to be available to us. Lawrence Timmons has a hip contusion. It may limit him in the early portion of the week. We expect him to come back. Troy Polamalu has a right Achilles strain. We're probably going to slow him down for the early portions of the week just like Heath Miller last week, with an eye towards practicing at the latter part of the week, and being able to play. We expect him to be able to play. Aaron Smith is a week closer. I thought you guys might like that. And the rest is the normal bumps and bruises that come with going into Week 11 of the football season.  (Was there or is there a final straw with Jeff Reed?) It's more of accumulation with where we are. This guy has had a great deal of success; it's not a decision that comes easy. The kicking position is one that merits a special consideration. It is unlike other positions where you can simply bench someone and go to their backup. There's one only kicker on a football team, so you don't take these decisions lightly when you have to make a move again. We are very respectful to the work that Jeff has done here, but at this time we thought it was appropriate we made a change. Sean Suisham was available. We worked him out, we like his resume and how he performed here today. He's experienced of course being here before. I think he was at camp here in 2005.  He is a veteran guy, no stranger to NFL competition. So we are extremely comfortable with the change and moving forward.  (Did anything Jeff Reed said or did off the field play into your decision? ) No, again we just looked at the cumulative of the body of work, where we are and how we move forward. We felt like at this time it justified a change.  (Did Jeff Reed slip on his miss Sunday?) I don't know that. (How tough was that conversation with Jeff Reed? ) It's extremely tough, but I'm not going to complain about that. You guys know, that's not my style. It comes with this position. I have to embrace the unpleasant things that come with this position like I embrace the pleasant things. I don't shy away from it by any stretch. It's apart of this business, one that I acknowledge. (Was Jeff Reed surprised by this decision at all?) I'm not going to put words into Jeff Reed's mouth in terms of the level of surprise or disappointment. It's not an easy conversation, but we did have it. (Do you expect Hines Ward available for this weekend? ) I expect Hines Ward to be available for this upcoming game. Of course there is an adjustment process that you go through from an offensive unit standpoint when you lose as guy like Hines Ward during the course of a football game. We ask him to do a lot of unique things, but the guys that took his place are capable men to do the job.  Injuries are a part of this game, as much as a part of this game as blocking and tackling. We embrace the challenges that the game of football presents, including injury.  (Is Shaun Suisham the only kicker you worked out?) Yes.  (Re: Shaun Suisham, is he a kickoff guy as well? ) Yes, and did a nice job of it. (Was Hines ever diagnosed with a concussion? ) He was diagnosed with a concussion, and he cleared the post concussion test. We will continue to be couscous as we move forward. We've seen things change courses, as we seen last week with Will Allen. He had sustained a concussion a few weeks ago and cleared. As the week wore on, he had experienced a headache Saturday morning. We acted appropriately, as we will do. (Is there a strict rule, or is it up to the doctors to approve a player's return to the field? ) I think we are all pretty familiar with the climate of the NFL in regards to concussions. With a competitor such as Hines Ward, you respect the want that he has. He was able to pass a test at the stadium, but sometimes you have to protect the extreme competitor from themselves, and Hines Ward is that. We love and respect that. It's a part of what makes him who he is, but we had to act in his best interest on Sunday night.  (Was Jeff Reed release about his mental mistakes?) I don't delve too deep into the mental state and things of that nature. This is a mental game. I am more of a result oriented guy, and that's what leads us to decisions.  (Do players take a concussion test every day leading up to the next game?) As many times as necessary. If they pass the test then we move on unless they experience some other symptoms. If they don't pass the test, then of course we will administer it.  Sometimes we even continue to administer it once they pass the test just to be on the safe. I think that is the appropriate thing to do, given the recent new information of head injuries.  (Do drops mean a lack of focus?) No, it indicates that we are not catching the football.  When you catch them you are concentrating and when you don't you're not.  I am a result oriented guy so I look at it from that perspective more than anything else. (Re: Jason Campbell) This is a guy that has been in a bunch of schemes of course, particularly in Washington.  We're not delving too much into past experiences against him particularly in another city.  We are really taking a look at the body of work that he has put together with his cast of characters that he is working with in Oakland in that system.  They are doing a nice job. They are controlling the line of scrimmage with their big people up front, (Robert) Gallery and so forth.  They are running the football extremely well, they execute play passes off of it.  They are stretching the field vertically, you know he has a big league arm and he has been in a lot of battles.  He is a savvy veteran guy and I am sure he won't be overwhelmed by Heinz Field and the guys in black and gold.  But that's ok, we have to go out and play the game, as does he. (Do you anticipate any changes at cornerback?) No, not at all. (What do they have to do to be better?) Our pass defense is a culmination of a lot of people.  Not only corners but safeties and linebackers and so forth and rush.  A lot of the things that went on with that game, many of them were underneath throws that aren't directly involving cornerback play.  We all accept responsibility for our inability to consistently stop the New England Patriots.  Coaches, players and everyone.  Not only the cornerback position. (How did your lineman on the left do and will they stay there?) They will.  Of course we anticipate having Chris (Kemoeatu) back, so if he is back so if he is available he will play.  I thought those guys did a serviceable job, but of course I am a result oriented guy.  It wasn't enough.  Same could be said for my performance. (So the job is still Jonathan Scott's?) Yes. (Re: Concerns about health is partly the responsibility of the player for reporting injuries:) Certainly. (Concerned that a competitive player such as Hines would not tell you that he was hurt?) Again, the baseline barometer for moving forward is the passing of a battery of post concussion tests.  I am not doctor by any stretch.  I respect those guys and the expertise that they bring to the table.  Obviously we're going to lean to their expertise and understanding in this area. (Re: Tom Brady had a lot of time to throw:) There were points in the game when he had a lot of time to throw and there were also points in the game when we were rushing three.  The vast majority of the game I thought he was making quick decisions and getting the ball out of his hands on a myriad of short routes and underneath throws where rush is a less of a factor.  So I wouldn't point to that as the central reason we were unable to slow those guys down.  It really was a complete body of work or a sufficient performance by them and lack of by us. (Re: Concern when Hines lost balance coming off of field:) I don't know that.  I think more than anything it was the fact that he sustained a concussion during the football game. (Re: New England defense:) They have a time tested body of work. That core group of guys has been together for a number of years.  So to say that we saw something that we hadn't seen before would be a stretch.  Their personality changes from week to week but it is still them.  They did what it is that they do and they did it extremely well.  They did what they do better than we did what we do.  And that is why they were successful. (Any correlation between what Brady did and what (Drew) Brees did in New Orleans?) No, really not.  They are two different schematic systems and two different guys in terms of what they bring to the table.  Drew is a movement guy, play action pass guy, changing the launch point, whether it is roll out or resetting the pocket behind tackles.  His effectiveness is based on his mobility and the way that he moves.  Of course Tom's strengths are in his decision making and making quick decisions of getting the ball out of his hands. (Re: Defense being able to get at Ben:) We got behind in the football game and when you get behind of course you've got to take some shots.  They probably benefited from that some.  Your personality changes some given game circumstances and I acknowledge that, but I also acknowledge that they did a nice job of getting after the passer. (Out of character for Oakland to copy some of the things that New England did?) Again I am not going to try to anticipate what it is they are going to do in terms of their decision making or how they match up against us.  They are a team that is coming off of a bye week.  I am sure they put together a portion of their plan prior to us even playing New England.  I would imagine that a team that is hot and has won their last three games is going to continue to do what they have done.  But I am also going to acknowledge that we've got some unflattering tape out there that might be a window into how to attack us on Sunday, if they are looking.  We will see on Sunday I guess. (Are they at all similar from last year that you can gain some things from the tape?) No, they are very similar of course other than the quarterback position.  The tight end (Zach) Miller played against us last year, Louis Murphy had a big football game, (Justin) Fargas was their feature runner but we saw some of the others.  They are going to play regular football, they are going to run it, they are going to try to stretch the field vertically and have a myriad of tricks.  Reverses and flea flickers and such, that has been their personality in recent years and I don't see why it would change this week given the amount of success they have had playing Raider football.

Good afternoon. It was a tough, hard-fought victory for us last night in Cincinnati. Like I said last night, I'd like to reiterate that it's good to go on the road in the AFC North and get a victory. We were far from perfect, but such is life. We're 6-2 here at the turn, and we got a short week. We got a scolded New England team to get ready for. Needless to say we got a lot on our plate. Kind of a brief synopsis of the injury report as we sit here right now, Will Allen sustained a concussion in the game. He'll have post-concussion tests. He may be limited at the early portion of the week, but we'll see how those tests go. They always dictate his availability. Brett Keisel is still working through his hamstring strain. He was really quite unable to get it going last night. We expect this guy to continue to work and see where he is this week. Chris Kemoeatu has a knee sprain. He will be limited the first part of the week and we'll see if we can get him going, get him enough snaps in preparation to be available for us. Heath Miller has a little fluid on his knee. That may limit him tomorrow. Mewelde Moore has a concussion, similar situation as Will Allen. Maurkice Pouncey is going to be fine with a tibia bruise. He came back into the game and finished. Isaac Redman also has a concussion. Max Starks experienced some stingers. We will see where he is. We got somewhat of a laundry list, and we're working off of a short week. It's important that we prepare smart in regards to working around and with some of these injuries. I am sure many of these guys will be available for the contest, but they have limited preparation. The standard is the standard. We are very smart with these guys, even look at potentially ulterior modes of preparation to make sure enough of these men get sufficient looks at what's necessary for us to play. It's a good football team in New England. They're 6-2. It starts with their quarterback, Tom Brady, who can really spread the ball around to a bunch of people. They're capable of working exclusively out of a no-huddle offense or huddling if they chose. I think last week they exclusively worked out of no huddle. He spreads the ball around to a bunch of people. They got Deion Branch back from Seattle. He's a legitimate threat. Brandon Tate is another guy. Wes Welker is the best in the business inside. I think that's well documented. We're going to have our hands full there. Guys like William Gay and others are going to try to slow him down, particularly on possession downs. Some of the things they do with him are run game alternatives. We got to be good against this guy because he's one of the best. They have a unique tight end situation. They really have some quality guys there. Aaron Hernandez, a Florida man, is playing beyond his years. He's a rookie; he's very productive. I think he's number two to Welker on the team in receptions. They utilize this guy's unique skill set in a lot of ways. We went down there and looked at their pro day. We were looking at Maurkice Pouncey and really came away impressed with this guy's skill set and what he's capable of doing in terms of route running and catching the football. He's proven that to be true on NFL tape. Rob Gronkowski is another tight tend that they give the ball to. They got a stable of backs, and they utilize them all. One noteworthy guy I think is Danny Woodhead, who has kind of taken the role of Kevin Faulk in terms of being a dual-threat guy, third-down kind of a back, matchup issues and problems out of the backfield, draw-runner and so forth. I really like the spark that he's providing them in the games that we've studied thus far. Defensively they are a very young unit. I am sure there is a great cause for optimism when you take that approach, seeing the guys that they have contributing play. Stabilizing veteran presence up front is Vince Wilfork. He not only plays nose tackle, but you see him quite a bit now at defensive end. He's playing quality football for them. At the linebacker position they've got a nucleus of impressive young guys led by Jared Mayo inside, along with Brandon Spikes, a rookie from Florida, who we are really familiar with. He did some good things at Florida and was impressive in his pro day. Jermaine Cunningham, another Florida man, is playing outside. He made the transition from defensive end to outside linebacker. We too were interested in him as an outside linebacker candidate. He appears to be very comfortable in that role. He's making plays for them. In the secondary I really like their collection of safeties. Brandon Merriweather and Patrick Chung are really good. James Sanders comes in sub-package football. He's starter capable. He's started for them in the past. That crew of safeties is as deep and solid as you'll find. The rookie cornerback, Devin McCourty, is really playing some good football for him. He's a Rutgers' man, a mature, savvy player for his age. We held him in high regard in draft preparations as well. This guy at the NFL stage isn't too big for him. Coach Belichick and company, they'll always be prepared. They'll put together a good, schematic plan. They'll come in here ready to play, particularly so after I'm sure last week's performance. They'll be excited about getting out and playing again, as will we. We recognize that this is a big game for us. It's great to be back at home in front of our fans. Boy the road has been tough, but that's what the road is. We pushed through that stretch, not ideally, but we'll take it and we'll be back at home this weekend in front of Steeler nation. (More opportunity for Jonathan Dwyer with Mewelde Moore and Isaac Redman down?) If they are down that might mean more opportunities of course.  We take these post-concussion symptoms very seriously, but we are not going to worry about those things until it is evident.  Those guys will go through the normal procedure, post concussion tests and if they are available to play they will play.  If not, then we will look at options. (Re: Bringing pressure:) I thought the pressure was good for the better part of the night.  With a guy like Carson (Palmer) he can dictate whether he gets hit or not and those type of things.  He was getting the ball out of his hand early, so the pressure was sufficient early in the football game.  Of course, later in the football game when he had to start driving the football down the field a little bit, he wasn't as in control of whether or not he got hit.  Because of that we were able to hit him some, get to him some and the positive things that come with that.  But I like our pressure for the better part of the night.  With a savvy guy and a quick decision maker such as Carson, you are not going to get to him at the early portion of the football games, quite frankly, unless he wants you to. (Re: New England becoming more of an offensive oriented team:) Well for the better part of the time period that you mentioned, I was an NFC coach so I was less concerned about what made them spectacular, to be honest with you.  Since I have been here, they have Tom Brady, so they are always going to be among the elite. (Re: New England's young players having trouble picking up New England defense) They are 6-2.  I think that speaks to a pretty good defense.  When you are ahead like they are, I am sure that, as they are, when you are 6-2 people are going to get yards and move up and down the field, but doing what's necessary to keep the out of the end zone, I have always been impressed with Belichick's group in terms of situational football, third-down, redzone, short-yardage and things of that nature.  Points are a true measure of a defense and ultimately the record is a true measure of a team. (What did Cleveland do so well against New England?) I don't know why everyone is surprised that Cleveland plays well.  They have a back that will hurt you really bad, they are always good schematically, defensively with their packages and the way they are capable of getting after you.  And if they complete manageable third downs, they have a good chance to beat you.  That is what the tape showed quite frankly, not only in the instance of New Orleans but also in the instance of New England. (When you took the lead early in the fourth quarter 27-7, did you feel the air leave a little?) No, I sensed us making some errors and that's always I guess the case.  I thought the turnover when they got the short-field was big.  They capitalized and made plays, we didn't make enough plays and it made the game extremely interesting. (Are you concerned with letting the big lead go in the fourth quarter?) I'm not.  I am more concerned about preparing for New England.  That's just where I am on a short week like this because you really just quickly put an eye on what happened and transpired and how it might affect what occurs moving forward.  That's my mentality right now, just preparation for New England and how last night's game might dictate schematic approaches and so forth. (Re: that game against Cincinnati last year was the one that began the slide:) That week three game began the slide?  We were 6-2 at the turn.  Next. (Are you gratified when it game time to run the ball, even thought you didn't get the result you wanted with the missed field goal, but that this is what you were looking?) It was exciting to see and particularly under the circumstances I was really concerned. Of course we had one back left and five offensive lineman.  We were able to chew the clock up, they made the necessary first downs and moved the ball down the field.  Unfortunately we weren't able to get the field goal, you like to let that be a signature of how you finish the game, of course that wasn't the case because we didn't hit the field goal and our defense had to go out there and make a play or two, but I like the mentality of the group.  I like the way the seized that moment and really I thought had an opportunity to seize control of the game, finish it off in a manner in which you like as a coach.  It just didn't unfold that way. (Did last night change your philosophy dressing seven offensive lineman instead of eight?) No, we are always going to try to insulate ourselves with what we deem necessary.  Last night we dressed six defensive lineman because of the status of Brett Keisel and that proved to be an issue and we are glad that we did in that regard.  We will take a look at our issues this week and kind of see where that leads us.  Obviously the offensive line is a concern. (Re: Execution at the end of games:) You've got to be able to grind it out, you have to be good in the kicking game, have to be able to change field position, a lot of the things that we didn't do. We turned the ball over in short field, we were highly penalized in the fourth quarter, there are a lot of reasons to look at and point to how we can be better, how we need to be better.  You are not going to beat the New England Patriots like that in the fourth quarter.  We know and understand that. (Re: Terrell Owens) He is playing really good football for those guys.  He has done a nice job.  We try to deny  those guys as much as we can.  Quite frankly I think they moved him a around a little but more that what maybe we were prepared for.  They got him in the slot some, I know that first touchdown, he was inside.  He is a veteran player with an impressive resume and he added to is last night. (Do you pick your poison with Terrell Owens and Chad Ochocinco in regards to trying to take one of them out of the game?) It felt like it would be easier to get Ochocinco out of the game because he was the single receiver side guy.  He had some route combination issues when you are talking about Terrell, and that has probably been the case with most people that have played him.  It is easier to get that single receiver wideout out of the game than it is the combination route runner.  Terrell has hurt a lot of people, Chad has hurt a lot of people.  They have a really good group.  It was somewhat pick your poison but we were also concerned about letting Cedric Benson get rolling as well.  They've got a lot of offensive weapons.  It is evident at how they were able to get that thing going at the latter part of the game and we have a great deal of respect for them  (How concerned are you with the number of injuries with a short week?) I am, but I am more concerned about the readiness of the able body guys, the guys that will ultimately play for us.  We've got a group of men that we believe are capable if prepared.  They have to prepare as if they are going to get the opportunity.  We will see how some of these injuries sort out at the later part of the week.  The only time that injuries are really a major factor are the in-game injuries because then you are dealing with 39 versus 46 when you are talking about suited and so forth.  During the course of a preparation work week, we have the opportunity to get the healthy guys prepared and we are not going to make excuses about the injuries, or who is available or whos not.  We believe to the core that we will go out and play with 46 guys that are capable to playing winning football and meet our standards. (Update on Aaron Smith?) No, what did I say last week?  It is a little less extended right now.  We are going to kind of keep our head down and be hopeful and really evaluate him in the next couple of weeks and then there will probably a significant update in some form or fashion.  Right now he is just doing what the doctors suggest and really we are just focused on the guys that are healthy, with a potential eye maybe to the return to the big man. (Considering the rushing output, can we assume Ziggy Hood has a pretty good night?) He did, but as did Nick Eason and Casey Hampton and as did others.  That is an 11 man job when you talk about shutting down the run as we have been able to.  Corners support it and so forth.  Really been impressed with how we have been able to handle ourselves in that area. (Re: Gaining life based off of sequence at the end of the half and taking advantage of those moments:) If you have opportunity of course to put points on the board you want to desire to do so. We've had a couple two minute situations at the end of the half in recent weeks where we hadn't taken advantage of it and given opportunities to our opponents.  There is always a calculated risk involved, particularly when you are talking about attempting a 50-something yard field goal, if you miss it, it provides field position for your opponent, but we had a good weather situation, felt comfortable and wanted to give Jeff the opportunity to bang that kick and he did.  Your ability to finish halves in games and really start halves in games is critical.  It kind of sets the tone if you will.  You can steal points.  People equate it to boxing as in stealing a round if you make a significant play or two and change field position and put points on the bard. It is our desire to do that but more than anything we were just playing the cards as they were dealt to us last night in Cincinnati. (id you have that feeling of "Here we go again," when the lead began slipping away last night?) No. (Re: Running out the clock versus taking the risk of throwing on third-downs in the fourth quarter:) There is a general school of thought, but usually it's pretty straight forward and common sense in that instance. We had run the ball pretty comfortably down the field. What we deemed was a manageable third-down situation in field goal range. That play was pretty close to coming out the other side. Whoever that defender was did a nice job dipping under Doug Legursky and making the tackle. That's just finishing football. That's fourth quarter football. We came up a little short in that instance. (Re: Dramatic improvement in special teams:) It's probably a combination of all parties involved. I liked the energy and know-how that Al Everest has brought to the table. I also like the contributions of some of the men we've added. Arnaz Battle has done a nice job in a lot of phases. William Gay has been a constant special teams' core guy for us. Young guys like Stevenson Sylvester and Jason Worilds have anteed-up and kicked in. Emmanuel Sanders put his hat on the ball and caused a fumble on the opening kickoff. It's really probably equally contributed to schematics and players. (Re: Cincinnati's special teams' miscues:) I am a little less concerned about their issues. I am probably more concerned about our play and I am glad we were able to make the significant plays.

Good afternoon. It's a big week for us here on the South Side. We're coming off a disappointing performance in New Orleans, and we're in preparation for a great opportunity in Monday night in Cincinnati. We've been studying these guys quite a bit and looking at our issues as well as we prepare for this football game. We got a lot of work to do. They're a good football team. From our perspective this is why; they swept the division a year ago. Their core players are still the same. They've added to that mix. Their coaching staff is in place. They've got great familiarity with us. They've already proven this year that they are AFC North ready. They beat Baltimore at their place in Week 2. All of those are things that we're focused on. The reason why is that it's a great opportunity and a big challenge for us. I know what their record is. They've been in some close games. They lost to Cleveland by three; they lost to Tampa Bay by three. They had control of that Tampa game, but it got away from them late. We realize sometimes games play themselves out like that. We're not going to read too much into their 2-5 record. We recognize what they're capable of. And that's getting after us. We got video evidence to prove that. They did it twice a year ago. So we're going to get prepared with those things in mind. Offensively they've got some usual suspects. I'm not going to waste your time talking about what Carson Palmer, Cedric Benson and Chad Ochocinco are capable of. We know that they've added Terrell Owens. No need to talk about in great detail what he is capable of. He's got Canton-like career numbers. He's providing big time plays for him this year. Probably the most interesting thing about them offensively is their awesome contribution that they are getting from their two young players, their rookies. The tight end Jermaine Gresham is doing a nice job. They're asking him to do a myriad of things. He's in the backfield. He's a move guy. He's on the line of scrimmage; he's a vertical route runner. He's a very talented guy and is playing extremely well for them. Jordan Shipley is playing really good football for them as a third wide receiver in the slot. He's got over 20, somewhere around 22 catches. He's playing like a savvy veteran. Those two young guys' contributions are big contributions that they're getting offensively. Those are the guys that we're trying to familiarize ourselves with as we're trying to prepare for this game. Defensively they're a very talented group, and they're coached by Mike Zimmer and company. Up front we've had issues in the past with Tank Johnson and (Domata) Peko. They're still very disruptive people inside. I like their edge rush men, their situational rush men. They're getting quality play out of the rookie Carlos Dunlap, and the young man, Michael Johnson, out of Georgia Tech. Those are two formidable guys from an edge-pressure standpoint. They're going to provide big time challenges for our tackles and the people that we choose to assist our tackles in the passing game. Their linebacker core is a good group, led by Dhani Jones and his two cohorts from Southern Cal. They do a nice job, but I think it's also important to recognize Brandon Johnson when you're talking about their linebacker core. He plays in all sub-package football. He's a big, long and rangy guy. He covers a lot of ground; he's good at blitzing. He's got long arms. You see him touch a lot of passes. He is somebody to be recognized and dealt with as well. Their corner tandem, we talked about those guys a year ago. We thought they were on the cutting edge of being breakout guys. I think the league knows that now. I am sure from their perspective that they expected that because they are high-round picks. They are what they are. Those guys are playing really well. They challenge throws. They can play on the line of scrimmage. They can play off the line of scrimmage. They're equally as good in man and zone. They play some cover two, Tampa two. Those guys are great at rerouting. They're both consistent and physical tacklers. We got to deal with those guys. They got a veteran group of safeties, guys that have played, and they added Reggie Nelson from Jacksonville to that group. From a health standpoint we are a relatively healthy group. Isaac Redman had an ankle sprain in the game. He did come back in the game and finish it as did Flozell Adams. Those guys might be limited somewhat here initially. I don't know that at the early part of the week, but it should not be an issue because they came back in the game. Other than the known issues, Aaron Smith and so forth, we're a relatively healthy group, which is good. This is a big week for us. We're back in AFC North action, and more importantly than that, AFC North road action. If you're going to be a dominant team, which is what we desire to be in our division, you have to be able to go into other people's places and play winning football. And it's a tough thing to do. It's easy to say and tough to do. But we're going to take the approach of saying very little and getting about the business of preparing to do the job. (Do you expect Brett Keisel to be back?) His work here is going to dictate his availability and the amount of his availability. We anticipate him getting some work and go from there, but we're extremely hopeful of him being back in the mix. (Re: Aaron Smith's return and Ziggy Hood's performance:) Again it is an extended period of time, a number of weeks with Aaron Smith. We know the quality of player and person that he is. We're going to be hopeful when there's hope, and there is. Aaron is of the same mentality. So that's going well. Once we get down this road a number of weeks we'll be able to evaluate recovery and progress to be able to nail down a range. At this point it's safe to say he'll be out an extended period of time. I thought Ziggy played well in the game as did Nick Eason. They did a nice job. He was in his gap. He made the necessary plays when they were presented to him. I've been pleased with his performance. And really, it needs to continue and move upward as we proceed.  (Re: Ziggy saying he needs to grow up:) He's talking about the natural maturation process that young guys go through. This is not a patient man's business. He's not a patient young man. I like that about him. But his progress is going to be measured in snaps and snap opportunities. And for him and for me, it can't come quick enough. (Do you have concerns about your pass defense?) I do, but for the sole purpose of winning. We recognize that Drew Brees is a talented quarterback. He has a variety of weapons to use. We talked about that in great detail a week ago in here. He made some great plays in that football game, particularly in the second half. I liked what we were able to do against him in the first half. But he settled down as did his group, and he got going. He made some plays. That's part of losing and the reasons why you lose. That's not our intentions when we step into the stadiums, but we didn't get the job done. We tip our hat to Drew and company but we also acknowledge that we've got some work to do. (What's the process you go through in regards to challenging plays?) If I see it on the field and I think it's a challengeable play, I'll challenge it. If I get information from upstairs, where we think it's a challengeable play, we will. If we don't, we generally rely on the players that are on the field. I've been here long enough where I know when I am going to get legitimate information or emotional information. That's our general process. In the first instance you talked about, we thought it was a challengeable play. Obviously we were wrong. And that instance had no bearing on whether or not we challenged the second play. Quite frankly on the second play, of course since the game I found out it was a potentially challengeable play. We didn't deem it to be one in the instance in which it occurred. There wasn't a bunch of video evidence available to us, and the guys on the field didn't seem to think it was a challengeable play, so we didn't. We're not going to make that as an excuse. We had more than that opportunity to get that ball in the end zone down there. And we take responsibility for our inability to do that. And we're not going to let a judgment on the field be a crutch for us in that particular instance. We've got to score touchdowns when we have the ball down there. I'm less concerned about that element of the play or the fact that we challenged it or didn't challenge it. I just want to see a score when we're in those situations.  (Do your coaches have enough time upstairs to call down to say challenge or don't challenge?) Generally we do, but of course when you are on the road in different environments and different setups and different sources of information, it takes a period of time to get adjusted to that. Of course our familiar places that we travel to such as division games you are more familiar with the setup and how to combat it.  But it is just a natural process that everyone in the league goes through and issues that everyone has. (Is it possible they were showing scoreboard footage and not the NBC feed in the coaches' booth?) Yes.  It is possible. (What was it in the (Rashard) Mendenhall play that was not challengeable?) We didn't think he crossed the plain and he didn't either, so we didn't challenge it. (Fair process when you are relying on someone else to post a replay?) It's extremely fair because eight games a year probably weighs in our favor and eight games a year it probably doesn't, everybody has the same issues there.  Those guys have tough jobs, I respect the work that they do. (Should all replays that a referee sees be available to a person on your staff?) I like the process that we have right now.  I think it is a good one.  Time is of the essence when you start to talk about some of the possibilities that you are suggesting.  I don't think the process is broken in any way.  Maybe we lose an opportunity there but that's not the reason we lost the football game and we are not going to turn it into that.  We had more than that opportunity to score a touchdown in that instance.  That's what I think about when I think about that sequence of plays and not a missed opportunity to potentially challenge a call. (Were your third-down situations a problem with execution or recognition and reacting to what New Orleans was doing?) Probably both.  I like to preface that by saying it was probably in the early portions of the game.  I think we settled down as the game went on, but quite frankly not soon enough.  I thought that they had similar issues early in the game.  I thought that it was an excitable, hostile environment and I thought that it was an environment dominated by both defenses early.  Drew Brees and company got going quicker than we did in the second half of that game.  So it put us behind the eight ball and made the margin for error very slim. (How does Cincinnati rate on the noise meter?) It's a hostile environment.  We expect it to be Monday night. (Did (Drew) Brees do anything different with the pass in respect to (Troy) Polamalu and any concern with it being in tape?) No, when you are talking about two perennial all pro type players, there is always a little cat and mouse, little mental warfare if you will.  That's part of the game, within the game.  I am sure that there is mutual respect between those two men.  Drew won and you have to tip your hat to that and I am sure Troy would be the first to do that. (How can you maintain consistency?) Win. (What was different in 2008 season?) We won. (Re: Harrison possibly fined by NFL for hit on Brees:) I don't know that he is going to be fined or that there has been any kind of discussion so I am not going to speculate on that.  I haven't received any information of that nature.  He was penalized on the play, we accept that and move on.  It wasn't the difference of the outcome of the game. (Re: Do you think if that happened then hypothetically:) I just don't want to play the hypothetical game.  If he does, then I will deal with it at that time and I think that is prudent approach to take. (Do you think Harrison might be targeted by the League?) No. (Did they show blitzes or anything that surprised you?) I don't think it was anything that we hadn't seen or anticipated or had rules to deal with, I just think that at the early portion of the game we didn't do a good job of dealing with it.  I don't think they did a good job of dealing with us.  I think that first half of that game was dominated by defenses.  I think that the half time score bears that out.  I think New Orleans got started a little quicker in the second half offensively than we did.  It put us behind the eight ball, it made the margin for error very slim and then when Heath (Miller) fumbled, of course that was an error that we couldn't afford because New Orleans got started quicker than us offensively in the second half of the game. (How much do you base decision on Jeff (Reed) from previous week?) I've got a high level of trust for Jeff.  I base my judgments on range from what happens in pregame.  He was pretty consistent in pregame and I acknowledge from time to time that you are going to miss 51-yard kicks. (Re:  The job Sean Kugler has done:) I think he has done a really good job, but then again we are not about patting ourselves on the back. We're just trying to win football games. We are not interested in evaluating our work, whether if it's a time period or a specific group within our unit. We are trying to win as a team. One of the most enjoyable things about this football team, the 2010 Steelers, is that we don't care about style points or who gets the job done. We're just trying to step into stadiums, win games and go home. Sean's a big part of that. (Re: Division play:) I think there are a lot of things to motivate both teams. There's a high degree of familiarity in competition between both teams. They pulled the boom out on the entire division, including us a year ago. They've already won versus Baltimore at their place this year. We know what we will get from them, which is good football, so we better be prepared for it.  (Are they spreading it out more this year? ) No, I think it's their personality, and their playing to it. I think they feed you a lot of Cedric Benson. They're 2 -5, and I think that dictates some of the things that occur, as opposed to last year. I'm just being honest. When you're winning you're going to feed Cedric Benson. When you're losing there are probably going to be more passes thrown. That's just football.  (Are you disappointed in the news that Thaddeus Gibson was picked up by San Francisco? ) I'm disappointed, but I realize that is a big part of our profession. We knew there was a strong possibility of him getting claimed by someone when we put him out there. When you're a 5 -1 team and you let a man go, some teams whose records aren't as good are going to assume yours is better than theirs. That's today's NFL.  (If you had to do it all over again, would to have taken that same risk in exposing Gibson? ) Absolutely, I had to.  This is a young man, whose third time he's been called upon has played good football.  It's not necessarily about the pure number of snaps that he played. It's more about his availability.  You don't want to go in short, particularly in a defensive line; it was a definitive necessary maneuver. If I had to, I'd do it again.  (Do you think McLendon has a long term future?) I think he has an upside of course, and that is why we are working with him and call on him when given the opportunity.  A lot of people when injured get in a position to go outside the organization for potential solutions. We like the men that we work with and we believe that if they prepare themselves, and if they are ready, we like to start there in terms of giving them opportunity's to answer the bell.  He has provided a nice platform for the other young men in how to prepare you, and put yourself into position to answer to bell. I think the work that he has done and is doing is creating opportunity for others.  (How did Trai Essex do at right guard?) He was solid and I think there is room for improvement. Of course he has not played in several weeks, as we expect him to improve as we move forward.  (Have you added a practice squad player?) We will. (Will it be a defensive lineman?) We are going to add a practice squad player.

Good afternoon. It's a big day here on the South Side and a big week for us. Challenges are what we seek and we are getting that this week in the form of the world champion New Orleans Saints. Not only that but at their place in prime time. Our team gets excited about these kinds of challenges; they embrace these kinds of challenges. But the attitude is not going to get what we need to get done. We've got some preparation in front of us, and ultimately we better play winning football. We're really excited about the opportunity; we take it as such to play the defending world champs at their place on prime time television. It's going to be an awesome atmosphere, one that's going to challenge us I'm sure. But one that I am thinking our team will really be enthused about and hopefully we'll put a winning performance together. Looking at these guys, they've got a great deal of talent. They're extremely well coached. They're opportunistic. They have all the characteristics of a world championship caliber team. It starts with Drew Brees at quarterback. This guy's completing 70 percent of his passes. He has over 2,000 yards throwing. He throws the ball around to a bunch of guys. I think that's probably the most disturbing thing as you look at them. They've got three to four wideouts that have more catches than Mike Wallace. They got two tight ends that got more catches than Heath Miller. They've got three running backs that got more catches than [Rashard] Mendenhall. You got to defend all the eligibles when you play these guys. They do a nice job of distributing the ball offensively. They appear to be very unselfish. It doesn't matter who the running backs are. [Chris] Ivory has over five yards per carry. He's over 300 yards for the season. Given the opportunity he's performed well for them. They do a nice job of protecting Drew. He's the number one quarterback in the NFL on third down. So needless to say we have our hands full with them offensively. Defensively they are led by [Defensive Coordinator] Greg Williams. They're very aggressive; they're very opportunistic. They create their opportunities. They apply pressure to you in different ways. They're capable of applying pressure with their down people, like most 4-3 teams. They've got quality people up front: Sedrick Ellis, Will Smith, Alex Brown, Anthony Hargrove comes in rotation. He's a tough guy from an interior standpoint to block in passing situations. But they also have a myriad of pressures that Coach Williams employs, and they execute at an extremely high level. They get you behind the chains because they are very aggressive in some of their run fronts. Then when you are behind the chains they are capable of getting after you. They do a nice job disguising their coverages and pressures particularly when they're in the dome at home. Silent counts are an issue. They're usually an advantage to a defense when you're using your foot to indicate snap counts. They break disguises based on the quarterback's foot. They're just a well-coached and opportunistic group. That being said we like to focus on the things that put us in position to play our best football. That's our preparation and ultimately our play. Along those lines we have some injury things to report. Flozell Adams appears to be doing well with his ankle injury. He might be limited somewhat here in the early portion of the week, but we expect this guy to make it. Brett Keisel is going to be limited in the early part of the week as is LaMarr Woodley. We're hopeful that those guys can play. We'll see where the week takes us. Aaron Smith had surgery yesterday on his torn triceps. It was partially torn. It was fixed. He's going to be out an extended period of time. At this juncture we intend to wait that out. Aaron is a quality player, a veteran leader for us. If there is hope for his return, then of course we are going to be hopeful as long as we possibly can. That is our mentality as we sit here today. The rest of the things are bumps and bruises that go along with playing. We better get over those pretty quickly. We're going into a rough-and-tumble situation here on Sunday night down in New Orleans. (Will you add a defensive end with Aaron Smith being out?) We will but chances are we will find those answers in house, like we always do. Steve McLendon has stepped up when given the opportunity. At other parts this season, position flexibility, some of the things we talk about continually, not only with Steve but with others. Chris Hoke has proven that he is capable of playing defensive end. We'll have a mix-and-match concept that will hopefully see us through. The guys just got to play football. (What's the best case scenario for Aaron's return?) It's going to be an extended number of weeks. Let's just see how it goes. (Re: Trai Essex and his return:) Trai was extremely close last week. He practiced partially most days last week. We were probably a little cautious with trying to put this thing definitely behind us. We were able to do that and we look forward to him practicing and participating in this football game. (Re: Adjusting to the left side if Brett Keisel returns:) More than anything right now is that we have Ziggy Hood and Nick Eason ready to play defensive end. And until we get further information we have to perceive with that mentality. Hopefully at the latter part of the week we will be able to ponder the possibility of Brett Keisel's participation. (If LaMarr Woodley cannot go, do you move Lawrence Timmons to the outside position and Larry Foote to the inside?) Larry Foote is a veteran backup. He has logged many man hours at the linebacker position. Lawrence Timmons is a talented guy that has the chance to affect the game regardless of where he plays. I'd probably be more inclined to slide Lawrence to the outside and play Foote inside. We might potentially play Jason Worilds some in passing situations just like he did last Sunday. (Re: Jason Worilds' play:) He made the significant play when we needed it. There is big-time room for growth when you're talking about a young man, detail of assignments and so forth. But along the way he better play winning football. And he delivered a timely play for us last week. We expect more of the same this week. (Re: Satisfied with pass defense:) We have been up on some people. Some people got one dimensional. We have been very strong against the run. I'm not overly concerned with stats. When people are behind and they can't run the football, they are going to through the football on you, and they're probably going to pick up yards. The thing that's most exciting is that we don't allow people to score touchdowns. We lead the league in scoring defense even in the red areas we make people kick field goals. To me that's a formula for winning defense. I'm less concerned about what stats may potentially tell us. We all know in many instances they lie. (Re: Difference between right and left outside linebacker position:) They're the same. One is on the left side of the ball; the other is on the right.  (Re: Ball security with Ben Roethlisberger:) I am always concerned about ball security with everyone. That's a formula for success as far as we are concerned. We are a 5-1 football team for a lot of different reasons, but probably just as important as any is our turnover ratio. I think we might be plus-eight or so on the season. So security of the ball is an issue for us regardless of who is handling it. To be as good as we can in that area, of course Ben tries to be as good as he can in that area. Ben is who he is, and we understand his playing personality. Ninety-nine percent of the cases we like it. (Re: Super Bowl Champions struggle to repeat:) A lot is written and said about the potential of that. I tend to look for hardcore evidence. They have experienced a number of injuries. Playing a month longer than most may have something to do with that, a shorter offseason and so forth. But those are their issues, not ours. We accept responsibility for our 2009 failures, and we know where those responsibilities lie. And that's with us. How they are addressing their season is up to them.  (Re: Cleveland being successful at New Orleans:) They probably weren't as familiar with the kind of damage that Shaun Rogers can do. I think that's probably the thing that jumped off the tape to me more than anything. We're very familiar with the kind of damage that Shaun Rogers can do, because unfortunately we see him twice a year. He was a disruptive force in that game. But you turn the ball over, you open yourselves up for games such as that, and that's what really happened in the game.  (Assuming Trai Essex is ready to go, does he got back into right guard?) We will see how the week unfolds form a preparation standpoint.  A lot of it has to do of course with his health. (What was going on with Doug Legursky alternating, was it knee related?) No, we've played a lot of offensive linemen this year.  We also have played Jonathan Scott.  In Tennessee and in Tampa we alternated linemen, fresh bodies, good bodies as far as I am concerned.  We have a great deal of respect for what every man in helmet is capable of providing us on gameday.  We call upon it.  Guys such as Ramon Foster, Tony Hills, Jonathan Scott have played quite a bit of football for us, for back-up offensive lineman this year and it is something that we are excited about.  We believe that we have capable men and we want to use them. (Re: Play up to the whistle:) You let me know when you hear a whistle.  That is has been one of my contentions.  There has been a de-emphasis on the whistle as far as I am concerned in the National Football League and I don't agree with it.  We talk about player safety, yet we don't blow whistles at the end of football plays.  That's kind of a misnomer when you are talking about the whistle. What we want to do is play until the action ceases. (Do you think they are slow on the whistle because of replay?) They want to have the opportunity for replay to get calls right and I am not opposed to that by any stretch, but there has been a de-emphasis of the use of the whistle in the National Football games. (Was that goal line fumble a replay loophole and can it be fixed?) I don't know that it can be fixed.  I think the rule is pretty clear and we were aware of the rule in the course of the game as that situation was unfolding.  They are pretty clear on it.  They have to have clear recovery of the defensive unit in order to reward the ball to them.  Whether it is down by contact or whether it is breaking the plane of the goal line, they need clear recovery and they didn't have it. (Re: Refs making close calls and replay allowing it to be overturned:) Those guys have tough jobs, I am just glad I am not a referee. (Should there be a recovery one way or another is there is a fumble?) I don't know.  Those guys have tough jobs, I am just glad it is not mine.  I just coach football. (What are the risks if there is no whistle?) Potential injuries to players. (Re: Ray Anderson praised James Harrison for his restraint:) I think what Ronnie Brown did had more to do with it than anything else.  James took his normal approach and angled towards the football, Ronnie Brown caught the ball clean and got down like a savvy veteran does when he is in harms way.  I am less concerned about Ray Anderson's evaluation of James' performance than I am just evaluating James' performance myself. (Would that have been the same kind of play like last week with James' hit on Cribbs that was declared legal?) I don't know.  You can ask Ray Anderson. (Are you ok with guys from the NFL commenting on your players' performance?) It would be tough for me to care less about their opinion to be quite honest with you. (Did you coach differently?) Not at all.  We just play football.  We are just trying to get out of the stadiums with wins. (James admitted that he pulled back. Did you see other players do the same?) I didn't see anything of that nature.  If I appear short it is because it is somewhat insulting to me to assume that we are doing anything under any normal circumstances other than trying to play within the rules.  That's how our guys play, that is how we coach, number one, first and foremost because it is conducive to winning.  And that's what our intentions are when we step in stadiums to play.  Whether it was last weekend, three weeks ago or a month ago or a month from now. (Did the thought of going for the touchdown on 4th down from the goal line cross your mind?) No, we were going to put points on the board and take the lead.  They had utilized all of their timeouts at that point, so we were going to give it to our defense and give them an opportunity to win the game. (What makes playing without Aaron Smith difficult?) Anytime you lose a player and particularly a player such as Aaron, others have to step up.  You  know the philosophy that we bind to in terms of the standard being the standard and what we mean by that quite frankly is those that step in for him have to play winning football, that there are no excuses.  That our intentions will be the same on Sunday night and that is to play winning football.  Do I expect the guys that take his place to play like Aaron, or to make similar plays, maybe not.  But they better be above the line.  They better play winning football and I acknowledge that our group understands what it's about under those circumstances as well.  And generally we will get timely plays from others to compensate.  That is part of being a team and that of course is something we buy into. (Re: Bein pleased with Ziggy Hood's improvement from last year:) I have been.  He had a great training camp and preseason.  Has not had the kind of production that he would like thus far, but that season is still early.  He has a big time opportunity to work on that this weekend.  Knowing him I know that he will do what is necessary in the process. I just saw him downstairs, in here today, getting in a little extra work on a Tuesday.  Not that that is out of the ordinary though, he is not the kind of guy that is responding to an opportunity, that is just Evander Hood. (What would you have done differently in the first half?) I may give Jeff (Reed) an opportunity to bang that one.  I know it was a far kick, it was a pretty decent kick, but we did have the wind at our back, it was a nice climate, a nice day in South Florida.  In hindsight I might have given him the opportunity to bang that one. (Instead of letting the clock run out, maybe throw it to the endzone?) Potentially, but more interested in putting points on the board than potentially exposing guys to hits and so forth at that juncture. (If LaMarr can't go will you bring someone new in?) It's something to consider, but I tend to reserve those judgments based off of the information we get as the week unfolds regarding the injury of the guys we are talking about, particularly LaMarr Woodley. (Once there is a ruling of a touchdown, does that end play?) I don't know, evidently not.  Ask Mike Pereira or some of those guys.  They probably have a better answer than I do. (Are they a different offense with Reggie Bush?) He is a dynamic playmaker.  Not only in the run game but also in the passing game.  He is a special player.  I would imagine that what they call is not going to change but the manner in which it unfolds will because he is that special of a guy.  You have to acknowledge him and how he is capable of changing the game, not only offensively but in the punt return game.  Reggie Bush is a special, special player. (Do you alter so players are in line with their level of capability?) Yes, but those are questions we ask ourselves on a week-to-week basis.  Whether we have backups or not based on the physical matchups of the people that we play.  What's a good matchup, what's a bad matchup, who needs help, those are questions that we continually ask ourselves regardless if it is a quote-un quote front line defender or offensive player in there or a backup.  That is just a natural development of game plans where you try to play to your strengths and minimize your weaknesses in an effort to win the football games. (Does New Orleans have a specific go to guy at wide receiver?) They do, they've got some really good players.  They just have a number of them.  And Drew does a nice job of spreading the ball around.  (Marques) Colston is a big-time football player, Lance Moore is a big-time football player capable of taking the top end of the coverage off.  He is a vertical threat.  (Robert) Meachem is a former first rounder who has evolved into a nice football player.  (Devery) Henderson has been down there a long time, he is a legitimate speed guy.  They've got (Jeremy) Shockey, (Pierrre) Thomas.  They have a lot of eligibles. (Is it bad timing for you that Brees threw four picks?) Like in most instances when you talk about a quality football team or a competitor, specifically, you would have much rather him thrown touchdowns.  But we have no control over that. They are going to go through their processes, make the necessary corrections that they feel that it is they need to make in order to put together a winning performance.  We have to do the same and really ultimately at the end of the day, those things are irrelevant.  We are all focused on the opportunity that is Sunday night and I am sure both teams will be. (Nick Eason and Ziggy Hood talked about Hood's ankle injury.  Was it ever a factor?) None.  He hasn't missed a practice or game.

Good afternoon. It's Tuesday; it's a big week for us, the first of a three-game road stretch. We're going down to South Florida to play the Miami Dolphins. We're pretty familiar with these guys. We've played them some. We played them late last year. They're a really good football team. They're 3-2 this year. Their losses are to the New England Patriots and the New York Jets, two very good football teams, like they are. They're a battle-tested group, an AFC East opponent. We got a lot of respect for those guys and what they're capable of. If we look at the tape there are several things in all three phases that stand out to you. First of all, when you're talking about their team and how they play, they stay on schedule offensively. They're converting 49.3% of their third-down conversions. So they are moving the football; they are converting third-downs. They are dominating time of possession. They got two quality running backs in Ronnie Brown and Ricky Williams. It starts there for us trying to contain those men. They can wage a war of attrition if we don't do a nice job against those guys. In that is included the wildcat attack. They are originators in this league of that attack. What they do with Ronnie Brown, he is special and different than most wildcat runners. I've said that sitting in this setting many times before because he is a runner; he is a tailback. He's a force to be reckoned with in that offense and in base offense. Lousaka Polite, the Woodland Hills guy at fullback, is a quality fullback. That opens holes for both men. Their quarterback, Chad Henne, is doing a very nice job. He's got some nice weapons to throw to and different than last year. They have Brandon Marshall, Central Florida man, who is a perennial Pro Bowl-caliber player. He's big, 6-4, 230 pounds; he's a physical matchup problem for anyone in your secondary. He's strong, but what makes him unique, there are a lot of big receivers, is his ability to run after the catch. He's got short-man quickness in terms of his ability to drop his weight and change direction. He's got great balance; he's a tough guy to tackle once he catches it. He's an easy target down the field; they move him around quite a bit. Henne appears to be very comfortable throwing the ball. He was targeted 17 times last week and caught 10 of them. I am not going to sit here and talk about denying this guy the ball. If they're committed to getting him the ball they will. I think it's important that we try to minimize the amount of damage he does to us, similar to the Roddy White example when we played Atlanta. When they are committed to getting the ball to Pro Bowl-caliber guys they're going to get it. You just try to minimize the amount of damage that they do to you when they do get it. We want to tackle them of course and challenge throws. Davone Bess, their slot man, is very good. I think he's just been rewarded with a contract extension and deservedly so. He works well in the slot. He's a tough matchup problem in zone defense versus linebackers and people of that nature. When you get him one-on-one versus nickel backs, he does a nice job of separation at break points. He's a guy that is experienced beyond his years because of a number of balls that he caught at Hawaii as a college player. Their line is anchored by Jake Long at left tackle. James Harrison has his hands full again this week. He went from Joe Thomas to Long but such is the battle of being a right outside linebacker. Those left tackles are usually pretty good. And this guy is arguably just as good as anyone that plays that spot in the world right now. Defensively up front, Kendall Langford is a Hampton man, is a very good player. Randy Starks had a big year a year ago. He is continuing to wreak havoc. They anchor the front, but they play a lot of people. The linebacker group is one that is noteworthy. It starts with Karlos Dansby. They picked him up from Arizona. He's a big, rangy defender that can run. He's good in coverage. He's good at applying pressure. He's good at chasing the ball sideline-to-sideline. He's got a bunch of physical talent. He's big and fast. Outside, Cameron Wake is continuing to emerge as a Pro Bowl-caliber player. We're very aware of this guy. We pursued him when he came over from Canada like we did Stefan Logan. Miami was able to get his services, and boy are they reaping the rewards of it. This guy is disruptive on whatever tape you turn on. They move him around. He plays on the right side, and he plays on the left side. He has a relentless motor. He gets after the passer, but he also does a nice job playing the run. Sacks and fumbles are his type of thing. He's gotten the ball out several times. He's really playing good football for them. They've got Channing Crowder back on the inside to go along with Dansby. He's been a consistent player for those guys over the last number of years. He's missed some time early in the year but he's back up and running again. In the secondary, for me it's about the emergence of a young guy, Vontae Davis. He appears to be an emerging, elite cornerback in this league. Not many holes in his game to speak of. He challenges people, he plays on the line of scrimmage and he appears to be very aware. He's got good ball skills, and he's a very good tackler. He explodes on contact; he gets guys down. Wide receivers, tight ends, running backs, he doesn't discriminate. He's consistently physical. Jason Allen, their first-rounder a few years back out of Tennessee, is doing good work for them at the other cornerback position. I think he has three or four interceptions. We got our hands full. They got a good team; they are 3-2. They are back at home. They are coming off a nice road victory against Green Bay, which I am sure they will use as a springboard. We better prepare ourselves to be at our best because that's going to be required for us to win. If you look at us from an injury standpoint, I think I stated on Sunday that Brett Keisel sustained a hamstring injury. We can categorize him as out for this week. Trai Essex continues to work back from his ankle sprain. At this point we can call him questionable. I just saw him. He had a nice little workout out back. He was able to get up on his toes. He's probably going to practice in a limited capacity. We'll see where that takes us this week; hopefully it will include him participating. We'll see. Rashard Mendenhall has a left shoulder contusion. It might limit him early this week, just the bumps and bruises that come along with being a feature ball-carrier. Doug Legursky sustained a left MCL sprain in the football game. He was able to stabilize it and come back into the game on Sunday. We expect him to be available and not be limited in any way. It's a good thing because we are going to need all the healthy bodies we can get as we being this road trip. And it starts in South Florida on Sunday. (Have you learned anything more about James Harrison being fined or suspended by the league?) I've just seen the reports that you guys have seen that the hit on Massaquoi is under review. As are all the hits around the league, so I'll let those guys do their job. My opinion is still my opinion in regards to the hits. (Re: Strict enforcement of helmet-to-helmet hits:) I'm a proponent of it. I'm all for player safety. I think it's a proper initiative that the NFL has. I think we need to safeguard the men that play this game to the best of our abilities, and make it as safe as we possibly can. But I also think we have an obligation to those that look at the NFL to provide the safest game we can. I'm talking about high school, college and little league players and so forth around the world. I'm a proponent of player safety and whatever rule or rule adjustment we do to make it safe. (Can players adjust during the hits to avoid the helmet-to-helmet hits?) They have to. I've been highly involved in some of the discussions that have transpired in the last year or two in regards to player safety. We've used words like flagrant and egregious and lowering the strike-zone. Those are words you use as a coach to make sure that you're playing within the rules, not only to keep players safe but to increase our chances of winning, because being a highly penalized outfit is not going to help you. I'm very in tune about what's being asked. We coach it, and I'm a proponent of player safety. (Re: James Harrison's hit on Cribbs not being flagged:) They [The NFL] are not looking at the hit on Cribbs. Cribbs was the wildcat quarterback. He was the runner. Those guys are not protected. That's why a few weeks ago when you guys were asking me why Dennis Dixon doesn't run. The NFL is dangerous for non running backs running in close quarters. (Has wrap-up tackling become a lost art in the NFL?) No, we coach form tackling. Hit-and-wrap tackling is essential. And if you look at that play [Harrison's hit on Cribbs] the first man to make contact with him was a hit-and-wrap tackler in LaMarr Woodley. We teach the second man in to dislodge the ball on contact because that's what we desire. We want possession of the football. They both did exactly what we coach and what we ask them to do. The first man to confront Joshua Cribbs was LaMarr Woodley. He came to balance; he had a nice-formed wrap tackle. The second man in attempted to dislodge the ball on contact and was able to do it, of course though it was recovered by Cleveland.  (Do you agree there should be a higher penalty for repeat offenders?) I am a proponent of levying whatever kind of punishment the NFL Office deems necessary for those who are repeat offenders, for those that are flagrant and for those that are egregious hits.  I agree with that. (So you are not opposed to suspensions?) Whatever they deem necessary, I am going to be a supporter of, particularly when it comes to player safety. (What is your pecking order at right guard?) First let's see who is healthy.  I think it starts there.  Preparation is a big part of determining who plays, so of course, if Trai (Essex) is limited, then of course the nod will potentially go to Doug Legursky.  But we will see as the week unfolds. (What is your pecking order at right defensive end?) We've got two candidates there in Ziggy Hood and Nick Eason.  Both are capable, both are going to play.  Who starts or who comes out of the tunnel has yet to be determined.  But both guys are going to have to step up their performance if they are going to meet the standards that are similar to what we expect when we see Brett Keisel play. (Is Nick Eason healthy?) Yes. (If they eliminate any contact with helmets, do you think that will change the game?) No, I just don't know if that is realistic.  Helmet to helmet contact is going to occur time to time in football.  Things happen fast and these are big moving people.  I think the issue here is that we coach luring of the target, to minimize or reduce a number of those opportunities and to talk about flagrant or egregious approaches.   (Re: James Harrison's comments about the difference between hurting and injuring a player:) I didn't see those comments but I know James.  He says a lot of things that he doesn't necessarily mean.  He is a tough talker, like a lot of guys that play the game at this level.  If you want to get to know James, catch him on a Tuesday when he is walking through the building with his son, he is a big softy. (How close were you to signing Cameron Wake and how do guys like that squeeze through the cracks?) Not close enough.  He is a Dolphin.  There are guys coming out of the CFL and other areas every year, we have a really good scouting staff, guys that look at as I am sure the other 31 teams do.  You turn over stones to find quality players.  They found one in Cameron Wake and they are reaping the rewards of that find. (Have you seen a change with Miami with X's and O's or is it more of a personality change?) It's both and that occurs on every team in every year.  Last year was last year, they have acquired some quality people like Brandon Marshall, Karlos Dansby, they have a new defensive coordinator in Mike Nolan.  The normal changes that occur on teams from year to year in today's NFL is a big part of it.  You look at some of the things that occurred last year, but you spend more time looking at what they have done, and they have a five-game body of work that can provide quality information for us as we prepare this week. (Re: their special teams breakdowns:) I am sure they are just tightening things up.  It is tough to change your personality at this juncture in the season, once you get down the road.  Those things happen.  Games get broken open in a different fashion on a week-to-week basis.  That was an unfortunate weekend for them I am sure.  They made what they deemed as necessary adjustments, moved on and it was a winning edge for them in Green Bay last week.  So we better be prepared for them to be at their best. (Re: Emmanuel Sanders and will he dress this week?) Undecided on that.  We are going to continue to pit those two young men against each other so that we can get the desired results that we want, which is third-down conversions like he provided for us, and that which is quality kick returns like Antonio Brown has provided for us.  He did a nice job but they are both still growing and developing.  We want to assist them in that by providing the truest motivation for them which is competition. (Re: Three-game road trip:) I just acknowledge that we have three road games in a row.  I'm not concerned about it.  We aren't going to fly from Miami to New Orleans.  We are going to come back to Pittsburgh and prepare for next week.  So this is where I am with it.  We are preparing to go to Miami.  We are playing one team this week and that is our focus. (Re: Timmons level of play and did you see that start to happen before his injuries last year:) I did and even going back to 2008 we were playing him in sub-package football.  If you look at his numbers relative to the number of snaps that he played in 2008, what he is doing right now shouldn't be that much of a shock to anyone.  He has been productive since he has played defense for us.  He will continue to get better as he gets comfortable with the nuances of the game and being able to decipher what people are trying to do to him, he is an emerging player and is doing a really nice job. (Ben gave himself a C+ or B- for his performance, do you agree with him?) I'll agree with him if he wants to me to.  I just want to win football games.  Ben has a desire to be perfect, so I am with him on that. (Re: Ziggy Hood's play:) I need to see more from Ziggy and the other 52 men on our team.
