(Is it a possibility for Steve McClendon to be upgraded this week from the practice squad?) I wouldn't necessarily call it a good possibility.  It is a possibility.  The circumstances on those decisions change as you go throughout the year.  Early on in the year you are concerned because of the lack of snaps people have played, you worry about conditioning.  We are five games into this thing now where guys are used to playing a number of snaps and they are in in-season NFL condition.  Six guys is probably more of a requirement in early September than in late October, but again that is a potential option for us, one that we will look at later in the week. (Re: Opposing team receivers being able to catch the ball without anyone around them:) We have to get closer.  Particularly if it happens to be Brandon Marshall.  We are not a finished product and we don't even pretend to be. We are a team that is getting better and hopefully we can win games along the way. This week's challenge is the Miami Dolphins, we probably are not going to be perfect in Miami but we better be good enough to win. (Rodney White approach defending Brandon Marshall?) We've played teams with multiple receivers that can play in our division and in others.  Whether you want to site Cincinnati or others, that is just the story of the National Football League.  The thing is to challenge throws, to minimize yards after catch and to eliminate balls going over the top of your head.  And of course in order to do that, the rush is an element of it.  So it is an 11 man job if you will, to try to contain Brandon Marshall and we better be at our best because he is that good, as are the rest of their guys. (Is there a part of you that enjoys being out in the road?) I love it.  But there isn't much about the National Football League that I don't enjoy.  I like playing at home, I like neutral sites because that's usually a big game.  It doesn't matter. (Concerned about number of touches Rashard Mendehall is getting?) I am, but we had a limited number of options or so over the first month of the season.  He had to carry the torch for us and he did a very nice job of it.  Hopefully as we proceed we will find ways to lighten his load as we move forward. (Does that mean more Isaac Redman?) It also means that and it also maybe means spreading the ball around a little bit, we will see.   (What is your pecking order at third down back?) No, we think all of those guys are capable.  We've taken different approaches in different weeks.  One week we'll have Mewelde Moore spell them on first downs in the first half and Isaac Redman do it in the second half or vice versa.  All of those guys are capable, so we call on them.

Good afternoon. Back to business for us here this week on the South Side preparing for the Cleveland Browns. Always view the bye week with mixed emotions. It's always good to step away and reflect a little bit, evaluate, self-evaluate, make potential corrections and grow. But at the same time you're always somewhat nervous when you miss out on some action a little bit. There's always some anxiety that comes with getting back to action. So we'll have to sort through those feelings here this week as we get back in the mix after having watched last weekend. When you watch the Cleveland Browns, they're a 1-4 football team, yes, but they probably played the toughest schedule to this point in the NFL. Look at the games that they've played, the teams that they've played. Tampa Bay, they lost in the opener by three points. They've proven to be a good team. The Baltimore Ravens, we know what they are, they lost that game. They beat Cincinnati. Kansas City has proven to be a good team. They lost a game there. And of course Atlanta is a good team. They're battle-tested. They've been in against some good teams, some teams that are faring well thus far. They've got some new components that we have to worry about. Offensively it starts with Peyton Hillis, their feature ball carrier. He's a rough and tumble guy that wears you down. That is their personality. They pounded some teams with him, the Baltimore Ravens included in that. We're always concerned about Joshua Cribbs, whether it's as a wideout or return man, both punts and kicks. He's always been a thorn in our side. He's a very good player, doesn't look like much has changed in that area. At tight end, Benjamin Watson appears to be a feature target for them, regardless of who is playing quarterback. He's a vertical threat, a very athletic guy that's been around some really good football, an ex-New England Patriot that provides big plays for them. They got a young receiver corp that appears to be getting their feet on the ground, Mohamed Massaquoi, Brian Robiskie and others. Up front, the left side is a big-time strength of theirs with Joe Thomas at tackle, Eric Steinbach at guard and Alex Mack at center. They are really doing a nice job waging the war of attrition on opponents. It's been particularly impressive. Lawrence Vickers, their fullback, is a big part of that. Defensively, they got some new guys particularly on the linebacker front that we have to be ready for and contend with. Matt Roth at outside linebacker along with Scott Fujita are veteran guys that have been around. Fujita is coming off a world championship season with New Orleans. They are playing really good football for them. Their guys up front, Robaire Smith, Ahtyba Rubin and Kenyon Coleman play rock-solid football and have good gap control. They have a spark plug, a big one in Shaun Rogers. This guy is very disruptive. They are playing him in some sub-package football. They are moving him around getting him in some one-on-one rushes versus people they believe to be a formidable matchup. He's got a big-time resume in terms of blocking kicks. He's always big-time trouble for us. Maurkice Pouncey will be introduced to some more AFC North football this week when he tries to block that man. In the secondary they got something old, something new. Sheldon Brown is a veteran guy that has been around. T.J. Ward is a young guy that's playing safety for him. He's really smashing people, playing good, physical football, kind of reminiscent of Ryan Clark the way he plays the game. Eric Wright holds down the cornerback spot. He's always competitive week in and week out in terms of challenging guys and taking the calculated risks that come with that position. We are excited and nervous at the same time. But that's what coming off bye weeks are about. I like our preparation to this point. I think we're a relatively healthy team. Really the only injury of note is Trai Essex. He went through individual [workouts] a little bit yesterday. Chris Hoke doesn't appear to be limited in any form or fashion, which is good for us. So we'll just keep pushing towards Sunday and continue to work and hone our skills, and prepare for an opportunity to get back in the race, particularly against an AFC North opponent like the Cleveland Browns. (Who do you expect the Browns to play at quarterback?) I have no idea. And I'm really not overly concerned with it. Those are their issues, like our quarterback issues have been ours. They are a professional football team. I am sure whoever they put in there is going to be capable. We're going to have to respect them whether it's Seneca Wallace, Jake Delhomme or Colt McCoy, or for that matter or Josh Cribbs. They are going to snap it to someone. We got to be prepared. (RE: Emotional edge for Ben's return:) I don't know that his absence affected them in that way. I just think the natural challenges that come with the football season affects them in that way. We got a group that has a desire to be great, a group that accepts challenges, a group that wants to win. They'll be presented with those similar challenges and opportunities this weekend, regardless of whether Ben is playing or not. Of course we're excited he is. (How do you approach kicking to Joshua Cribbs?) Weather is an element; it always is. We've faced him at times where we would like to keep the ball away from him and the climate has dictated that we weren't given that option. I don't anticipate the weather being that severe this time, but that's a plan we'll develop throughout the week, with the elements being a part of it. (How much did the weather play into the loss last year at Cleveland?) I think the play of Cleveland was the ultimate determinant of the outcome of that game and our play. They played well and we didn't. (What are your plans offensively with Ben back and who is your No. 2 quarterback?) We are going to do like we always do this week in terms of catering our playing, our strengths versus their strengths, trying to minimize our weaknesses. Ben has many strengths and we are going to utilize them. We also have 10 other players in that huddle that are capable of helping us win so we are going to utilize them as well. In terms of the No. 2 quarterback, we are not decided on that at this juncture. Just like I am not decided on who is returning kicks or punts for that matter. (Do you expect to see more of Cribbs in the Wildcat because of their QB situation?) I think we should expect to see a great deal of Cribbs in the Wildcat regardless of their quarterback situation because he had such success against us a year ago and that is usually the nature of the league and that is what makes it so awesome. When you show areas of deficiency, usually you are going to continue to see those challenges until you fix it. We didn't fix it in that football game. We will have an opportunity to fix it in this one and if we don't, we are going to see quite a bit of it. (Could you put Emmanuel Sanders back on kickoff return?) Yes. (Could he return punts?) He is a punt returner. Yes. I think he settled under one or two in the preseason, has worked extensively at that once the season has begun. (Did the bye week help you establish where you are as a team?) No. More than anything we wanted to develop from a skills standpoint. We wanted to provide practice as improvement opportunities for our young players. We wanted to provide rehab opportunities for our rehab players and rest for some of our elderly players. It was about focusing on us, getting better and improving. In regards to skill development, we understand that this bye occurred at the early juncture of the season and that we are still very much a team in development, individually and collectively. Those improvement areas are usually centered around technique and detail of a assignment. That's why we took the approach that we did. We pitted Steelers versus Steelers, a lot of good-on-good from a repetition standpoint and a lot of competition. (Will Ben provide morale boost?) He always does because he is a ridiculous competitor. When he has an opportunity to compete, you feel him in the room or in the stadium. One of the interesting attributes about him as a player and as a person, when faced with adversity and given the opportunity to compete, man he does. I think guys feed off that. (RE: Peyton Hillis and Joshua Cribbs:) I can't speak to their intended plan. I can speak to what I have seen thus far. Peyton Hillis is a legitimate featured ball carrier and has run through some really good defenses. Josh Cribbs is a multi-dimensional weapon that they use in a lot of ways. Cribbs has run the ball, thrown the ball and has gotten behind people for 65-yard touchdowns from a wide receiver standpoint. I expect them to utilize both men. How they mesh the two together or use them collectively, those are their decisions and not ours. (With Ben being back, did you alter your bye week regimen?) No, we didn't. I think any alterations to our bye week plan was really done to acknowledge the early bye week and the fact that we are still very much in the early stages of this season and still very much a developing football team, individually and collectively. (What did Cleveland do so effectively running the ball against Baltimore?) They broke tackles, they blocked people. They do a nice job of getting hats on hats. This line has played together for an extended period of time now. I don't think Joe Thomas has missed a snap in the last year, same thing can be said for (Eric) Steinbach and (Alex) Mack. They have had some movement or issues on the right side, of course with (John) St. Clair and (Tony) Pashos at tackle particularly. But this is a group that has been together for a long time, particularly on the left side. They get hats on hats, very rarely are there unblocked people and this runner is running extremely hard. It is all supplemented really well by Jerome Harrison, who provides lighting with the thunder of Peyton Hillis. He is very good in the passing game, screen game and perimeter runs. (Can you talk about Mike Holmgren putting his stamp on their offense this year?) I haven't because I don't know Mike really that well, personally in terms of what's important to him from a football standpoint. I know that they have made some changes. With change at the top usually comes change. They have some interesting players, some veteran players, they have put together a nice mix of guys. They have acquired some people that are making them better. They are doing a nice job. (RE: Shaun Rodgers not playing every down:) I can't speak to why he doesn't play; of course talent isn't an issue. Usually when you talk about men of that stature, snap count is a relevant issue. I know that he has a big time opportunity to affect the game in some sub-package football, passing down things. If a guy that size is going to play 30-35 snaps, maybe they feel like he has an opportunity to affect the game more in sub-package. I don't know that. I know that we better be ready to deal with him because he is a very disruptive, powerful man, similar to the guy that was so disruptive against us last week in (Haloti) Nagata. (What do they do well defensively against you last December?) They are not out of place, they play smart, they have nice sub-package, pressure package that we didn't contend with very well a year ago and guys made plays at opportune times. There is really no secret to playing good defense. I don't care if you are talking about Cleveland's defense, our defense or anyone. When the guys are where they are supposed to be, guys make timely plays and they play together and hustle, you have the chance to play some good football. They are doing that. I mentioned earlier that they are a 1-4 team and have played some good people. They lost to Tampa by three points, they had some turnovers in that game, their defense was put on the short field. (Ronde) Barber returned an interception down to the 3-yard line. They lost to Kansas City in a close game. Kansas City's corner, Brandon Flowers, picked the ball off and ran it back. They have been in some games, they have lost some games, some of the points they have given up their defense wasn't on the field. They are better than their record. (RE: Fans reaction to Ben coming back and does it matter? ) Of course it matters. We are a professional sport and we get so much energy from our fans and we work hard to entertain and please them. They really kind of make us go. I expect him to get a warm reception. I really do. I really think that is the nature of Steeler nation. I know we are excited to have him back, I know he is excited about getting back with his teammates and performing for our fans at Heinz Field. (Will you introduce the offense or the defense? ) I have not decided who is returning the kicks, so I have not decided who I'm introducing. (Do you anticipate yourself talking to players about the pitfalls of using Twitter and other social media?) We have a general rule here. I do not care if they tweet; I just don't want them to tweet business in any form or fashion. I think if you stick to that rule then you eliminate any potential things that you'd have to deal with. I'm not opposed to the guys tweeting or Facebook, just don't talk about my business.  (Looking back on the four weeks when Ben was not here, did it go as you thought it would go?) No. I thought we would be 4-0, but we are 3-1. We're moving forward. (RE: Ben being ready:) It looks like he is rested. Ben throwing deep balls to Mike Wallace was entertaining. He's had a good week of practice, and it's just that. Good practice puts you in position to take advantages of opportunities that present themselves in the stadium on game days and you have to take advantage of those. He is no different than anyone else from that standpoint. I'm sure there will be some anxiety, some excitement and nervousness that come with playing after an extended period of time off. I'm sure he'll quickly get through that as he gets warmed up and the competitive juices flowing. All of those are interesting and fun things to be a part of, and we're excited about this opportunity that we have this weekend.  (Did Ben do too much on his time off?) I don't think. This is going to be a 60-minute football game. I think that he will warm up to the competition, move on and be him. Competing and playing football is what he does. I'm sure he'll get back on that bike and learn how to ride it quickly. (Will Heath Miller's role change at all with Ben being back?) Not at all. We are going to continue some of the things we've done with him and to feature him. Hopefully we will maybe do them more successfully than we have in the recent past.

Good afternoon. It's Ravens week of course. It's business as usual for us, typical Baltimore Ravens kind of outfit. They have the number one defense in football led by Ray Lewis and company. He's got his usual cohorts that are wreaking havoc on their opponents. Haloti Ngata, Terrell Suggs, Jarrett Johnson, Kelly Gregg, the list goes on and on. On the back end, Dawan Landry, Tom Zbikowski, Fabian Washington, Chris Carr has fit in nicely. They brought him in as a return man. This guy is playing corner and doing some nice things inside of sub-package football for them. They've given up the fewest first-downs by far in the NFL. I think they're second in the league in red-zone defense. So they desire to play football the way we desire to play football. I think that's what makes this matchup special. We got a great deal of respect for this outfit. They bring the best out in us; we love playing against them. Regardless of what happens in the stadium, you're going to learn a lot about yourself playing against the Baltimore Ravens. Offensively there are some new things. Their run game is their run game. Ray Rice is a special kind of player. He's got great vision and patience, short area quickness. He has hurt us pretty good here the last several years. Willis McGahee is a legitimate tough man, one-cut runner, no frills kind of guy. We have big-time respect for him. Le'Ron McClain is an all-pro fullback and a very capable ball toter. Joe Flacco is their signal caller. They won with this guy when he was young. He's maturing; they're centering their offense around him. It appears to be a little bit more now. They have some legitimate weapons for him to throw to. Anquan Boldin is at the top of the charts in terms of receptions. He's got more receptions than our receiving corps. He's second in the NFL in third-down catches. He blistered Cleveland pretty good last weekend. I just finished watching that this morning. That was a horror-show if you sit in my position. Todd Heap is Todd Heap. He's got more receptions than our team. He's a security blanket for the quarterback. They're good with the running backs in terms of the check downs. And it's funny that I haven't even mentioned Derek Mason yet. That's the kind of task we're facing this week. But we're competitors. We enjoy it, we respect them, and we're excited about it. It is Steelers versus Ravens. It's something that is humbling to be a part of, exciting to be a part of and hopefully we'll prepare level-headed and play level-headed. It's a very emotional game. I think that the spirit and play of the leaders on each side of this matchup exemplifies what the matchup is about. You're talking about guys like Hines Ward, James Farrior or Ray Lewis. You know what you're getting when those guys step into stadiums. And I think the two teams mirror those men when they play one another. We're excited about that. From an injury standpoint we are in relatively good shape. We have no new injuries at quarterback. Chris Hoke is questionable at this juncture. If he gets some work in the latter part of the week we're going to try to play him. But of course we are going to play the healthy men. He's going to have to prove his health to us as does Trai Essex from his ankle sprain. We'll watch those guys and judge their level of play or their availability based on what they do here in the week. The rest of the injuries are bumps and bruises that go along with football. Will Allen returned to the game the other day with his ankle sprain. We expect him to be fine. Ziggy Hood sustained an ankle sprain at some point late in that football game. We expect him to be fine. He might be limited at the top of the week. And Anthony Madison had a little hamstring injury. He shouldn't be limited too much. Other than that we've got a clean bill of health. We're going to need it. Such is life when you're playing the Baltimore Ravens Sunday at one-o'clock, glad it's at Heinz Field. (RE: If Ray Rice can't play:) I don't think it's going to change their personality whatsoever from a play-calling standpoint, and I base that off of video evidence. They roll their backs some. You're going to see Willis McGahee whether or not this guy is healthy or not. You're going to see Le'Ron McClain whether this guy is healthy or not. And what Joe Flacco does is a nice job of checking balls down to backs when his primary receivers are covered. They've done it since he's been there. I don't expect that to change. Those other men I mentioned are very capable and dangerous men, men that we respect. So we got to be ready to play football versus the Baltimore Ravens whether Ray Rice is available or not. (Is Charlie Batch leading you into the Baltimore game?) He is at the quarterback position. He's done a nice job. We won last week. That's a good place to start. The guy has got a great deal of confidence in him. He's simply a man that's taken advantage of an opportunity. You got to be happy for him. It's an awesome lesson learned from our young players, one that I hope they take heed to. This league is about perseverance; this profession is about perseverance. It's about taking advantage of opportunities when they are given. He's given them a shining, clear-cut example of that at this juncture. (How is Byron Leftwich health-wise?) Byron is fine and he was fine last week.  (We're you tempted to put him in the game to see how he was?) No, we were comfortable with what we were doing and how we were going about our approach to the game. Byron was fine a week ago. (Is this rivalry unique?) I think it's unique because it's the best rivalry in the NFL. (What makes you say that?) Because I've witnessed about the last seven or eight of those meetings, it's always fireworks. It's always significant, it just is. It's football the way it's supposed to be played. Those guys put a lot into it on both sides. Both teams I'd imagine are spent when it's over. Mutual respect is a big part of it. (RE: Ray Lewis and James Farrior playing at such high levels after all these years:) They are freaks of nature, not only in terms of God-given ability and talent, but endurance, longevity, they are special people. They probably lead in different ways, but it probably fits their personalities. They are probably respected very differently. (RE: Dennis Dixon's surgery?) He came out of surgery fine. I haven't seen a surgery that wasn't a success. Tentatively they said anywhere from four-to-six weeks, but every time is different. We're hopeful that he's going to get back to us quickly. (Is he a candidate for the Reserve/Injured List?) Not this week. It depends on how games go. I never look too far ahead in terms of those kinds of decisions. We got to play a game this week. Injuries are a part of football; you never know and you just don't. (RE: Doug Legursky's performance:) I thought he represented himself very well. I think that's one of the reasons Trai Essex is feeling better. (RE: Baltimore's secondary:) They're the number one defense in the league and the number one defense in the league versus the pass. So I am happy Ed Reed isn't playing. (RE: Running game in the second half at Tampa Bay:) I am excited that it produced in the manner that it did on Sunday. Every week is different. We're trying to do the very best we can to win football games. We acknowledge that week-to-week that may change. (RE: Cleveland putting up rushing yards against Baltimore's Defense:) I would imagine that the Ravens are sitting in a meeting room somewhere talking about what they didn't do right. The fact that Cleveland had success a week ago doesn't bode well for us. It just doesn't. I would have felt better if Peyton Hillis had run for 40 yards as opposed to 140. Because I know the type of men that play for that team, I know how prideful they are. I know they will bounce back. Anytime you play football or defense, every now and then people are going to have days on you. The great defenses such as the Baltimore Ravens usually bounce back pretty quickly. We got a tall task this week given what happened to them a week ago. (What do you notice different about Joe Flacco these days compared to what you first prepared for? ) Nothing extraordinary, just the natural maturation process of a franchise-caliber quarterback, he uses all of his eligible receivers and doesn't ride an emotional rollercoaster. He is an extreme flat-liner; in the mix of pressure he's at his best. He can make any throw on the field. The deep comeback is a signature of his ball. He can drop the deep ball and take the top off the coverage. He is just a very talented guy who has some great weapons. Again, Anquan Boldin, Derek Mason, Todd Heap and the backs. He is a dangerous man, as is his outfit.  (How did they use Haloti Ngata and will they use Kelly Gregg?) It depends if you're asking how they use him or how they use him against us.  Last time they moved him around and we saw him over Heath Miller. I think they think we like to run to the tight ends. They put Ngata out there and it's uncomfortable for Heath to say the least. It won't be a reprieve for Maurkice Pouncey because he'll be looking at Kelly Gregg, an awesome football player. Also they have a young guy who they haven't even taken the wrapper off yet, named Terrence Cody.  (You always say that the margin for error is so small. When you go back and grade the quarterback do you look at the outcome Charlie Batch had compared to the things that could have turned out differently? ) It is what it is. Those plays that score, I like them.  Really when you look at it, and I know a lot is being written about the quality of Charlie's play. It was good, but he didn't play much differently than he did in Tennessee. I think I made that point to you guys; he gave us an opportunity in Tennessee. He put balls where they were supposed to be and gave guys the opportunity to make plays. Those guys did not make those plays in Tennessee, as they did in Tampa. That was the difference in his performance, statistically.  (Did you trust Charlie Batch in this game more than Dennis Dixon in the first two games?) We did. You're talking about a guy who's been a franchise quarterback, a starter who's been here for nine years. He's 35 years old; it's all a rerun to Charlie Batch. Dennis Dixon of course, it's all new to him. Dixon is a young talented guy. You try and help him manage the game as a coach. (Is that why you gave Dennis more of an opportunity?) No. I gave him the opportunity because he earned it. You know how he played in the preseason, he played extremely well.  He earned that opportunity, we gave it to him. (Does Lawrence Timmons's level of play and speed have any effect on what Troy Polamalu does?) Lawrence has played fast since he's been here. He's a special player, a blur on the screen along with 43. When you watch tape they have unique characteristics. They are run-and-hit guys. That's why they are first rounder's and linchpins of a rock solid defense.  (You've talked about this being an emotional game. Do you watch the level of emotions so that they don't get too high going into this game? ) You do, you want to play mistake free, and you don't want to hurt yourself. You can tell maybe the game last week versus Cleveland got out of hand, that's AFC North football. We understand that, and they understand that going into the game. I think that these two teams do a good job, better than what people give them credit for. In terms of playing clean and controlling their emotions when we see each one another, we know that the game is potentially going to be tight and you can't reduce your chances of winning by hurting yourself.  (Going in to the season, there were high expectations of the Ravens, about them going to the Super Bowl, and less expectation for you. Is that relevant for this time of the year or is that the type of thing to face? ) I think most story lines are irrelevant when these two teams play each other.   (Your defense is a lot healthier this year, is that the biggest reason why they have been so much better two, three games into the season or is there more to that? ) You made the key statement when you said two, three games. I think two, three games a year ago our defense was pretty salty.  It's too early to be anointing us and things of that nature right now. The Baltimore Ravens have the number one defense in football. (Talk about William Gay, and his role?) He's been a consummate professional, a team player. I tipped my hat a few days ago to Charlie Batch for how he's approached his situation and I can say the same for William Gay. This is a guy who started every game for us a year ago. We've reacquired Brian McFadden. Will has fallen back to a sub package role and he hasn't muttered a peep. He works extremely hard, always ready and into the game and he's making plays. I'm happy for him. I'm excited for him; I want more of those kinds of plays from him. (If Chris Hoke can't play, can you get by with five linemen? ) Potentially, we will cross that bridge when we come to it. Right now we are hopeful that Chris Hoke will be able to make it. (Does this situation serve as a rally point for the players in the locker room?) I think they are better prepared to answer that than I am.  I just acknowledge that we are dealing with a situation here, and that some of the situation is our doing. We have to fight our way out of it, that's more of the mentality of our football team more than anything else. (Is it possible to respect an opponent and dislike an opponent at the same time? ) Sure. I will not talk about likes and dislikes, but I will acknowledge that there is a great respect for that football team and how they do their business. (Regarding Mike Wallace's play?) I tease Mike Wallace. I call him the "one-trick pony" because he's searching for a ceiling in all the elements of his game. This is a young guy that's extremely humble, that works very hard and who has a distinguishing characteristic. He is a man in development with in some areas. I like how he works at it, and I'm going to continue to challenge him. (What kind of matchup are they looking for when they bring in a third tackle?) Coach Harbaugh would be a better man to answer that.  We have no control over who they play, when they play them or where they play them, or anything else.  It's just our job to stop them. (How close to perfect is Maurkice Pouncey playing?) That is a strong word.  He is doing a nice job.  An extraordinary job for a rookie but we don't grade on a curve.  We put him in the lineup because he is not playing like a rookie.  He is doing a nice job.  But this guy has a tall challenge this week.  It doesn't matter who they put in front of him, whether it is (Kelly) Gregg, (Haloti) Ngata or (Terrence) Cody, he is going to be introduced to the Ravens and Steelers rivalry pretty quickly, I am sure. (What is it that makes Ngata so special?) He is freakishly big, has great body control, and is very quick and fast in a short spaced area.  He's just got it all, he really does.  He is as dominate of a defensive lineman as there is in football right now. (When you have to double a guy like that, does that provide a win for the defense?) Absolutely, but it is what it is.  If you block guys like him with one man, he is going to be in your backfield. (Can players do this two more times a year if they increase the schedule to 18 games?) If they expand it to an 18 game schedule then that means everyone has to play an 18 game schedule and I am not too concerned about it.  If we are playing 18 and others are playing 16, then I have a problem. (Is either rookie at wide receiver making enough progress that they might get more playing time at that position?) Right now, Antonio Brown has the helmet and both guys are making steady progress.  Brown did play more offense in Tampa than he did in Tennessee.  We expect all of our young people to continue to grow and be given opportunities accordingly. (RE: Ray Lewis' level of play:) Looks like Ray Lewis to me.  He is a dangerous guy.  He is great versus the run, great versus the pass.  I think the most extraordinary thing about what is going on with him right now is how very good he is against the pass.  A guy that has been around as long as he has and has been in as many battles as he has, he is great in open space.  They utilize him in somewhat deep defense in that Tampa-2, he covers a bunch of ground, he is an intimidator, playmaker, he broke a ball up intended for Chad OchoCinco and that is kind of indicative of the kind of player he is.  He banged a ball out against Cleveland in the same coverage to a tight end last week.  He is a lot of range, makes a lot of plays and is extremely smart. (Are you happy with the field position game?) Daniel (Sepulveda) has done a nice job.  The field position game has been big for us.  We haven't always taken advantage of it, we've created a bunch of turnovers, and we hadn't scored a bunch of touchdowns.  Daniel has done a nice job of keeping us in play with his punting and Jeff Reed has been doing a nice job of taking advantage of scoring opportunities. We haven't produced touchdowns at the rate that we have liked to in the red zone, but we have scored every time we have been in the red zone.  So that is a testament to all of those guys and really just a testament to the team concept and how we have to persevere.  It has to be the signature of our football team in 2010. (Have you decided on the bye week activities?) I haven't decided on it and probably the number one determinant of our bye week activities is how we perform on Sunday. (Did Legursky play well enough in Tampa that Essex has to win his spot back?) He played good.

Good afternoon. I guess I'll start with an injury report since that seems appropriate. Dennis Dixon has a left knee injury. It is meniscus related. Right now he's scheduled to tentatively have surgery tomorrow morning with that. I don't know how long he'll be out. Usually you get more information when you go in and look at those things. So we're going to wait and see what it looks like before we proceed with the length of time he can potentially be out. Rest assured he's not going to play this week. With some of the other injury things that were pre-existing,  Casey Hampton has been in the building the last several days and has looked really good in terms of getting himself ready to go this week. The same could be said for Emmanuel Sanders; he's doing well. Byron Leftwich is back in the building and doing well from a workout standpoint. Max Starks should be a full participant as should Jason Worilds. Some of the things that were injury-related for us leading up to last week appear to no longer be an issue. But we do have new issues with Dennis Dixon and Trai Essex. Trai Essex has an ankle sprain. We'll see what he can do and kind of make our judgments from there based on what he's able to do here throughout the week. From a health standpoint we'll take it. Such is life in the NFL. The men that are healthy, we have to prepare witjh and go play winning football this weekend down in Tampa, Florida, versus a good football team that's 2-0 in a hostile environment, one that I am very familiar with. Particularly, in September football, one o'clock kickoff down there, weather is a factor. Conditions will be a factor in the football game. We got to acknowledge that. We have to do the best we can to prepare ourselves for that. Ultimately how we play is really going to determine how that wears and tears on us. When you look at Tampa, there are a lot of reasons they are 2-0. I've just finished watching the games again this morning, just looking at how they flow and bring the three phases together. They're playing off themselves, they really are. They create turnovers; they're plus-4 in two games. When they create those turnovers the offense scores with them; they're responding in that way. They're playing really good in special teams, their coverage units. I was really impressed with what they were able to do versus Joshua Cribbs a couple weeks ago up in Cleveland. We know about that guy. They really got after that bunch with their special teams units. They're very good on third-downs, about 41 or 42 percent on third-down conversions. That's pretty special with a young quarterback. He's using his legs to get some of them done. He converted two big ones in Sunday's game with his legs, third-and-10, third-and-11, third-and-nine type of conversions. But he's also using his known commodities, guys such as Kellen Winslow, who is the No. 1 third-down receiver in the NFL, the guy has got eight catches on third-downs. We know about him; we've competed against him. We know he's a tough, physical matchup, a very athletic and physical matchup for linebackers and a big, powerful matchup from a coverage standpoint for safeties. Defensively Ronde Barber is tied for the NFL lead in interceptions. He delivered a timely one here in the last two games. He set up a scoring drive versus Cleveland that put them back in that game. I know what he's capable of. AqibTalib is back for them. He missed the first game. That's an awesome corner-tandem that they have. He had a pick last week and closed that game out. They're stingy, they're multiple, they run a variety of packages, they get after people, but more importantly than any of those things is when we watched the games they really warmed up to the action. Nobody scored on them in the second half of football games this season. They shut Cleveland out in the second half; they shut Carolina out in the second half. So nobody scored a point on them, not even a field goal in the second half, so that speaks to how their game evolves over the course of the game and the necessary halftime adjustments and things that they make. We got our work cut out for us, but such is life. We enjoy the challenges that the NFL provides us, and we've been provided with a big one this week going into Tampa Bay to play an undefeated team. (Is Byron's knee still an issue and is he in a competition with Charlie Batch to start?) We don't anticipate (the knee) being. He's been able to comfortably get through some workouts. Workouts of course are different than practices and games, particularly the unanticipated movement that comes with playing football. But we feel comfortable with where he is. We're going to go through the week and proceed through the week to see how this thing sorts out. Those are the two candidates. You got to say that Charlie is in pole position because he's got a clean bill of health at this point. We don't anticipate Byron's health being an issue, but you at least at this point of the week have to acknowledge that could be a factor in terms of how the reps get sorted out and who ultimately plays. (Will you bring in another QB?) Not at this juncture, no. (Is Dennis Dixon a candidate for injured reserve?) It's really going to be determined by what we see after they go in and perform the surgery. With injuries of that sort, you can acknowledge and identify damage. You usually don't know the extent of the damage until you go in, so we're tentatively scheduled to go there tomorrow morning around nine o'clock, and we'll have other information as we proceed from there. (Do you know on what play Dennis got hurt?) I think it was the 22-yard scramble on third-and-two. Earlier in the game he said he planted his leg into the ground and planted his leg back inside. He said it felt a little unstable at that point. But adrenaline and things of that nature, sometimes when it's a non-impact injury -- meaning no one else was involved -- it takes a while before you realize something is amiss. (Will you dress any extra offensive linemen because of the dehydration from last game?) We had the same issues with our defensive line if they can't get off the field. It wasn't an issue with our defense in the last game because we created turnovers. Those are natural issues or questions that you ask yourself going into a game. The reality is you can't carry extra bodies at all positions. So based on the matchup, our level of comfort and preparedness and health, those are the things that will kind of determine where we distribute the helmets. (Does playing in a hot environment last week prepare you for similar weather this week?) No, it's a unique thing. We have to play in it. It's going to be hot on their sideline as well. I've coached football down there. This time of year when you coach football down there you like to feel good about the climate in that it's a winning edge. But the reality is that if you don't get off the field and make the necessary plays you need to make it could hurt you. I've been a part of that. We're not going to get too caught up in it. (Does playing in weather conditions in Tennessee prepare you for the weather in Tampa?) No.  It's a unique thing.  We have to play in it and it is going to be hot on their sideline as well.  I've coached football down there and this time of year you like to feel good about the climate and that it is a winning edge.  But the reality is that if you don't get off the field and make the necessary plays that you need to make, it can hurt you.  I've been a part of that so we aren't going to get too caught up into it. (Why did the offense have so much trouble putting seven's on the board opposed to three's?) We didn't operate very well on third down.  I thought Charlie made some plays in the second half.  We had an opportunity to make some plays for him that we didn't make.  They were competitive catches, no question.  There really wasn't one guy, it was when you looked at all of our guys, I thought, very reliable people.  Heath Miller had the opportunity to deliver a play or two for Charlie.  Mike Wallace had an opportunity to deliver a significant play that would have put us in scoring position in the third down situation.  I thought Hines (Ward) was capable of maybe catching that touchdown on that little short fade.  Those are the kinds of plays that need to be made.  Competitive plays, yes.  Combative plays, yes.  But those are the plays you have to make for a quarterback, particularly one that hadn't played a bunch or is in the backup situation.  We weren't able to do that and that is why we weren't able to ring the scoreboard up by seven's.  We will continue to work at it and hopefully produce some this week. (Are you including the third and 11 to (Mike) Wallace?) Yes, that was the one I was referring too.  Usually when he catches the ball and there aren't a lot of people back there with him, he has the chance to get in.  But that's football.  The reality is that we are not making enough of the necessary plays in the critical moments to get sevens or ring the scoreboard up.  We are just doing enough to win at this juncture. (When you are dressing two quarterbacks, does that limit you offensively?) No, I don't think that it does.  I have been in this league for a number of years now and I can't think of an instance when you are down to your third quarterback in in-game action, but stranger things have happened, particularly with us and recently. (Re: Shuffling of quarterbacks:) We don't care about the shuffling.  Whoever is in has to play to our standard.  The guys are going to do the best they can to help them.  We understand that we are going down there on a business trip and our business is winning. (Is (Antwaan) Randle El the next quarterback if need be?) We also have Arnaz Battle who was a quarterback at Notre Dame and Hines threw for 400 yards in the Peach Bowl one year.  We've got options.   (Are they lobbying for those spots?) Every man is capable.  Guys want to ante up and kick in and I appreciate that about them. (Re: comment about people telling the death of your team, does that contradict how you say to not pay attention to what others say?) Certainly it does, but we are all emotional beings and sometimes we lose out to that.  It was probably unwarranted really, but that is where I was at that point.  This is tough.  It is a tough game and it requires a lot.  You have to put in a lot, you have to be ten toes into this thing to win and at time that shouldn't annoy you, annoy you because of that fact.  GMAC, awesome and we have a great relationship with them, but we were the never say never moment of the week candidate a week ago because we win our home opener.  We kind of took offense to that, that it was a never say never moment that we won our home opener.  Such is life in our league.  We are going to try to have a thicker skin and proceed with our business this week and I am talking about myself. (Is annoyed a good state?) If it produces victories. Sure. (Will (Doug) Legursky start if Essex can't go?) Yes.  He has played really good ball in the preseason and into the regular season and of course he was called upon.  Happy with where that young man is. (Re: Center snaps botched:) It is probably an issue with Maurkice (Pouncey), probably an issue with the cadence, the fact that we were having to use silent counts, probably an issue that we were playing multiple quarterbacks, some of which that he hadn't taken a bunch of snaps with.  We got limited exposure of exchanges between Pouncey and Batch, especially considering the limited amount of 11-on-11 snaps that Charlie got in Latrobe.  Not making excuses, they are what they are.  We have to snap the ball, because that generally gets plays started. (Re: Elimination of mental mistake on defense:) They have made plays, no question.  As far as mental mistakes and miscommunication, those are things that are overblown, I think any defense that breaks down, those are generally the issues.  I know that has been the case with every defense that I have been a part of whether it is here or any other city that I have worked in.  That's always overblown I think.  That's what causes defenses to break down, they miss communicate.  They are out of place, that's what breaks them down. In regards to the plays that they are making right now, they are doing it.  They are making significant plays at significant moments and that produces great defensive play. (Re: (Lawrence) Timmons increasing level of play:) I really thought that he was on course a year ago. He missed fourplus games and it was limited in some others due to the high ankle injury that he had, but the play that he is exhibiting right now is no different than the play that he exhibited a year ago when healthy.  I thought the light came on for him a year ago. (Re: Antonio Brown's play:) He made a pretty good case for himself, but I can be a tough guy to work with sometimes so we will see how the week unfolds. (Re: Contributions from special teams:) We are just trying to win football games and we hadn't won many down there, of course.  It is a tough place to play, they are a good football team, and we knew we would have to take some calculated risks and produce some plays; we were able to do that.  Special teams was a part of it and it is a legitimate phase of our team and those guys stepped up and made plays.  Less concerned that the contributions came from that phase of our team and more excited about the fact that some of the contributions came from some very young people.  Antonio Brown made some plays; Stevenson Sylvester made some plays. When you get young guys making plays for you, it is encouraging. (Did the kickoff return at the start of your game make you change your offensive stance going into the game?) It really didn't, because any comfort, if that's the appropriate word or feeling that you had a long those lines went away pretty quickly when they sack fumbled us on the first third down of the game and had the ball in relative good field position, went down and kicked a field goal and it was a seven to three game.  It kind of balanced out the kick return and the game went on from there. (This is the first game you are favored to win, does that change your attitude?) I don't know that the fact that we are favored changes our attitude.  I am not going to make that assumption. (How long before did you know you would do the reverse on the kickoff?) Pretty much all week.  We worked it pretty good.  It was one of those things that if you were going to do it, you were going to do it early.  I think had we waited until the second kickoff return they might have notices that Antonio Brown was the off returner as opposed to the returner.  So that was one of the those things whether or  not we received the ball to start the game or the second half or whenever we ran the unit out there, in all likelihood it was probably going to go down immediately. (Was it something you noticed on their tape that prompted you to do that?) No, they are a very sound outfit in all three phases, but particularly in special teams.  It was nothing that really showed itself or lent itself to us doing that.  We just felt that is was a calculated risk that we needed to take in an effort to maybe change field position or give a shot in the arm to get things started.  Antonio is a talented guy, he has initial quicks, we thought that if he could get around a guy or two that he could give us a charge and get a chunk of real estate for us.  He provided more than we anticipated. (The onside kick, do you want your players to go aggressively after the ball like that?) Absolutely, you have to.  You have to play aggressively, particularly in those situations.  He had a clean play on the ball, he has to take it, he did everything right other than possess the football. (Have you ever seen an onside kick executed like that before?) Yes, I have had some obscure jobs and I have worked at VMI and Arkansas State and I have tried just about everything. (What is now your team's identity?) Hopefully our identity is winning and doing what it takes to win.  I think it is probably too early in the season, not only for us, but for everyone to try to put teams in a box or talk about identities.  It's just not a big enough body of work at this juncture I think to make those kinds of assessments.

Good afternoon. Quick synopsis of our performance the other day, my feelings are much the same as they were following the game. I'm proud of the team, glad we were able to win. But we got to get better in a lot of areas. That quality of performance is not going to be good enough to secure victory this week in a hostile environment versus the Tennessee Titans. And that's just how it is. We got some days to improve and get better, to better understand what kind of football team we are and what we need to do to win football games, and how we need to prepare to do it. Thought there were some positives of course as there always are, not going to dwell on those things. We're going to work on the things we feel like we need to improve in. That's the nature of this journey as we go from Week 1 to Week 2. We expect all teams; including the one we are playing to be better. Week 2 that's usually the case. Some of the nervousness and unknowing and uneasiness that comes with opening week is less of an issue in Week 2 so we better be better. From the injury standpoint, Byron Leftwich appears to be doing better with his knee sprain. We're going to give him some work in the limited capacity probably tomorrow and see where we go from there. Casey Hampton has a hamstring injury. We're going to watch him closely throughout the week. We're hopeful that he might be able to do something but it's up in the air at this juncture. Max Starks has an inversion ankle sprain, which in laymen's terms is a low ankle sprain. I know it was reported as a high ankle sprain. That report was inaccurate; it's a low ankle sprain. I saw him this morning. He appears to be doing better. He might be able to do something at the latter part of the week and maybe make himself available to us in this football game. Hopefully that's the case, if not we are very comfortable with Jonathan Scott in terms of what he's capable of. He's been a big addition to our outfit, and we expect him to play great ball if Max is unavailable. Looking at the Tennessee Titans, boy they made pretty quick work of Oakland last week. Offensively it starts with Chris Johnson. This guy can run through the back of the end zone every time he touches the football. There's an element of respect that comes with preparing for a guy that is capable of those things. We are familiar with him, we've played against him. He stuck his foot in the ground and cut back across our field, and got some yards in chunks on us. That's a big challenge. Additionally a challenge is Vince Young playing quarterback. We've played these guys quite a bit in the last couple years. It hadn't been against Vince Young. He adds an element to the preparation equation and play equation. This guy can break you down with his legs, whether it's by design or otherwise. They run some speed option stuff with him; he's getting chunks of yards that way. If you cover his eligible receivers up and you give him and escape lane he's capable of hurting you very bad with his legs. We got to get ready for that element; preparing for the Titans it's a little bit different than some of the other times in recent years that we prepared to play them. Nate Washington outside for them, Kenny Britt and Gage, they got some really good wide receivers. Their tight ends are a unique and very deep and good group with Leonard Stephens and Bo Scaife. They do a nice job of utilizing their tight ends. From a formation standpoint, they split those guys and try to create matchup issues with those guys. Bo Scaife is one of those big-body rebounded kind of guys that is pretty dog-gone good at hurting you down the field from a tight end standpoint. Defensively it starts with their front rotation. I say rotation because it's more than four men. It's a myriad of men that come at you. They all play with great energy and enthusiasm. They all have quick triggers and get off extremely well on the ball. The game location is going to be a factor this week from that standpoint. Silent counts and so forth are going to play into their advantage. Jason Jones, their interior defensive lineman and Tony Brown, they've been very disruptive in our backfield in recent years. Jacob Ford has been a disruptive force against us. We've got to prepare for those guys. They've got additions like Jason Babin and Derrick Morgan who are contributing to their personality. In the secondary they tackle extremely well. That's the first thing that jumps off the screen at you, whether it's Chris Hope or Michael Griffin or at the corner back position, Cortland Finnegan and Jason McCourty are extremely good tacklers. I think they minimize explosion plays with their open-grass tackling in the secondary. When you go into a place like Tennessee it increases your chances of winning if you can get some chunks to help you get down the field and change field position where they do a great job of minimizing the possibility of that with their great tackling in the secondary. There's not a lot to be optimistic about, but as a coach you can back yourself in those corners on days like today, Tuesday. We'll go to work, we'll prepare our guys, we'll put together a plan and I'm sure they'll go out and execute it to the best of their abilities. Between now and then we need to do everything that we can between players and coaches to make sure that's enough.(Are you concerned with Dennis Dixon going into this hostile environment?) Really it has nothing to do with Dennis. We've gone in there with Ben Roethlisberger and gotten beat up. It is a tough place to play particularly if they get you behind the chains or behind on the scoreboard. They can get off in their attacking, penetrating and disruptive group up front. They create negative plays. It's demoralizing; it ignited their fans. It's what playing on the road in the NFL is supposed to be about. It's an awesome challenge. We need to prepare for it so we can enjoy it. If you're ill-prepared it's not quite as fun. (Is saying you are going to contain Chris Johnson more realistic than actually doing it?) I thought Oakland was doing a pretty good job for a quarter-and-a-half until he went 76 yards. Such is a case with a guy like him. And historically speaking, guys that are capable of breaking you down in one or two plays, it makes them special people. There's a level of respect that goes with playing guys like him. I used to work for Monte Kiffin, and he used to tell stories about Barry Sanders. He said they'd shut him down other than the two plays that he went 80 yards. Well that's the kind of guy this guy is. It's not a quarter-battle; it's not a half-battle. It's a 60-minute or 60-minute plus battle. Every time he puts his hands on the ball he's capable of hurting you bad. (Will there be any consideration of you working Flozell Adams at left tackle?) None, he's a right tackle. (Are you waiting to see if Bryon Leftwich can go or is Dennis Dixon going to start?) Dennis is going to lead us into Nashville. (RE: Why you chose to answer the question about Ben being the starter the way you did:) In order for us to see our way out of this situation, I think it's important that we have a one foot in front of the other mentality. We need to be singly focused on what's in front of us every step of the way. That's the only way we're going to work through this situation. As a leader of the outfit, I'm going to subscribe to that as well. So I refuse to ponder the potential or the hypothetical scenarios that wait for us at the end of this situation. I'm in the midst of it; I'm living it like our football team is living it. I refuse to address any other element of it other than what we have right now, which is a Tuesday. We're preparing as a staff for the Tennessee Titans. Our guys are going to be in here tomorrow. We're going to do the best to our ability to prepare those guys. And they're going to do the best to their ability to execute the plan. And Dennis is our guy this week. (Are any of your receivers allowed to workout with Ben outside of this facility, and are you ok with that? ) They are not. (If Casey Hampton can't play, what predicament do you think location will have? ) We're going into a hostile environment. It's a twelve o'clock central kickoff in Nashville. I don't know what the weather forecast will be, but fatigue could become a factor. They have a good back who is also backed up very well by Javon Ringer.  Attrition could be a part of this game. It's something that concerns you more as a coach, when your nose guard is on the injury list. We will deal with it like we always do.  (What would bring you to use Nike Eason, Zigggy Hood at Defense tackle? ) Some of those guys have position flexibility; really it depends on the amount of base defense we see.  The issue might be solved for us if we end up in a bunch of sub package football.  I'm not going to get too caught up into that now, Chris Hoke will be our guy and others are capable.  (Is it fair to say that you rotated the defense line Sunday more than since you've been here?) It's an element acceptation of football. This is what we do every September, or try to every September because those guys are playing more snaps than they did in the pre-season. We want energy; we want to be able to win the line of scrimmage and playing fresh bodies is a big component of that. I really think that's one of the things Coach Fisher and the Titians subscribe to. It's one of the things that makes them a tough and special outfit to prepare for. (If Casey Hampton can't go would you consider bringing somebody in? ) There's a potential for that, yes. I think that Casey's availability, the level of conditioning and exhaustion we see from the other guys may be an ability to create space. There's a lot of things that factor into that equation and that's something of course that can play itself out in the week.  (Do you know who your third tackle will be to backup for those two weeks?) Tony Hills, who's had a very good pre-season and who's really done a nice job. He's in probe condition, but we are not willing to count out Ramon Foster. Foster is tackle capable as well. It's going to be fun to watch those guys battle and compete this week. Hopefully both of those guys get better because of it.  (Dennis Dixon didn't run a lot on in the game on Sunday. Was that by design or the way the game worked out? Do you want to see him run a bit more?) It's probably the way the game unfolded. I'm not opposed to him running. What I am for is him moving the chains and running up the scoreboard. If him running helps us do that, I am all in. (Are you happy with Randle El at punt return? And are there any thoughts of dressing Antonio Brown?) I thought he made great decisions. We had a lot of young people doing a lot of key jobs for us a week ago. Whether it's Maurkice Pouncey snapping the ball in Dennis Dixon's hands every time or so forth, I thought it was a prudent decision to put a veteran guy back there. I thought he made good decision; he ended around the 10-yard line, you know we were backed up quite a bit. He secured the ball in some sticky situations. I am pleased of where he is, but no questions that Antonio Brown is an attractive option.  It's good to have options.  (You've mentioned about their rotation, it's very strong and about their sacks. Where does that strength come from, is it a system thing, a diversity of strengths or is it just they come in waves?) I think it starts first and foremost that they have a lot of guys who are capable of playing above the line of winning football. When you have that, you give those guys an opportunity to play, which they do. It's important to them, they buy into it. The guys that come from off the bench play like starters. It's a very successful thing they have going on. (Have the defense caught up with the offense in the league?) I'm not going to try and tell a story based on one week of football. The scoreboard may ring up big time this week, and it might be another story. I am just really focusing on what our team is doing, and what we need to do to get out of stadiums with wins. I am not concerned about the big picture at this point.  (RE: Dennis Dixon running more plays like Coach Tressel calls for Terrell Pryor:) We are going to do what's best, not only for Dennis but our team. What Coach Tressel does for his team is good for those guys. We are just trying to win and of course keep Dennis upright. The National Football League games are violent of course than college football.  Terrell Pryor is just as big if not bigger than the people trying to tackle him. It's a different story on Sundays; that's an element of it.  (RE: Dennis Dixon and you starting him again:) It starts that we won. I thought that he got better as the game went on. There were some third down situations early in the game where he was delivering the ball to the appropriate target but it was falling short. As the game went on I thought that he was not only making the routine plays but creating a little bit. Stepping up in the pocket and hitting Heinz down the middle of the field on the third, and on the eight and plus situation was a signature play in terms on how he evolved over the course of the game. We are going with him because we assume he is going to continue to evolve not only in this week's preparation but when he steps into that stadium as well.  (RE: Seeing Vince young as a QB:) They are not a division opponent. When we've played them it's been Kerry Collins. I'm probably not the best guy to talk about the evolution in his career. What I see is guy that's capable of beating you with his arms and his legs. He is a dangerous guy who is able to do some unique things. It is because of him. That they put you in some hairy situations when they start to run speed options and pitch to Chris Johnson. That is this week's problems. That is the awesome challenge of not only coaching but playing in this league. This I am sure that at some point later on in this week that we will be excited about.  (RE: Leftwich dressing:) We are going to see where he is in terms of dressing based on the work that we give him this week. That is to be determined.  (RE: Special teams, and your thoughts about how your punter played on Sunday:) He played really well. Daniel Sepulveda is a talented guy. We have a great deal of respect for him; he's a good punter and a good athlete. You trade up into the fourth round to get a guy that punts, he better be pretty good. And he is. (RE: On Coach Fisher and the job he's done:) I think that the program speaks for itself. He needs no endorsement from me. (RE: Leftwich comments on his mobility:) Byron is a competitor, he wants back in. I respect and appreciate that. We are going to do what our medical experts tell us. I think that is the appropriate thing, not only for him but for the team. His lack of mobility is not going to work in his favor, in terms of bringing him back. (RE: Dixon and passing the ball low:) It was not tentative. It probably had to do with excitement or aggression. Some of those third- down situations, they were bringing heat. He was speeding up the process, which caused some fundamental issues with his delivery. It's actually the opposite; he was in attack mode. It's encouraging but I like the throws a little more on target.  (RE:  Dixon in huddle:) His gamesmanship was very good. Not only on the field in terms on communication, but with the offensive unit in the huddle. Also on the sidelines and in the locker room communication with coaches, he was like a professional and what we expected.  (Were you pleased about the run game Sunday, in particular the last play?) I thought we left some yards out there. We will try to leave less out there this week. It was above the line, no question. I thought I was very physical, but I thought that we could have had better technique from an assessment stand point. We are going to work to improve in that area this week.  (RE: Isaac Redman and short yardage situations: ) I think that same thing can be said for Isaac Redman. It was positive; he moved the chains for us. He is edging out the role for himself. We are still in the early stages of the season and we will see if he can continue to do that.   (RE:  Jeff Reed missing and making long kicks: ) Any opportunity to put points on the board, I'm not going to hesitate to go to Jeff Reed. He is a good kicker, ridiculously consistent, especially in Heinz field. He's more experience and more successful than any man who has ever played in the stadium. At the end of the half, I felt good about it from a distant standpoint. He was comfortably within range in pregame from 55, and he had just banged a 52 yarder in the other direction. We actually preferred the direction he was kicking in when he kicked the 55 yarder. There was no hesitation. We thought points were going to be a potentially scarce in that game. When there is an opportunity to put points on the board, we take it, we go to him. What happened in the game or transpired in the game is not going to change our mind set of how we are in Tennessee. If we have an opportunity for Jeff to deliver for us, we will call on him and we expect him to.  (RE: Reed's Kickoffs:) I thought he did pretty good, ball placement was good. More importantly than that I thought he had quality hang time.
